div.l: Duk perotheus loued wel Arcite
And had him knowe at thebes yeer by yere
And finally atte request and prayere
Of perotheus with outen any raunsoıı̄un
Duk theseus him leet out of prisoıı̄un
Ferly to goon wheer͗e that him liste oueral
In swiche a gise as I yow tellen shal
This was the forward plenly for tendite
Bitwixen theseus and him Arcite
That if so were that Arcite were y founde
Eủere in his lyue by day or nyght or stounde
In any contree of this theseus
And he were caught it was accorded thus
That with a swerd he shold lese his hed
Ther was non oother remedy ne rede
But taketh his leue and homward he him spedde
Let him be ware his nekke lyth to wedde
How gret sorwe soffreth now arcite
The deth he feleth thurgh his hert smyte
He wepeth wayleth crieth pitously
To slen him self he wayteh priuely
He said alas the day that y was born
Now is my prisoıı̄un wars than by forn
Now is me shape eternally to dwelle
Nat only in purgatorie but in helle
Allas that eủere knewe y Perotheus
For elles hadde y dwelled with theseus
Y fetred in his prisoıı̄un eủere mo
Than had y be in blesse and nat in wo
O only the syght of hir wham that I serue
Thogh y neủere hir grace may deserue
Wold haue suffised right y noght for me
O dere cosyn Palamon quod he
Thyn ys the victorie of this auentur
Ful blisful in prison maistow dure
In prison s̉ertes nay but in paradys
Wel hath fortune y turned thee the dys
That hath the sight of hir and y thabsence
For possible is syn thow hast hir presence
And art a knyght a worthi and able
That by som cas syn fortune is chaungeable
Thow maⁱist to thi disir som tyme atteyne
But y that am exiled and barayne
Of alle grace and in so gret despeⁱir
That ther nys erthe water fir ne Eir̉e
Ne creature that of him maked is
That may me hele or doon comforte in this
Wel oght y sterue in wanhope and in distresse
Farwel my lif my lust and my gladnesse
Allas whi pleynen folke so in cōmmune
Of purueyance of god or of fortune
That yeueth hem ful ofte in many a gyse
Wel better than they kan hem self deuise
Som man desireth for to haue richesse
That cause is of his moerdre or gret sekenesse
And som man wolde out of his prisoıı̄un fayn
That in his hous of his myne slayn
Infinite harmes ben in this matere
We wot nat what thyng that we prayen heere
We fare here as he that dronke is as a mous
A dronke man wot wel he hath as as an hous
But he noot which the right weye is theder
And to a dronke man the weye is slider
And certes in this worlde so faren we
We seken faste after felecite
But we goon wrong ful ofte trewely
Thus may we seyn alle and namelyche y
That wende and hadde a grette opinyo
That yf y myght stapen from prison
Than had y ben in ioye and ꝓprofitt heele
Ther now y am exaled fro my wele
Syn that y may nat seen you Emelye
I nam but ded ther nys no remedie
¶ Vpon that other side palamon
Whan that he wiste Arcite was agon Lemon
Swich sorwe he maketh that the gret tour
Resouneth of his yowlyng and clamour
The pure fettres of his shenes grete
Were of his bittre salt teres weete
Allas quod he Arcita cosin myn
Of al our strif god wot the frut is thyn
Thow walkest now at Thebes at thi large
And of my woo thow yeueste litel charge
Thow mayst syn thow hast wisdom and manhede
Assemblenalle the folk of our͗e kynrede
And make a werre so sharpe on this Cetee
That by som Auenture or som treete
Thow maist haue hir͗e to lady and to wyf
For whom that y most nedes lese my lyf
For as by way of possibilitee
Sith thou art at thi large of prisoıı̄un free
And art a lord gret is thin auantage
Moor than is myn that sterue here in cage
For y mot wepe and waille whil y leue
With al the woo that prisoıı̄un may me yeue
And eke with peyne that loue me yeueth also
That dobleth al my torment and my wo
Ther with the fir of Ialousie vp sterte
With in his brest and hent him by the herte
So wodly that he lik was to by holde
The boxtree or the asshen dede an colde
Than seide he o crwel goddes that gou͗ern
This world with biddyng of your word eterne
And writen in the table of Athamant
Your͗e ꝑparlement and your͗e eterne grant
What is man kynde more vn you y holde
Than is the sheep that rowketh in the folde
For slayn is man right as a nother beest
An dwelleth eke in prison and a rest
And hath sikenesse and gret adu͗ercitee
And ofte tymes giltles ꝑpardee
What gou͗ernance is in this p͗resciencie
That giltlees tormenteth Innocence
And yet encresseth this al my penance
That man ys bonden to his obseruance
For goddes sake to letten of his wille
Ther as a beest may al his lust fulfille
And whan a best is ded he hath no peyne
But man after his deth mot wepe and pleyne
Thogh in this world he haue cara and wo
With outen doute hit may stonden so
The answere of this lete I to dyuinys
But wel y wot that in this world gret pyne is
Allas y se a serpent or a thef /
That many a trewe man hath do meschief
Gon at his large and wher him lust may turne
But y mot ben in prison thurgh saturne
And eke thurgh Iuno Ialous and eke wood
That hath destruyed welny al the blod
Of thebes with his waste walles wyde
And Venus sleeth me on that oother syde
For Ialausie and feere of hym Arcite
Now wol y stente of palamon a lite
And lete him in his prison stille dwelle
And of Arcita forth y wol you telle
The somer passeth and the nyghtes long
Encrsseth double wyse the peynes stronge
Both of the louer and the prisoner
I noot which hath the wofuller͗e myster
For shortly for to seyn this palamon
Perpetueƚƚ ys dampned to prisoıı̄un
In cheynes and in fettres to ben ded
And Arcite is exiled vp on his hed
For eu͗ere more as out of that contree
Ne neu͗ere more ne shal his lady see
You lou͗erys ax y now this questioıı̄un
Who hath the worce Arcite or Palamon
That on may se his lady day by day
But in prison mot he dwelle alway
That other where him list may ride or go
But seen his lady shal he neu͗ere mo
Now demeth as you list ye that kan
For y wol telle forth as y began
Whan Arcite to thebes comen was
Ful ofte a day he swelte and seide allas
For seen his lady shal he neu͗ere mo
And shortly for to concluden al his wo
So muchel sorwe hadde neu͗ere creature
That is or shal whil that the world may dure
His slepe his mete his drynke is him biraft
That lene he wex and drie as is a shaft
His eyen holowe and grisly to by holde
His hew falowe and pale as asshen colde
¶ And solitari he was and eu͗ere a lone
And waylyng al the nyght makyng his moone
And if he herde song or Instrument
Than wolde he wepe he myght nat be stent
So febele were his spirtz and so lowe
And changed so that no man kowde knowe
His speche nor his voys thogh men hit herd
And in his ger͗e for al the world he ferde
Nat oonly lik the lou͗erys maladie
Of hereos but rather lik manye
Engendred of humour malencolek
By forne his celle fantastik
And shortly turned was al vp so doun
Both habit and disposicioun
Of him this woful louere daun Arcite
What shold y al day of his woo endite
Whan he endured hadde a yeer͗e or two
This cruel turment and this payne and woo
At thebes in his countree as y seide
Vp on a nyght in slepe as he hem leyde
Hem though how that the wynged god Mercure
By forn him stood and bad him to be murye
His slepi yerd in hond he bar vp right
An hat he wered vp on his heris bright
Arraied was this god as he took keep
As he was whan that Arguus took his sleep
And seide him thus to Athenes shaltow wende
Ther͗e is the shapen of thi wo an ende
And with that word Arcite wook and sterte
And truly how soore that me smerte
Quod he to Athenes right now wol y fare
Ne for no drede of deth shal y nat spare
To se my lady that y loue or serue
In hir͗e presence y recche noght to sterue
And with that word he kaght a gret a irour͗e
And saght that chaunged was al his colour͗e
And saght his visage al in a other͗e kynde
And right anon it ran him in his mynde
That sith his face was so disfigured
Of maladie the which he had endured
He myght wel if that he bar him low
Lyue in Athenes eu͗ere more vnknowe
And seen his lady welney day by day
And right a non he chaungid his array
And cladde him as a poure laborer
And allone saue only a squier
That knew his priuetee and al his cas
Which was disgised pourely as he was
Thatthenes is he gon the next way
And to the Court he went vp on a day
And at the gate he ꝓprofred his seruyse
To drugge and drawe what so men diuise
And shortly of this matere for to sein
He ful in office with a chaamberlayn
The which that was with Emelye
For he was wys and couth sone espie
Of eu͗ery seruant which that s͗erueth theere
Wel couthe he heuwen wod and water bere
For he was yong and myghty for the nones
And ther to he was strong and big of bones
To doon that eny wyght kan him deuyse
A yeer or two he was in that seruyse
Page of the chambre of Emelye the brighte
And Philostrat he seide that he highte
But half so wel biloued a man as he
Ne was ther͗e neu͗ere in Court of his degre
He was so gentil of condicioıı̄un
That thurgh out al the court was his renoıı̄un
Thei seiden that it were a charitee
That theseus wolde enhaunsen his degree
And putten him in worshipful s͗eruyse
Ther͗e as he myght his v͗ertues excersise
And thus with Inne a while his name is spronge
Both of his dedes and his god tonge
That theseus hath taken him so ner
That of his chambre he mad hym a squie
And gaf hym gold to mayntene his degree
And eke men broght hym out of his countree
Fro yeer to yeer ful pryue his rente
But honestly and sleighly he hit spente
That no man wondred how that he hit hadde
And thre yeer in this wyse his lyf he ladde
And bar him so in pes and eke in werre
Ther͗e was no man that Theseus hath derre
And in thi blisse lete I now Arcite
And speke y wol of Palamon a lyte
In dorknesse and horrible and stronge prison
This seuen yeer hath seten Palamon
For pyned what for wo and for distresse
Who feleth double soore and heuenesse
But Palamon that loue destrenth so
That wood out of his wit he goth for wo
And eke therto he is a prisoner
Perpetually nat only for a yeer
Who koude ryme in Englissh ꝓproperly
His Martirdoun for soth it ham nat I
Ther for I passe as lyghtly as y may
It fel in that seuenthe yeer of May
The thride nyght as old bokes seyn
That alle this story tellen moore pleyn
Were it bi auenture or destynee
As whan a thyng is shapen it shal be
That sone after the mydnyght Palamon
By helpyng of a freend brak his prisoıı̄un
And fleeth the Citee fast as he may go
For he had yeue his gayler drynke so
Of a clarre maad of c͗ertein wyn
With mercotikes and opie of Thebes fyn
That al that nyght though men wold him shake
The gailer sleep he myght noght a wak
How longe Iuno thurgh thi cruweltee
Woltow werreyen Thebes the Citee
Allas y broght is to confucioıı̄un
The blod roial of Cadme and Amphioıı̄un
Of Cadmus which that was the first man
That Thebes bulte or first the toun bigan
And of the Cytee first was crowned kyng
Of his lynage am I and of spryng
Be verray lyne as of the stok roial
And now I am so caitif and so thral
That he that is my mortal enemy
I serue hym as his squier porely
And yet doth Iuno me wel more shame
For I dar noght biknowe myn owen name
But ther as I was wont hight Arcite
Now hight y Philostᵃrate noght worth a myte
Allas thow Felle Mars allas Iuno
Thus hath your͗e ire oure lynage al fordo
Saue oonly me and wrecched Palamoıı̄un
That Theseus martyreth in prisoıı̄un
And ouer al this to slen me outrely The rave of love is I knowe by folliethe Marginal note appeares to be in a differend hand
Loue hath his firy darte brennyngly
I styket thurgh my trewe careful hert
That shapen was my deth erst than my shert This is no more But Pvell hatthe Marginal note appeares to be in a differend hand
Ye sleen me with your͗e eyen Emelye
Ye ben the cause wherfore that y shal deye
Of al the remenant of myn oother care
Ne sette y noght the montance of a tare
So that y kouthe don aught to your͗e plesance
And with that word he ful doun in a traunce
A longe tyme afterward he vpsterte
This Palamon that thoghte that thurgh his hert
He felt a cold swerd sodeynly glyde
For Ire he quook no lenger wold he byd
And whan that he had herd Arcites tale
As he were wood with face ded and pale
He stert hym vp out of the buskes thikke
And seide fals Arcite traytour wikke
Now artow hent that louest my lady so
For wham that y haue al this peyne and wo
And art my blod and to my consail sworne
As y ful ofte haue told the her by forne
And hast byiaped here duk Theseus
And falsly changed hast thi name Thus
I wol be ded or elles thow shalt dye
Thow shalt noght loue my lady Emelye
But y wol loue hir oonly and namoo
For y am Palamon thi mortal foo
And thogh that y no wepen haue in this place
But out of prisoıı̄un am a stert by grace
I drede noght that either thow shalt dye
Or thow ne shalt noght louen Emelye
Chees which thow wolt or thou shalt nat asterte
This Arcite with dispitous hert
Whan he him knew and hadde his tale herd
As fiers as a leon pulled out a swerd
And sayde thus by god that sitteh a boue
Nere hit that thow art sik and wood for loue
And ek that thow no wepene hast in this place
Thow sholdest neủere out of this groue pace
That thou ne sholdest deyen of myn hond
For y defie thi suretee and thi bond
Which that thou seist that y haue maad to the
What verray fool thenk wel that loue ys free
And y wol loue hir͗e maugree thi myght
And for as muche thou art a worthi knyght
And willenest to darrayne hir͗e by bataille
Haue here my trouthe to morwe I nyl nat faille
With oute wytyng of any other wight
That heer I wol be founden as a knyght
And bryngen ħarnoys right y nowe for the
And chees the beste and leue the werste for me
And mete and drynk this nyght wol y brynge
I now for the and clothes for thi beddynge
And if so be that thow my lady wynne
And slee me in this wode ther I am Inne
Thou mayst wel thy lady as for me
This Palamon answerde y grant it the
And thus thei ben deꝑpartid til a morwe
Whan ech of hem had leide his faith to borwe
O cupide out of alle charitee
O regne that wold no felow haue with thee
Ful sooth is seid that loue ne lordshipe
Wol noght his thankes haue no felawshipe
Wel fynden that Arcite and Palamon
Arcite is riden a non vn to the toun̄
And on the morwe er it were days light John Slechenden
Ful priuely two ħarnes hath he dight
Both suffisant and mete to darrayne
The bataille in the feeld bytwix hem tweyne
And on his hors allone as he was borne
He carieth al his ħarnoys hym byforne
And in the groue at tyme an place y set
This Arcite and this Palamoıı̄un ben met
To changen gan the colour in her face
Right the hunter the regne of Trace
That stondeth atte gappe with a spere
Whan honted is the leon or the bere
And hereth hym come russhyng in the greues
And breketh bothe bowes and the leues
And th my mortal enemy
With oute faille he most be ded or
For outher y mot sleen hym atte gappe
Or he mot sleen me if that me my shappe
So Ferden they in changyng of hir hewe
As fer as euerich of hem oother knewe
Ther nas no good day ne no saluynge
But streight with outen word or rehersynge
Euerich of hem helpeth for to arme oother
As freenly as he were his owene brother
And after that with sharpe speres stronge
Thei foynen ech at other wonder longe
Thow myghtest wene this palamon
In his fightyng were a wood leoıı̄un
As a cruel tigre was Arcite
As wild bores gonnen they to smyte
That forthem whit as foom for yre wood
Vp to the anclee foght thei in hir blood
And in this wyse I lete hem fightyng dwelle
And forth y wol of Theseus you telle
The destynee mynystre general
That executeh in the world oủeral
The purueyance that god hath sent byforn
So strōng it is that thogh the world had sworn
The contrarie of a thyng by ye or nay
Yet som tyme hit shal fallen on a day
That falleth nat efte with In a thowsand yeere
For c̉erteinly oure appetites here
Be it of werre or pees or hate or loue
Al is this ruled by the sight a boue
This mene y now by myghty Theseus
That for to hunten is so desirus
And namely at the gret herte in may
That in his bed ther daweth hym no day
That he nys clad an redy for to ryde
With hunte and horn and houndes him bysyd
For in his huntyng hath he swych delit
That it is al his ioye and appetit
To ben hym self the grette hertes bane
For after Mars he serueth now dyane
Cleer was the day as y haue told er this
And Theseus with al ioy and blis
With ypolita the faire queene
And Emelye clothed al in grene
On hountynge be they riden really
And to the groue that stood ful fast by
In which ther was an hert as men hym tolde
Duk Theseus the stryght wey hath holde
And to the launde he rydeth him ful right
For thus was the hert wont haue his flight
And ouer a brok and so forth on his weye
This duk wol han a cours at him or tweye
With houndes swich as that him list comaunde
And whan this Duk was comen to the laıı̄unde
Vnder the sonne he loketh and a non
He was war of Arcite and Palamon
That foghten breme as it were boles two
The bright swerdes wenten to and fro
So hidously that with the lest strook
It semeth as is it wolde falle an ook
But what they were he ne woot
This duk his Curser with his spores smoot
And at a stert he was bytwix hem two
And pulled out a swerd and criede ho
Namoore vp peyne of lesing of your͗e hed
By myghty Mars he shal a non be ded
That smyteth any strook that y may seen
But telleth me what myster men ye ben
That ben so hardy for to fyghte heer
With outen any Iuge or other officee
As it were in a listes rially
This Palamon answered hastyly
And seide sire what nedeth wordes mo
We haue the deth deserued both two
To woful wreches be we two caiteues
That ben emcomberd of owere owne lyues
And as thou art a righful lorde and Iuge
Ne yeue vs mercy neither refuge
But sle me first for seint charitee
But sle my felawe as wel as mee
Or sle him first thogh thou knowest it lyte
This is thi mortal fo this is Arcite
That fro thi lond is banysshed on his hed
For which he hath deserued to be ded
For this is he that coom vn to thi gate
And seide that he highte philostrate
Thus hath he iaped thes ful many a yeer͗e
And thou hast maked him thi chief squyer͗e
And this is he that loueth Emelye
For sith the day is comen that I shal dye
I make pleynly my confessioıı̄un
That y am thilk woful Palamoıı̄un
That hath thi prisoıı̄un broke wikkedly
I am thi mortal fo and it am I
That loueth so Emelya the brighte
That y wol daye present in hir͗e sighte
Therfore y axe deth and IuweseInstyce Iuwese Instyce
But sle my felawe in the same wyse
For bothe we haue deserued to be slayn
This worthi duk answerd a gayn
And seide this is a short conclusioıı̄un
Youre owne mouth by your confessioıı̄un
Hath dampned you and y wol hit recorde
It nedeth noght to pyne you with the cord
Ye shul beded by myghty mars the rede
The queene a non for verray wōmman hede
Gan for to wepe and so ded Emelye
And alle the ladyes in the compaignye
Gret pitee was it as it thoughte hem alle
That eủere swych a chaunce shulde by falle
For gentil men they were of gret estat
And no thyng but for loue was this debat
And sagh hir blody wondes wyde and soore
And alle criden bothe lasse and moree
Haue mercy lorde vp on vs wommen alle
And on hir̉e h bare be knees a doun they falle
And wolde haue kyst his feet ther as he stood
Tyl atte laste a slaked was his mood
For pyte renneth soone in gentil herte
And thogh he first for Ire quook and sterte
He hath considered shortly in a clause
The trespas of hem bothe and ek the cause
And al thogh that his Ire her giftgilt gift gilt accused
Yet his resoıı̄un he hem bothe excused
Al thus he thoghte wel that eủery man
Wol helpen hym self in loue if that he kan
And ek delyủere hym self out of prisoıı̄un
And ek his hert hadde compassioıı̄un
Of wommen for thei weptoıı̄un eủery choon
And in his gentil hert he thoght a non
And softe vn to him self he seide fy
Vp on a lord that wol haue no mersy
But be alyon both in worde and dede
To him that ben in repentance and drede
As wel as to a proud despitous man
That wol mayntene that he first by gan
That lord hath lytel of discrecioıı̄un
That in shi swich a cas kan no diuisioıı̄u
But weyeth pride and humblesse after oon̄
And shortly whan his Ire is thus a goon̄
He gan to loken vp with eyen lighte
And spak thise same wordes al on highte
The god of loue a benedicitee
How myghty and how gret a lord is hee
A yeins his myght ther gayneth non obstacles
He may be clepid a god for his myracles
For he kan maken at his owene gise
Of eủerych hert as that hym liste deuyse
Lo here this Arcite and this Palamon
That quyt were out of my prisoıı̄un
And mych haue lyued in Thebes really
And wyten I am hir mortal enemy
And that hir deth lith in my myght also
And yet hath loue maugree hir eyen two
Broght hem hider both for to dye
Now loketh is nat that an hyfolye
Ho may ben a fool but yf he loue
By hold for goddes sake that sit a boue
Se how thei blede be thei noght wel arrayed
Thus hath hir lord the god of loue hem payed
Hir wages and hir fees for her seruise
And yet thei wenen for to be ful wyse
That seruen loue for aught that may bifalle
And this is yet the beste game of alle
That she for whom thei haue this iolite
Kan hem therfore as muche thank as me
She woot no moore of al this hote fare
By god than woot a kokkow or an hare
But al moot ben assaied hoot and cold
A man|mot ben a fool other yong or old
I woot it by my self ful yore a gon
For in my tyme a seruant was I oo
And therfore syn y koude of louers peyne
And woot hoow sore it kan a man destreyne
As he that hath ben kaght ofte in his laas
I you for yeue al hoolis trespas
At requeste of the quthat kneleth here
And ek of Emelye my suster dere
And ye shal both a noon vn to me swere
That neủere more ye shal my contree dere
Ne make werre vp on me nyght nor day
But ben my frendes in that ye may
I you for yeue this trespas euerydel
And they hym sworen his axyng faire and wel
And hym of lordshipe and of mercy preide
And he hym graunted grace and thus he saide
To speke of Roial lynage and richesse
Thogh that she were a queene or a pryncesse
Ech of you bothe is worthi doutelees
To wedden whan tyme is but nathelees
I speke as for my suster Emelye
For whom ye haue this strif and Ialaucie
Ye woot your̉e self she may nat wedden two
At ones thogh ye fyghten eủere mo
That on of you al be hym looth or leef
He mot gon pipyng in an yuyleef
This is to sein she may nat now han bothe
Al be he neuer̉e so Ialous ne so wrothe
And for thi I you putte in this degree
That ech of you shal haue his destynee
As hym is shape and herkneth what wyse
Lo here your̉e ende of that I shse
Mi wil is this for plat conclusioıı̄un
With outen any replycacioıı̄un
If that you liketh take it for the beste
That eủerych of you shal gon where him lest
Frely with outen raunseon or daunger
And this day fifty wekes fer ne ner
Euerich of you shal brynge an hundred knyghtes
Armyd for listes vp at al rightes
Al redy to darrayne hir͗e bi bataille
And this bi hete I you with outen faille
Vpon my trouth and as I am a knyght
That whether of you both that hath myght
This is to seyn that whether he or thow
May with his hunderd as I spak of now
Sle his contraria or out of listes dryue
Than shal I yeue Emelye to wyue
Tho whom that fortune yeueth so faire a grace
The listes shal y maken in this place
And god so wisly on my soule rewe
As I shal euen Iuge ben an trewe
Ye shul noon other ende with me make
That oon of you ne shal be ded or take
And if you thinketh this is wel ysayd
Sey your͗e auys and holdeth yow a paid
This is your͗e ende and your͗e conclusioıı̄un
Who loketh lightly but palamoıı̄un
Who spryngeth vp for ioie but Arcite
Who couth telle or who couth it endite
The ioye that is maked in the place
Whan Theseus hath doon so fair͗e a grace
But doun on knees went eu͗ery man͗er with
And thanked hym with al hir hert and myth
And namely the Thebans ofte syth
And thus with good hope and with hert blyth
They take hir leue and homward gonne they ryde
Tho Thebes with his olde walles wyde
¶I trow men wolde deme it necligence
If i for yete to tellen the despenc
Of Theseus that goth so bisily
To maken vp the listes really
That swich a noble Theatre as it was
I dar͗e wel seyn in this world ther nas
The circuyt a myle was a bowte
Walled of stoon and diched al with oute
Rounde was the shap in maner of compas
Ful of degrees the heighte of sixti pas
That whan a man was set on a degree
He letted noght his felowe for to see
Estward ther stode a gate of marbel whit
Westward right suche a nother in the oposit
And shortly to concluden̄ swich a place
Was noon in erthe in so lytel a space
For in that londe ther was no crafty man
That geometrie or Ars metryk can
Ne purtreyour ne keruer of ymages
That Theseus ne yaf mete and wages
The Theatre for to maken and deuyse
And for to doon his rithte and sacrefice
He estward hath vp on the gate a bowe
In worship of venus goddesse of loue
Doon make an Auter and an oratorye
And on the westward in memorie
Of mars he maked hath right swich a nother͗e
That coste largely of gold a fother͗e
And northward in a touret on the walle
Of alabastre with and red coral
An oratorie riche for to see
In worship of dyane goddesse of chastitee
Hath Theseus doon wroght in noble wyse
But yet had I forgeten to deuyse
The noble keruyng and the purtreitures
The shap the contenance and the figure
That weren in thise oratories three
First in the themple of venus maistow see
Wroght on the wal ful pitous to byholde
The broken slepes and the sikes colde
The sacred teeris and the waymentyng
The fyry strokes of the desiryng
That loues s̉eruantes in this lif enduren
The othes that her̉e couenantz assuren
Plesaunce and hope desir fool hardinesse
Beautee and youthe baudrie richesse
Charmes and force lesynges flaterie
Despence bisynesse and Ialousie
That wered of yolow gooldes a gerlond
And a kokkow sittyng on hir̉e hand
Festes instrumentes caroles daunces
Lust and array and alle the cricumstaunces
Of loue whiche that I rekene and rekene shaƚƚlle
By ordre weren peynted on the waƚƚlle
And mo than I can make of mencioıı̄un
For soothli al the Movnt of Citheroıı̄un
Ther̉e Venus hath hir pryncipal dwellynge
Was shewed on the wal in purtreyynge
With al the gardyn and the lustynesse
Nat was for yeten the porter ydelnesse
Ne narcysus the fayre of yore a gon
Ne yet the folye of kyng Salamon
Ne yet the gret strenthe of Ercules
Thenchauntementꝭes of Medea and circes
Ne of Turnes with the hardy fiers corage
The riche Cresus caitif in seruage
Thus May ye seen that wisdom nerychesse
Beaute ne sleighte strengthes hardynesse
Ne may with venus halden chamꝑpartie
For as hir lust the world than may she gy
Lo al this folk so caght were in hir las
Til they ful ofte wo seyde allas
Suffiseth here ensamples on or two
And thogh I koude rekene a thousand mo
¶The statue of Venus glorious for to se
Was naked fletyng in the large see
And fro the nauel doun al couered was
With wawes grene and bright as any glas
A Citole in hir͗e right hand hadde she
And on hir hed ful semely for to se
A Rose gerlond fressh and wel smellynge
A boue hir͗e heed hir͗e douves fleikerynge
Bi forne hir͗e stood hir͗e sone Cupido
Vp on his sholders wynges had he two
And blynde he was as it is ofte sene
A bowe he bar͗e and arwes bryght and kene
Whi sholde I nat as wel ek telle you al
The purtreiture that was vp on the wal
With Inne the temple of myghty Mars the rede
And peynted was the wal in lyenthe and brede
Lik to the estres of the grissly place
That highte the grete temple of Mars in Trace
In thilke colde frosty Region
Ther͗e as Mars hath his sou͗ereigne mansion̄
First in the wal was peynted aforest
In whiche ther dwelleth neither man ne best
With knotty knarry barayne trees olde
Of stubbes sharp and hydous to byholde
In which ther͗e ran a rumbel in a swogh
As thogh a storme shuld bresten eu͗ery bogh
And doun ward from an hiƚƚ vnder a bent
Ther stood the temple of Mars armypotent
Wroght al of burned steel of whiche the entree
Was longe and streyt and gastly for to se
And ther out cam a rage and swich a veze
That it made al the gat forto rese
The northren light in at the dores shoon
For wyndow on the wal was ther͗e noon
Thurgh whiche men myghten any light destre desterne destre desterne
The dore was of adamaund eterne
I clenched ouerthwart and endelong
With Iren togh and for to make it strong
Eu͗ery peler the temple to sustene
Was tonne gret of Iren bright and shene
Ther͗e say I first the derke ymagnynge
Of felonye and alle the compassynge
The creuel Ire reed as any glede
The pikepurs and eke the pale drede
The smyler with the knyf vnder the cloke
The shepud brennyng with the blake smoke
The tresoıı̄un of the mordryng in the bed
The open werres with wounde al bibled
Contek with blody knyf and sharp manace
And ful of chirkyng was that sory place
The sleer of him self yit saw I there
His hert blod hath bathed al his here
The nayl y dryuen in the shode a nyght
The colde deth with mouth gapyng vpright
A myddes of the Temple sat meschaunce
With discomfort and sory contenaunce
Yet saugh I wodnesse laughyng in his rage
Armed compleynt out hees and fiers outrage
The careyne in the bussh with throte y corue
A thousand slayne and noght of qualme y storue
The tiraunt with the preye byforce yrafte
The toun destroyed ther was no thyng lafte
Yit saugh y brent the shippes hoppesteres
The hounte strangled with wilde bere
The sowe freten the child right in the cradel
The cook y scalled for al his longe ladel
Noght was for geten by the Infortune of Marte
The cartere ouer riden with his carte
Vnder the wheel ful lowe he lay a doun
Ther was also of Martes dyiusioun
The barbour and the bochier and the smyth
That forgeth sharp swerdis on his stith
And Al a boue depeynted in a tour͗e
Saugh I conquest sittyng in gret honour͗e
With the sharpe swerd ouer his hed
Hangynge by a subtel twynes threed
Depeynted was the slaughter of Iulius
Of gret nero and of Anthonius
Al be that thilk tyme thei were vnborn
Yit was hir deth depeynted there biforn
By manasyng of Mars right bi figur͗e
So was it shewed in that pn purtreytur͗e
As is depeynted in the sterres a boue
Who shal be slayn or elles ded for loue
Suffiseth oon emsample in stories olde
I may nat reken hem alle thogh y wolde
The statue of Mars vp on a cart stood
Armed and loked grym as he were wood
And ouer his hed ther shynen two figures
Of sterres that ben cleped in Scriptures
That oon puella that other͗e Rubeus
This god of Armes was arraied thus
A wolf ther stood biforn him at his feet
With eyeun rede and of a man he eet
With subtil pencel was depeynted this storie
In redoutyng of Mars and of his glorie
¶ Now to the Temple of dyane the chaste
As shortly as I can y wol me hast

div.l: (base) To telle yow / al the discripsioun
(base) Depeynted been the walles / vp and doun
(base) Of huntyng and of shamefast chastitee
(base) Ther saw I. / how woful Calistopee
(base) Whan that Diane / agreued was with here
(base) Was turned / fro a womman / til a Bere
(base) And after was she maad / the lode sterre
(base) Thus was it peynted / I kan seye yow no ferre
(base) That shynyth in the hevy / frōm yow so ferre
(base) Hir sone is eek a sterre / as men may see
(base) Ther saw I Dane / yturned to a tree
(base) I mene nat / the goddesse Diane
(base) But Penneus doghter / which that highte Dane
(base) ¶ Ther saw I Attheon / an hert ymaked
(base) For vengeaunce / that he saw Diane al naked
(base) I seigh / how that hise houndes haue hym caught
(base) And freten hym / for that they knewe hym naught
(base) ¶ Yet peynted was / a litel ferther moor
(base) How Atthalante / hunted the wilde boor
(base) And Meleagree / and many another mo
(base) For which Diane / wroghte hym care and wo
(base) Ther saw I. many another wonder storie
(base) The whiche / me list nat drawen to memorie
(base) ¶ This goddesse on hert ful hye seet
(base) With smale houndes / al aboute hir feet
(base) And vnder nethe hir feet. she hadde a moone
(base) Wexinge it was / and sholde wanye soone
(base) In gaude grene / hir statue yclothed was
(base) With bowe in honde / and arwes in a cas
(base) Hir eyen caste she / ful lowe adown
(base) Ther Pluto / hath his dirke Regioun
(base) A womman trauailyng was hir biforn
(base) But for hir child / so longe was vnborn
(base) Ful pitously / lucina gan she calle
(base) And seyde help / for thow mayst best of alle
Wel coude he peynte liffuly that it wroghte
With many a flouryn he the hwes boghte
Now ben thise listes maad and Tʰeseus
That at is gret coste arrayed thus
The temple and the Theatre eủerydel
Whan it was doon him liked wonder wel
But stynte y wol of Theseus a lite
And speke of Palamoıı̄un and of Arcite
¶ The day approcheth of hir retornynge
That eủeryche sholde an hondred knyghtes brynge
The bataille to darrayne as y you tolde
And til Atthenes hir couenante for to holde
Hath eủerych of hem broght an hundred knyghtes
Wel armed for the werre at alle rightes
And sikerly there trowed many a man
That neuer̉e sithen that the world bygan
As for to speken of knyghthod of hir̉e hond
As fer as god hath maked see and lond
Nas of so fewe so noble a compaignye
For eủery wight that loued chiualrie
And wold his thankes han a passant name
Hath prayed that he myghte ben of that game
And wel was him that therto chosen̄ was
For if ther fel to morw swych a cas
Ye knowen wel that eủery lusty knyght /
That loueth ꝑparamours and hath his myght
Were hit in Engelond or elles where
Thei wolde hir thankes wilnen to be there
To fighte for a lady a benedicitee
It were a lusty sighte for to see
And right so ferden thei with palamoıı̄un
With him ther̉e wenton knyghtes many on̄
Som wol ben armed in an habergoıı̄un
And in a brest plate and in a lithte gipoıı̄u
And som wol haue a payre plates large
And som wol haue pruce seeld or a targe
Som wol ben armed on his legges wele
And haue an axe and som a mace of stele
Ther nys no newe gise that it nas old
Armed were thei as y haue you told
Eu͗erych after his opinyoıı̄un
Ther maistow seen comyng with Palamoıı̄un
Lygurge hym self the grete kyng of Trace
Blak was his berd and manly was his face
The cercles of his eyen in his hed
Thei glouden bitwixen yelowe and red
And lik a griffon loked he a bowte
With kempe heres on his browes stoute
His lymes grete his braunes hard and stronge
His sholders brode his armes rounde and longe
And as the gyse was in his contree
Ful hey vp on a chaar of gold stood hee
With foure white boles in the Trays
In stede of cote Armure auer his ħharnays
With nayles yelowe and brithte as any gold
He had a beres skyn̄ colblak for old
His longe here was kembed by hynde his bak
As any rauenes fether it shoon for blak
A wrethe of gold armgret of huge wyghte
Vp on his hede set ful of stones brighte
Of fyne rubeus and of diamauntz
A boute his chaar ther wenten white Alauntz
Twenty and mo as gret as any steer
To huntoıı̄un at the lioıı̄un or the deer
And folowed him with mo sel fast ybounde
Colered of gold and turretes filed rounde
An houndred lordes haadde he in his route
Armed ful wel with hertes sterne and stoute
div.fw: with Arcite in stories as men fynd
div.l: With Arcite in stories as men fynde
The grete Emetryus the kyng of ynde
Vp on a steed bay trapped in steel
Couered in cloth of gold diapred weel
Cam rydyng lyk the god of Armes Mars
His cote Armure was of cloth of Tras
Couched with ꝑperles white and round and gret
His sadel was of brend glod newe y bete
A mantlet vp on his sholder hangyng
Bret ful o Rubies red as fir sparklyng
His crispe heer lyk rynges was y ronne
And that was yelowe and glitered as the sonne
His nose was heigh his eyen bright citryn
His leppes rounde his colour was sangwyn
A few frekenes in his face yspereynd
By twyx yelewe and somdel blak ymeynd
And as a leon he his lokyng caste
Of fyue and twenty yeer his age I caste
His berd was wel by gonne for to sprynge
His vois was as a trompe thonderynge
Vp on his hed he wered of laurer grene
A gerlond fressh and lusty for to sene
Vp on his hond he bar͗e for his deduyt
An Egle tame as any lyly whit
An hondred lordes had he with him there
Al armed saue hir handes in al hir gere
Ful richely yn al maner͗e thinges
For trusteth wel that dukes Erles kynges
Were gadered in this noble compaignye
For loue and encresse of chyualrye
A boute this kyng ther͗e ran on eu͗ery part
Ful many a tame leon and leopard
And this wyse thise lordes alle and some
Ben on the Sonday to the Citee com
A boute prime and in the toun a light
This Theseus this duk this worthi knyght
Whan he had broght hem to his Citee
And Inned hem eủerch at his degree
He festeth hem and doth so gret labour
To esen hem and don hem al honour
That yit men wenen that no mannes wit
Of non estat ne coude amende it
The mynstralcye the seruice atte feest
The grete yiftes to the meest and lest
The riche array of Theseus paleys
Ne who sat first ne last vp on the deys
What ladies fairest ben or best daunsynge
Or which of hem kan dancen best and synge
Ne who most felyngly speketh of loue
What haukes setten on the ꝑperche a boue
What houndes liggen on the floor a doun
Of al this make I now no mencioun
But al thefect thenketh me the beste
Now comth the point and herkeneth if you leste
¶ The sonday nyght or day bygan to sprynge
Whan Palamon the lark herd synge
Al thogh it nere nat day by houres two
Yit songe the larke and Palamon right tho
With holy hert and with an hye corage
He roos to wenden on his pilgrymage
Vn to the blisful Cetherea benygne
I mene Venus honurable and digne
And in hir͗e hour he walkedh forth a paas
Vn to the listes there hir temple was
And doun he kneleth and with humble cheere
And hert soor he seyde as ye shal here
Fairest of fair o lady myn Venus
Doghter of Ioue and spouuse to Vulcanu
Thow glader͗e of the mount of Cetheroıı̄un
For thilk loue thow haddest to Adooıı̄un
Haue pitee on my bitter teeres smert
And tak myn humble prayer at thyn hert
Allas I ne haue no langage to telle
Theffect ne the torment of h myn helle
Myn hert may nat myn harmes biwreye
I am so confuce that I kan nat seye
But mercy lady bright that knowest wele
My thoght and seest what harmes that I fel
Considre al this and rewe vp on̄ my soore
As wisly as I shal for eu͗ere more
Enforce my myght thi trewe seruant to be
And holden werre al way with cha cha
That make I myn a vow so ye me helpe
Y kepe noght of Armes for to yelpe
Ne I ne axe nat to morwe to haue victorie
Ne renoun in this caas ne veyne glorie
Of pris of Armes blowen vp and doun
But y wold haue fully poscessioun
Of Emelye and deye in thi s͗eruice
Fynde thow the manere how and in what
I recke nat but it may better͗e be
To haue victorie of hem or thei of me
So that y haue my lady in myn Armes
For thoght so be that Mars is god of Armes
Youre vertu ys so gret in heuene a boue
That if thouyou thou you list I shal wel haue my lo
Thi temple wol y worship eu͗ere mo
And on thin Auter where I ryde or go
I wol do sacrifice and fires bete
And if ye wol nat so my lady swete
Than praye I the to morw with a spere
That Arcite me thurgh the hert ber

Vp on̄ hir heed was set ful faire and meete
Two fires on the Auter gan she beete
And dide hir͗e thynges as men may biholde
In State of thebes and thise bokes olde
Whan kynled was the fir͗e with pitous cheere
Vn to diane she spak as ye may here
O chaste goddesse of the wodes grene
To whom both heuene and erthe see is sene
Queene of the Regne of pluto derk and lowe
Goddesse of Maydens that myn hert hast knowe
Ful many a yeer and woost what y desyre
As keep me fro thi vengeance and thin Ire
That Attheon a boghte crewelle
Chaste goddesce wel wostow that I
Desere for to ben a mayden al my lif
Ne neu͗ere wol I be no loue ne wif
I am thow woost yit of thi compaignye
A mayde and loue huntynge and venerie
And for to walken in the wodes wylde
And noght to ben a wyf and be with childe
Nat wol I knowe compaygnye of man
Now helpe me lady sith ye may and kan
For tho thre formes that thow hast in thee
And Palamon that hath swych loue to me
And ek Arcite that loueth me so soore
This grace I preye the with houten more
As send loue and pees bitwix hem to
And fro me torne a wey hir͗e hertes so
That al hir͗e hoote loue and hir͗e desir͗e
And al hir͗e besi torment and hir͗e fir͗e
Be queynt or torned in a nother͗e place
And yf so be thow wolt nat do me grace
Or if my destynee be shapen so
That I shal nedes hau oon of hem tw
As send me hym that most desireth me
Byholde goddesse of clene chastite
The bittere teeres that on my cheches falle
Syn thou art mayde and keper of ??? alle
My maydenhod thou kepe and wel conserue
And whille I leue a mayde I wol the serue
The fires brenne vp on̄ the Auter clere
Whil Emelye was thus in hir preyere
But sodeynly she seigh a sight queynte
For right a noon on f of the fires queynte
And quyked a gayn and after that a non
That other͗e fir was queynt and a gon̄
And as it queynte it made a whistlynge
As doon thise wete brondes in hir͗e brennynge
And at the brondes end out ran a noon
As it were blody dropes many oon
For which so sore a gast was Emelye
That she was neigh mad and gan to crie
For she ne wist what it signefied
But oonly for the fe feere thus hath she cried
And weep that it was pitee for to here
And therwith al diane gan apere
With bowe in honde right as an hounteresse
And seide doghter͗e stynt thin heuynesse
A mong the goddes hye it is affermed
And by et͗erne word writen and confermed
Thow shalt be wedded vn to oon of tho
That han for the so muche care and wo
But vnto which of hem I may noght telle
Far͗e wel for I ne may no lenger͗e dwelle
The fieres which that on myn Auter͗e brenne
Shul the declaren er͗e that thou go henne
Thyn auentre of loue as in this cas
And with that word the Arwes in the ca
Of the goddes clateren fast and rynge
And forthe she wente and made a vanyssh
For which this Emelye a stoned was
And seid what a mounteth this allas
I putte me in thi ꝓproteccoıı̄un
Dyane and in thi disposicioıı̄un
And home she goth a non the nexte weye
This is theffecte ther͗e nys no more to seye
¶ The nexte houre of Mars folwyng this
Arcite vn to the temple walked is
Of fierse Mars to doon his sacrifice
With alle the rytes of his payen wyse
With pitous hert and heigh deuocioıı̄un
Rght thus to mars he seide his orisoıı̄un
O stronge god that in the regnes colde
Of Tarce honured art and lord y holde
And hast in eủery regne and eủery lond
Of Armes al the bridel in thin hond
And hem fortunest as the lyst deuyse
Accepte of me my pitous sacrifice
If so be that my youthe may deserue
And that my myght be worthe for to serue
Thi godhede and that I may ben oon of
Thanne pray I the to rewe vp on̄ my pyn
For thilk peyne an thilk hoote fir
In whiche thow whilom brendest for de
Whan that thow vsedest the beautee
Of faire yonge fressh Venus free
And haddest hir̉e in Armes at thi wille
And though the ones on a tyme mysfille
Whan Vulcaanis had caght the in his las
And fond the liggyng bi his wif allas
For thilk sorw that was in thin hert
Haue routh as wel vp on̄ my peynes smer

And swethe smel the grounde a non vp yaf
And Arcita a non his hand vp haf
And more encence in to the fier͗e he caste
With other͗e rites mo and at laste
The statue of Mars bi gan his hauberke rynge
And with that soun he herd a murmurynge
Ful lowe and dym that seide thus victorie
For which he yaf to Mars honour͗e and glorie
And thus in ioye and hope wel to fare
Arcite a non in to his In is fare
As fayn as foule o is of the bright sonne
And right a non swich strif ther͗e is bygonne
For thilk grantyng in the heuene a bove
Bytwixe Venus the goddesse of loue
And Mars the sterne god Armipotente
That Iuppiter was bysy it to stente
Til that the pale Saturnus the colde
That knew so manye of auentures olde
Fond in his olde exꝑperience and art
That he ful sone hath plesed eu͗ey part
As sooth is seide elde hath gret auantage
In elde is bothe wisdom and vsage
Men may the olde at renne and noght at rede
Saturne a non to stente strif and drede
Al be it that it is a gayn his kynde
Of al this strif he gan a remedy fynde
Mi dere doghter͗e Venus quod Saturne
Mi cours that hath so wyde for to turne
Hath moore power͗e than woot any man
Myn is the drynchyng in the See so wan
Myn is the prisōn in the derke cote
Myn is the stranlyng by the throte
The murmour͗e and cherles rebellyng
The groynyng and the pryue empoysonyn
I do vengeance and pleyn correccioıı̄un
Whil I dwelle in the sygne of the leoıı̄un
Myn is the ruyne of the heigh halles
The fallyng of the toures and of the walles
Vp on̄ the Mynour͗e or the Carpenter͗e
I slogh Sampsoıı̄un shakyng the piler͗e
And myn ben the maladyes colde
The derke tresoıı̄uns and the castes colde
My lokyng is the fader͗e of pestilence
Now weep no more I shal do diligence
That Palamoıı̄un is thin oewne knyght
Shal haue his ladi as thou hast him hight
Thogh Mars shal helpe his knyght yit nathelees
Bytwixe you ther͗e mot be somtime pees
Al be ye nought of o complexioıı̄un
That causeth al day swich dyuisioıı̄un
I am thin aiel redy at thi wille
Weep now no moore I shal thi lust fulfille
¶ Now wol y stenten of the goddes a boue
Of Mars and of Venus goddesse of loue
And telle you as playnly as I kan
The gret effecte for which that I be gan
Gret was the feste in Atthenes that day
And ek the lusty sesoıı̄un of that May
Made eu͗ery wight to ben in swich plesaunce
That al that monday Iuste they and daunce
And spenden hit in Venus high seruise
But by cause that they shulde rise
Erly for to seen the grete sight
Vn to hir͗e reste wente they at nyght
And on the morwe whan the day gan sprynge
Of hors of harnys noyse and claterynge
Ther͗e was in hostelryes al a bowte
And to the paleys rood ther͗e many a route
Of lordes vp on steedes and palfreys
Ther͗e mystow seen deuysyng of harnys
So vnkouth and so ryche and worth so weel
Of goldsmythrie of brouding and of styel
The sheldes bright teestres and trappures
Gold hewen helmes hauberkes cote Armures
Lordes in parementes on hir͗e courseres
Knyghtes of retenue and ek squyeres
Naylyng the speres and helmes bokelynge
Gyggynge of sheldes with layners lasynge
Ther͗e as nede is thei were nothyng ydel
The fomy steedes on the golden brydel
Ganwyng and faste the Armureis also
With file hamer͗e priken to and fro
Yenen Yemen on foote and cōmmuneus many oıı̄un
With short staues thikke as thei may goıı̄un
Pipes trompes Nakeres clariounes
Than in the bataille blowyn blody sounes
The palis ful of peples vp and doun
Here there ten holdyng hir͗e questyoun
Deuynynge of thise Thebans knyghtes two
Somme seyden thus somme seyde it shal be so
Somme helden with hym with the blake berd
Somme with the balled somme with the thikke hed
Somme seide he loked grym and he wolde fighte
He hath a sharp sparth of twenty pound of wighte
Thus was the halle ful of deuynyng
Longe aftere that the sonne gan to spryng
The grete Theseus that of his sleep a waked
With Mynstralcye and noyse that was maked
Heeld yit the chambres of his paleys ryche
Til that the Thebane knygtes bothe y liche
Honured weren and in to the palys fet
Duk Theseus is at a wyndow se
Arraied right as he were a god in Tron
The pepel preseth thiderward ful soon
Hym for to seen and don high reu͗erence
And ek thei herkend his hest and his sentence
An heraud on a schaffold made an oo
Til that the noyse of the peple was y doo
And whan he say the noyse of peple was stylle
Thus shewed he the myghty dukes wille
The lord hath of his heigh discrecion
Considered that hit were destruccion
To gentel blod to fighten in the gyse
Of mortal bataille now in this emprise
Wherfore to shapen that thei shal noght dye
He wol his firste pᵃarpos modyfye
No man therfor vp on̄ payne of los of lyf
No maner͗e shot ne pollaxe ne short knyf
In to the lystes sende or thider͗e bryng
Ne short swerd for to stoke with poynt bytyng
No man ne drawe ne bere it by the the is syde
Ne no man shal vn to his felowe ryde
But o cours with a sharpe y grounde spere
Foyne if him liste on forte him self to were
And he that is at meschief shal be take
And noght slayn but he shal be broght vn to the stake
That shal be ordeyned on other͗e side
And thider͗e he shal byforce and ther͗e a byde
And if so falle the Chifteyn be take
On other͗e side or elles sleen his make
No lenger͗e shal the torneynge laste
God spede you goth forth and lay on faste
With longe swerd and with mace fighteth your͗e fille
Go now your͗e way this is the lordes wille
The vois of peple toched the heuene
So louge cried thei with mury steuen
That hunted is or for his honger͗e wood
Ne of his preye deseireth so the blood
As Palamon to slen his foo Arcite
The Ialouse strokes on hir͗e helmes bite
Out renneth blood on both hir͗e sides rede
Som tyme ther͗e is an end of eu͗ery dede
For er͗e the sonne vn to the rest wente
The stronke kyng Emetryus gan hente
This Palamon as he faght with Arcite
And made his swerd depe in his flessh bite
And by the force of twenty is he take
Vn yolden and y drawen to the stake
And in the rescus of this Palamon
The stronge kynge lygurge is born a doun
And kyng Emetryus for al his strenthe
Is born out of his sadel a swordes lenght
So hitte him Palamon er͗e he were take
But al for noght he was brght to the stake
His hardy herte myght hym help naught
He moste a bide whan that he was caught
By force and ek by composicioıı̄un
Who sorewith now but woful Palamoıı̄un
That moot namore goon a geyn to fight
And whan that Theseus had seyn this sight
Vn to the folk that foughten thus echoıı̄un
He cried ho namore for hit is doıı̄un
I wol be trewe Iuge and nat partie
Arcite of Thebes shal haue Emelye
That by his fortune hath here faire y wonne
A non ther͗e is noyse of peple bygonne
For ioy of this so loude and high with alle
It semed that the listes shulde falle
What kan now faire Venus do a bove
What seyth she now what doth this queen of lou
But wepeth so for wantynge of hir͗e wille
Til that hir͗e teeris in the lystes fille
She seide I am a shamed dooutelees
Saturnus seide doghter hald thi pees
Mars hath his wille his knyth hath al his boone
And by my hed thow shalt ben esed soone
The tromperes with the loude mynstralcye
The herawdes that ful loude yelde and crye
Ben in hir͗e wele for ioye of daun Arcite
But herkneth me and stenteth noyse a lyte
Swhiche a myracle ther͗e by fel a non
This fiers Arcite hath of his helme ydon
And on a courser͗e for to shewe his face
He pryketh endlong the large place
Lokyng vpward vp on this Emelye
And she a gayn hym caste a frendlich eye
And was al his chire as in his herte
Out of the grounde a fuyr͗e infernal sterte
From pluto sent at requeste of Saturne
For whiche his hors for fere gan to turne
And lepte a side and foundred as he leep
And er͗e than Arcite may taken keep
He pight him on the pomel of his hed
That in the place he lay as he were ded
His brest to bresten with his sadel bowe
As blak he lay as any cole or crowe
So was the blod yronnen in his face
A non he was yborne out of the place
With herte soor to Theseus Paleys
Tho was he coruen out of his harneys
And in a bed ybroght ful fayre and blyue
For he was yit in memory and a lyue
And al way cryyge after͗e Emelye
Duk Theseus with al his compaygnye

Allas deꝑpartyng of oure compaignye (lines n=1915 and n=1914 are reversed in the text however correct placement is noted with an a and b in front of the lines and lines indicating the ending rhymes wyf and lyf that go together)
My hertes lady ender͗e of my lyf
What is this world what axeth men to haue
Now with his loue now in his cold graue
Allone with outen any compaygnye
Farwell my swete foo myn Emelie
And softe take me on your͗e armes tweye
For loue of god and herkneth what y seye
I haue here with my cosyn Palamoıı̄un
Had strif and rancour͗e many aday a goıı̄un
For loue of you and for my Ialousie
And Iuppiter so wys my soule gye
To speken of a seruant ꝓproprelye
With circumstances alle trewlye
That is to seyn trough honour knyghthede
Wysdom humblesse estat and hye kynrede
Fredom and alle that longeth to that art
So Iuppiter haue on my soule part
As in this world right nowe ne knowe I noon
So worthi to ben loued as Palamon
That serueth you and wol doon al his lyf
And yif that eu͗ere ye shal ben a wyf
For yeet nat Palamon the gentyl man
And with that word his speche faille gan
For from his feet vp to his brist was come
The colde of deth that hadde hym ouercome
And yet more ouer for in his armes twoo
The vital strenthe is lost and al a goo
Oonly the Intelleet with outen moore
That dwelled in his herte sik and soor
Gan faillen whan the herte felte deth
Dusken his eyen two and failled breth
But on his lady yet cast he his eye
His last word was mercy Emelye
His spirit chaunghed his hous and wente there
As I cam neu͗ere I kan nat tellen where
Therfor I stente I nam no dyuynystre
Of soules fynde I nat in this registre
Ne me ne luste thilke opynyons to telle
Of hem thogh that thei writen were to dwelle
Arcite is cold ther Mars his soule gye
Now wol y speken forth of Emelye
¶ Shrighte Emelye and howleth palamon
And Teseus his suster took a noon
Swownyng and bar͗e hir͗e from the corps away
What helpeth hit to tarien forth the day
To tellen how he weep both euen and morwe
For in swich cas women han swich sorowe
Whan that hir͗e housbondes ben from hom ago
That for the more part thei sorewen so
Or elles fallen in swich maladye
That atte the last c͗erteynly thei dye
Infynyte ben the sorwes and the teris
Of olde folk and folk of tendre yeris
In al the toun for the deth of this Theban
For him there wepeth both woman child and man
So gret wepyng was ther͗e noon c͗ertayn
Whan Ector was broght al Fressh y slayn
To troye allas the petie that was there
Cracchynge of chekes rentyng ek of here
Whi woldestow be ded thise women crie
And haddest gold ynow and Emelye
No man myght gladen Teseus
Sauyng his fader olde Egeu
That knew this worldes transmutacioıı̄un
Has had seyn it chaungen both vp and doun̄
Ioye after͗e wo and wo after gladnesse
And shewed hem ensample and liknesse
Right as ther daye neu͗ere man quod he
That he ne lyued in erthe in som degree
Right so ther͗e lyued neu͗ere man he seyde
In al this world that som tyme he|ne deyde
This world nys but a thurgfare ful of wo
And yewe ye we be pilgrimes passyng to and fro
Deth is an ende asof as of eu͗ery world soore
And ou͗er al this yet seyde he muche moore
To theffect ful wysly to enhorte
The peple that thei sholde hem recomforte
Duk Theseus with al his bysy cure
Caste now where that the sepulture
Of good Arcite may best y maked be
And ek most honurable in his degree
And atte the last he took conclusioıı̄un
That ther͗e as first Arcite and Palamoıı̄un
Hadden for loue the bataille hem bytwyne
That in that selue groue soote and grene
Ther͗e as he hadde his amorouse desires
His compleynt and for loue his hoote fyres
He wold make a fir in which the office
Funeral he myght al complice
And a noon comande to hakke and hewe
The okes olde and lay hem on a rewe
In colpons wel arrayed for to brenne
His officers with swifte feet thei renne
And ryde a non at his comuandemet
And after Teseus hath y sent
After͗e abere and hit al ouerspradde
With cloth of gold the richest that he hadd
And of the same suyt he cladde Arcite
Vp on his hondes his gr gloues white
Ek on his hed a croune of laurere grene
And in his honde a swerd ful bright and kene
He layd hem bare the visage on the bere
Ther with he weep that pety was to here
And for the peple shulde seen hym alle
Whan hit was day he brᵒoght hem to the halle
That roreth of criyng and the soun̄
Tho cam this woful Theban Palamoıı̄un
With flotery berd and ruggy asshe heeris
In cloothes blake ydropped al with teeres
And passyng other͗e of wepyng Emelye
The rewfuleste of alle compaignye
In as muche as the seruise sholde be
The more noble and riche in his degre
Duk Theseus leet forth three steedes brynge
That trapped weren in steel al gleterynge
And couered with the armes of daun Arcite
Vp on thise steedes greete and white
Ther͗e seten folk of which on bar͗e his sheeld
A nother his spere in his hondes heeld
The thirde bar͗e with hym his bow turkeys
Of brend gold was the caas and ek the harneys
And riden forth a paas with sorweful cheere
Toward the groue as ye shul after here
The noblest of the grekes that there were
Vp on̄ hir sholdres carieden the beere
With slak paas and eyen rede and wete
Thourgh out the Citee by the Maistre strete
That sprad was al with blak and wonder͗e hye
Right of the same is the strete y write
Vp on̄ the right hounde went olde Egeus
And on that other side duk Theseu
With vesselles in hir͗e hond of gold ful fyn̄
Al ful of hony melk and blod and wyn̄
Ek Palamoıı̄un with ful gret compaignye
And after͗e that come woful Emelye
With fir͗e in honde as was that tyme the gyse
To do the office of funeral seruice
Heigh labour͗e and ful gret apparaillynge
Was at the seruice and the fir͗e makynge
That with his grene top the heuen raught
And twenty fadme of brede the armes straught
This is to seyn the bowes were so brode
Of stree first ther͗e was layd Many a lode
But how the fir͗e was maked vp on̄ highte
Ne ek the names how the trees highte
As ook fir͗e birch aspe alder holm popler͗e
Wilow Elm Plane Assh Box Chesteyn lynde laurer͗e
Mapul thorn beech hasil ew whippultree
How they weren feld shal nat be tolde for me
Ne how the goddes rennen vp and doun
Desherited of hir͗e habitacioun
In which thei woneden in reste and pees
Nymphes Fawnes and Amadrides
Ne how the beestes and the briddes alle
Fledden for fere whan the wod was falle
Ne how the ground a gast was of the light
That was nat wont to seen the sonne bright
Ne how the fir was couched first with stree
And thanne with drie stikkes clouen a three
And thanne with grene wode and specerie
And thanne with cloth of golde and with perrie
And gerlandes hangynge with ful many a flour
The Mirre thencece with also swete sauour͗e
Ne how Arcite lay a monge al this
Ne what richesse a boute his body i
Ne how that Emely as was the gyse
Putte in the fir of funeral seruise
Ne how she swowned whan men|made|the fir͗e
Ne what she spak ne what was hir͗e desir͗e
Ne what Iewelles men in the fir͗e caste
Whan the fir was gret and brente faste
Ne how some caste hir͗e sheld and somme hir͗e spere
And of hir͗e vestimentez which thei were
And cuppes ful of wyn and blood
In to the fir͗e that brente as it were wood
Ne how the grekes with an huge route
Thries riden al the fir͗e a boute
Vp on̄ the lefte hond with a loud shoutyng
And thries with hir͗e speres clateryng
And thries how the ladies gonne crie
And how that ladde was hom ward Emelye
Ne how that Arcite was brent to asshen colde
Ne how that the liche wake was holde
al thilk nyght ne how the grekes pleye
The wake pleyes ne kepe y noght to seye
Who wrastleth best naked with oille enoynt
Ne who that bare hym best in no disioynt
I wol nat tellen al how thei goıı̄un
Hom til Attenes whan that the pleye was doıı̄un
But shortly to the poynt than wol y wende
And maken of my longe tale an ende
By ꝓproces and by length of c͗ertayn yeres
Al stent is the mornyng and the teris
Of Grekes by oon̄ general assent
Than semed me ther͗e was a ꝑparlement
At Atthenes vp on a c͗erteyn poynt and cas
A mong the which poyntes y spoken was
To haue with certein contrees alliaunce
And haue Fully of thebans obeisaunc
For which this noble Theseus a non
Leet senden after͗e gentil Palamon
Vn wist of hym what was the cause and why
But in his blake clothes sorwfully
He cam at his comandement in heye
Tho sent Theseus for Emelye
Whan they were set and husht was al the place
And Theseus a biden hath a space
Er͗e Any word cam from his wise brest
His eyen seet ther͗e as was his leest
And with a sad visage he siked stille
And after͗e that right thus he seide his wille
The firste moouere of the cause a boue
Whan he first madde the faire cheyne of loue
Gret was theffect and heigh was his entente
Wel wist he whi and what ther͗e of he ment
For with that faire cheyne of loue he bond
The fir͗e the ayr͗e the water͗e and the lond
In certeyn bondes that they may nat flee
That same prynce and that moeuer͗e qduod he
Hath stabliced in this wrecched world a doun
Certeyne dayes and duracioun
To al that is engendred in this place
Ouer͗e the which day they may nat pace
Al mow they yit the dayes a bregge
Ther͗e nedeth noon autoritee allegge
For it is preued by exꝑperience
But that me lust declaren my sentence
That may men wel by this ordre discerne
That thilke moeuer͗e stable is and eterne
Wel may men knowe but hit be a fool
That eu͗ery part is deryued from his hool
For nature hath nat taken his begynnyng
Of no partie or of cantel of a thyn
But of a thyng that ꝑparfit is and stable
Descendyng so til it be corumpable
And therfore his wyse purueyaunce
Hath so wel byset his ordinaunce
That speces of thynges and ꝓprogresions
Shullen enduren by successions
And noght eterne with outen any lye
This maistowe vnderstonde and seen atte eye
Lo the ok that hath so longe a norissynge
Fro the tyme that hit frist gynneth sprynge
And hath so long a lif as ye may see
Yit at the last wasted is the tree
Considereth ek how thow that the hard stoon
Vnder͗e our͗e foot on which wee trede and gon
It wasteth as it lyth by the waye
The brood ryuer͗e some tyme wexeth dreye
The gret townes se we wane and wende
Than ye se that al this thing hath ende
Of man and womman se we wel also
That nedes in oon of the termes two
This is to seien in youth or elles age
He moot be ded the kyng as shal a page
Som in his bed som in the depe see
Som in the large feld as ye may see
Ther helpeth noght al gooth that ilke weye
Than may I seyn that al this thyng mot deye
What maketh this but Iuppiter͗e the kyng
That is prince and cause of all thyng
Conuertyng al vn to his ꝓpropre wylle
From wich it is deryued soth to telle
And her͗e agaynes no creature on lyue
Of no degre auailleth for to stryue
Thanne is it wisdom as it thynketh me
To maken vertu of necessite
And take it weƚƚ that we may nat eschue
And namely that to vs aƚƚ is due
And who so gruccheth oght he doth folye
And rebel is to hym that al may gye
And c͗erteinly a man hath moost honour͗e
To dyen in his excellence and flour͗e
Whan he is siker͗e of his good namm name
That hath he don his frend no shame
And gladder oght his frend ben of his deth
Whan with honourtext struck through yolden is his breth
Than whan is name appalled is for age
For al forgeten is his vasselage
Than is it best as for a worthi fame
To dyen whan he is best of name
The contrari of al this is wilfulnesse
Whi grucchen we whi haue whe heuynesse
That goode Arcite of chyualrie flour͗e
Deꝑparted is with duetee and honour͗e
Oute of this foule prison of this lif
Whi grucchene her͗e his cosyn and his wif /
Of his welfare that loueth hym so wel
Kan he hym thank nay god woot neu͗ere a deƚƚ
That bothe his saiille and ek hym offende
And yit thei mowe hir͗e lustes nat amende
What may I conclude of this longe serye
But after͗e sorwe I rede vs to be merye
And thonken Iuppiter of aƚƚ his grace
And er͗e we departen from this place
I rede we make of sorwes towo
O ꝑparfit ioye lastyng eu͗ere moo
And loketh now where moost sorwe is her͗e Inne
Ther͗e wol y first amenden and bygynne
Suster͗e quod he this is my fulle assent
With alle thauys here of my ꝑparlemen
That gentel Palamoıı̄un youre owene knyght
That serueth youe with wille and hert myght
And euere hath doon syn ye first hym knewe
That ye shul of youre grace vp on hym rewe
And taken hym for housbond and for lorde
Lene me your͗e honde for that is oure accorde
Lat se now of youre wommanly pitee
He is a kynges brother sone ꝑpardee
And thogh he were a poure bachiler͗e
Syn̄ he hath serued you so many a yer͗e
And hath for you so gret adu͗ersitee
It most be considered leueth me
For gentel mercy oght to passen right
Thanne seide he thus to Palamon the knyght
I trow ther nedeth litel sermonyng
To make you assenten to this thyng
Com neer͗e and take you lady by the hond
Bitwix hem was maad a non the bond
That hight matrimoyne or mariage
By al the conseil and the baronage
And thus with alle blisse and melodie
Hath Palamoıı̄un y weddid Emelye
And god that al this world hath wroght
Send hym his loue that hath it dere a boght
For now is Palamon in alle wele
Lyuyng in blisse in richesse and in hele
And Emelye hym loueth so tenderly
And hir he hir he hir͗e serueth so gentilly
That was ther͗e no word hem bytwene
Of Ialousie or any other͗e tene
Thus endeth Palamoıı̄un and Emelye
And god saue al this faire compaigny
