div.l: (base) And clepe hym fader for youre gentilesse
(base) And Auctours shal I fynden as I gesse
(base) Now ther ye seye that I am foul and old
(base) Thanne drede yow noght to been a Cokewold
(base) For filthe and elde also mote I thee
(base) Been grete wardeyns vpon chastitee
(base) But nathelees syn I knowe youre delit
(base) I shal fulfille youre worldly appetit
(base) Chees now quod she oon of thise thynges tweye
(base) To han me foul and old til that I deye
(base) And be to yow a trewe humble wyf
(base) And neuere yow displese in al my lyf
(base) Or ellis ye wol han me yong and fair
(base) And take youre auenture of the repair
(base) That shal be to youre hous by cause of me
(base) Or in som oother place may wel be
(base) Now chees your seluen wheither that yow liketh
(base) This knyght auyseth hym and soore siketh
(base) But atte laste he seyde in this manere
(base) My lady and my loue and wyf so deere
(base) I putte me in youre wise gouernaunce
(base) Cheseth youre self which that may be moost plesaunce
(base) And moost honour to yow and me also
(base) I do no fors the wheither of the two
(base) For as yow liketh it suffiseth me
(base) Thanne haue I gete of yow maistrye quod she
(base) Syn I may chese and gouerne as me lest
(base) Ye certes wyf quod he I holde it best
(base) Kys me quod she we be no lenger wrothe
(base) For by my trouthe I wol be to yow bothe
(base) This is to seyn ye bothe fair and good
(base) I pray to god that I mote steruen wood
(base) But I to yow be also good and trewe
(base) As euere was wyf syn that the world was newe
And but I be to morwe as fayre to seene
As any lady Emꝑperice or quyene
That is by twix the Est and eke the West
Do with my lif and deth right as you list
Cast vp the quortyn loke how that it is
And whanne the knyght sey verreyly al this
That she so fayre was and so yonge ther to
For ioy he hente hir in his armes two
His hert was bathed in a bathe of blisse
A thousand tymes a rewe he gan hyr kysse
And she obeyed hym in euery thyng
That myght do hym plesance or lykyng
And thus they lyue vn to hir lyues ende
In ꝑperfit ioye and Ihu crist vs sende
Housbondes meke and yonge and fresshe a bedde
And gᵃrace to ouer byde hem that we wedde
And ek y praye Ihu shorte hir lyues
That nought wil by gouerned by hir wyues
And olde and angry nygardes of dispence
God send hem sone verrey pestilence
this worthi lymytour this noble frere
He made alwey a maner louryng chere
Vp on the Sompnoᵘur but for honestee
No vileyns worde as yit to hym spak he
But atte laste he seyde vn to the wyf
Dame quod he god yeue you right good lif
Ye haue here touched also most y thee
In scole matere gret difficulte
Ye han seide moche thyng right wel y seye
But dame as ye riden by the wey
Vs nedeth nought to speken but of game
And late autoritees in goddes name
To prechyng and to scole of clergie
But yif it like to this compaignye
I wol of a Sompnouʳ telle a game
Parde ye may wel knowe by the name
That of a Sompnouʳ may no good be seyde
I pray that noon of you be mysee paiede
A Somnpnouʳ is a renner vp and doun
With maundumentȝ for fornicacion
And is y bet at euery tounes ende
¶ Oure hoost tho spak a sire ye sholde be hende
And curtayse as a man of your͗e estate
In compaygnye we wil nou debate
Telleth your͗e tale and let the Sompnouʳ be
Nay quod the Sompnouʳ lat hym say to me
What so hym liste whan hit comth to my lot
By god y shal hym quyten eủery grot
I shall hym telle which a gret honour
It is to be a flateryng lymytour
And of many an other maner cryme
Which nedeth nat rehersen for this tyme .
And his office y shal hym telle y wis
Oure hoost answered pees no more of this
And after this he seide vn to the frere
Telle forth your͗e tale leue meister dere
Wlylome ther was dwellyng in my cuntree
An Erchedeken a man of height degree
That boldly did execucion
In punyssyng of forncacion
Of wicchecraft and ek of bauderye
Of diffamacioun and auouterie
Of cherche reues and of testamentȝ
Of contractes and ek of lak of sacrament
Of vsure and of symonye also
But certes lechours did he grettest wo
Thei shulde synge yif that thei were hent
And smal tithers were foule I shent
Yf any ꝑperson wolde vpon hym pleyne
Ther myght after hym no pecunyal peyne
For smale tithes and smale offeryng
He made the people pitously to syng
For or the bisshop caught hem in his hoke
Thei were in the Archedekens boke /
And thanne had he thurgh his Iurisdiccion
Power to doon hem correccion
He had a Sompnour redy to his honde
A slegher boy was non in Engelonde
For sotelly he had his espiaile
Thai taught hym where hym myght ought auayle
He couth spare of lechours oon or two
To teche hym to xxiiii. mo
For theigh this sompnour wood were as an hare
To telle hym harlotrie y wil nought spare
For we ben out of his correccion
Thei han of vs no Iurisdiccion
Ne neủer shul t̉erne of al here lyues
Peter so ben wōmen of the Styues
Quod the sompnour y put out of oure cure
Pees with meschaunce and with mysauenture
Thus seide oure hoost an lat hym telle his tale
Now telleth forth though the sompnour gale
Ne spareth nat my owne maistre dere
This fals thef this sompnour quod the frere
Had alwey bondes redy to his honde
As any hauke to lure in Engelonde
That tolde hym al the secree that thei knewe
For hir aqueytance was nat come of new
Thei weren his approwours pryuely
He took hym self a gret ꝓprofit therby
His maist̉er knew nat al wey what he wan
With outen maundement a lewed man
He couthe sompne vp peyne of cristes curs
And thei were glade for to fille his purs
And made hym gret festes atte nale
And right as Iudas hadde purses smale
And was a theef right swich a thef was he
His maister had but half his duetee
He was yif y shal yeuen hym his lande
A theef and ek sumpnour and a bonde
He had \eke/ wenches at his rettenue
That whether sir Robert or sir hewe
Or Iakke or Rauf or who so that it were
That lay by hem thei tolde it in his ere
Thus was the wenche and he of oon assent
And he wold fecche a feyned maundement
And somonun hym to chapitre bothe two
And pil the man and lat the wenche go
Thanne wolde he seyn frende y schal for thi sake
Do strike the out of oure łletres blake
The thar no more as in this cas trauaille
I am thi freende there y the may availle
Certeyn he knew of bribries mo
Than possible is to telle in yeres two
For in this worlde nys degge for the bowe
That can an hurt dere from an hole knowe
Bet than this sompnour͗e knew a sligh lecchour
Or an Anoutrer or a pamour
And for that was the fruyt of al his rente
Ther fore on it he sette al his entente
And so bi fil that ones on a day
This sompnour euer waytyng on his pra
Food forth to sompne a wydewe an olde ribibe
Feynynge a cause for he wolde han a bribe
And happed that he say by fore hym ride
Agay yoman vnder a forest syde
A bowe he bare and arwes bright and kene
He had vp on acourtpie of grene
An hatte vpon his hed with frenges blake
Sir quod the sompnour hayl and wel a take
Welcome quod he and eủery good felawe
Where ridestow vnder this grene wood shawe
Seyde this yoman wiltow fer to day
This sompnour hym answerd and seide nay
Here fast by quod he is myn entent
To riden for to reisen vp a rent
That longeth to my lordes duetee
Artow thanne a bailly ye quod he
He dorst nought for verry filth and shame
Sey he was a sumpnour for the name
Deꝑpardieux quod this yeman dere brother
Thow art a bailly and y am a nother
I am vnknowen as in this contree
Of thyn a queyntance I wol pray the
And ek of bretherhed yif that you list
I haue gold and siluer in my chist
If that the happe to comen in oure schire
Al shal be thyn right as thou wolt desyre
Graunt mercy quod this sumpnour͗e by my feith
Euerich in others hond his trowthe leyth
For to be sworne bretheren til thei deye
In daliaunce thei riden forth and pleye
This sumpnour which that was ful of iangles
As ful of venyme ben this wari hangles
And euere enqueryng vpon euery thyng
Brother quod he where is now youre dwellyn
And other day if that y shold you seche
This yoman hym answerd in softe speke
Brother quod he fer ni the north contree
Where as y hope some tyme y shal the see
Or we deꝑparte y shal the so wel wisse
That of myn hous ne shaltow neuer mysse
Now brother quod this sompnour y you preye
Teche me while that we ryden by the weye
Syn that ye ben a bayllif as am y
Some subteltee as telle me feithfully
In myn office how y may most wynne
And spareth nought for no conscience ne synne
But as my brother telle me how do ye
Now by my trouthe brother dere seyde he
As y shal telle the a feythful tale
Mi wages ben ful streite and ful smale
Mi lord is hard to me and dangerous
And myn office is ful laborous
And ther fore by extorcions y leue
For sothe y take al that men wol me yeue
Algate by sleight or by violence
Fro yere to yere y wynne al my dispence

Now sith ye han so holy meke a wyf/
What nedeth you thomas to make strif/
Ther nys y wis no s̉erpent so cruwel
Whan man tret on his taile ne half/ so fel
As womman is whan she hath caught an yre
Vengeance is thanne al that thei desire
Ire is a synne oon of/ the grete of seuene
Abhominauble vn to the god of/ heuene
And to hem self/ it is distruccion
This euery lewde viker or ꝑperson
Can sey how yre engendreth homiside
Ire is in soo south executour of pryde
I couthe of yre sey so moche sorow
Mi tale shulde laste til to morow
And therfore prey y god \bothe/ day and nyght
An y Irous man god sende \hym/ litel mygh
Hit is gret harme and eke gret pitee
To sette an Irous man in heigh degree
Whilom ther was an yrous pocestat
As seith Senek that duryng/ his estat
Vpon a day out riden knyghtes two
And as fortune wolde that hit were so
That oon of hem come home that other nought
A non the knyght bifor the Iuge was brought
That seide thus thow hast thi felaw slayn
For whiche y deme the to the deth c̉ertayn
And to a nother knyght comaunded he
Go lede hym to the deth y charge the
And happed as thei wenten by the weye
Toward the place ther he shulde deye
The knyght cam which men wenden had ben ded
Thanne thought thei it was the best red
To lede hem both to the Iuge a gayn
And saad lord the knyght ne hath nat slayn
His felawe here he stondeth hool a lyue
Ye shal be ded quod he so mot y thryue
That is to seyn bothe oon and two and three
And to the first ky knyght thus spak he
I dampned the thow most algates be ded
And thow also most nedes lese thyn hed
For thou art cause whi that thi felawe deyeth
And to the thirdde knyght \right/ thus he seigh
Thou hast nat doon that y comaunded the
And thus he ded do slen hem alle thre
Irrous cambises was eke dronkelewe
And delited hem to ben a shrewe
And so bifel a lord of his meyne
That loued vertuous moralitee
Seide on a day bitwix hem two right thus
A lord is lost if he h be viciou
And dronkennesse is eke a foule record
Of any man and namely in a lord
Ther is ful many an eithe and many an ere
A waytyng on a lord and he not where
For goddes loue drynk more temprely
Wyn maketh man to lesen wrecchedly
His mynde and his lymes euerichon
The reuers shaltow se quod he a non
And proue it bi thyn owne exꝑperiens
That wyn ne doth to folk no such offence
Ther is no wyn bireueth me my mygh
Of honde ne fote ne of myn eighen sight
And for despite he dranke ful mochel more
An .C. part than he had doon bifore
And right a non this Irrous cursed wrecche
Let this knyghtes sone bifore hym fecche
Comaundyng hym he sholde bifore hym stonde
And sodeynly he toke his bow on honde
And vp the strenge he pulled to his ere
And with an arwe he slowe the child right there
Now whether haue y a siker hond or non
Quod he is al my myght and mynde a goon
Hath wyn bereued me myn eighensigh
What shuld y telle tanswer of the knyght
His sone was slayn ther nys ne more to seye
By war therfore with lordes for to pleye
Syng placebo and y shal yif y can
But yf it be vn to a pore man
To a pore man men shulde his vices telle
But nought to a lorde though he shulde go to helle
Lo Irrous Cirus thilk Percien
How he destroied the Ryuer of gysen
For that an hors of his was dreynt ther Inne
Whan that he went Baluloyne to Wynn
He made that the Ryuer was so smal
That wemmen myght wade it ouer al
Lo what seid he that so wel teche can
Ne be no felow to nou Irrous man
Ne with no wood man walk by the weye
Lest the repent y wil no ferther seye
Now Thomas leue brother leue thyn Ire
Thou shalt me fynde as Iuste as is a Squyre
Hold nat the deueles knyf ay to thyn hert
Thyn angre dooth the al to sore smert
But shewe to me al thi confession
Nay quod the sik man by Seynt Symon
I haue ben shryuen this day at my curat
I haue hym tolde al holy myn estat
Nedeth no mo to speke of it seith he
But yif me list of myn humylitee
Yeue me than of thi gold to make oure cloistre
Quod he for many a muscle and many an oistre
Whan other men han ben ful wel at yese
Hath ben owre fode oure cloistre for to reyse
And yit god wot vnethe the fundament
Parfourned is ne of oure pauement
Nis nat a tyle yit with in oure wones
By god we owen .xl. pound for stones
Now help Thomas for hym that harwed helle
For elles mote we oure bokes selle
And yf you lak oure predicacion
Than goth the worlde al to destruccion
For who so fro this world wold vs byreyue
So god me saue thomas by youre leue
Ye wol byreyue out of this world the sonne
For ho so can teche and worken as we conne
And is nought of litel tyme quod he
But sythen Blye was and Blys
Han freres ben that fynde y of record
In charite thanked be oure lord
Now thomas help for Seynt charite
And doun a non he sette hym on his kne
This sik man wox wel neigh wood for Ire
He wold that the frere had ben a fyre
With his fals dissymulacion
Swich thyng as is in my possession
Quod he that may y yeue and non other
Ye sey me thus how that y am youre brother
Ye certes quod this frere ye trusteth wel
I toke oure Dame the łletre of oure sele
Now wel quod he and som what shal y yeue
Vn to youre holy Couent whil y leue
And in thyn hond thou shalt it han a non
On this condicion and other noon
That thou depart it so my dere brother
That euery frere haue as moche as other
This shaltow swere on to thi ꝓprofession
With oute fraude or caulacioun
I swere hit quod the frere vp on my feith
And therwith al his hand in his he leigh
Lo here my fey on me shal be no lak/
Now thanne put thi hand doun by my bak
Seide this man and grope wel be hynde
By nethe my buttok there shaltow fynde
A thyng that y haue hid in pryuetee
A thoughte this frere that shal go with me
And doun his hand he launcheth to the clyfte
In hope for to fynde there a yifte
And whan this sik man felt this frere
A boute his towel grope there and here
A myd his hond he let the frere a fart
Ther nys no cabel drawyng in a car
That myght han late a farte of such a soun
The frere vp sterte as doeth a wood leon
A fals cherle quod he for goddes bones
This hastow for dispit doon for the nones
Thow shalt a bye this fart yif y may
His meynee which that herden this affray
Cam lepyng in and chased out the frere
And forth he goth with a ful angry chere
And fet his felowe there as lay his store
He loked as it were a wilde bore
He grynt with his toth so was he wrooth
A sturdy pas doun to the courte he goth
Where as ther woned a man of gret honour
To whom that he was al wey confessour
This worthi man was lord of that vilage
This frere come as he were in a rage
Where as this lord sat etyng at his bord
Vnneth mygh the frere speke a word
Til atte laste he seide god you se
This lord gan to loke and seide benedicitee
What frere Iohn what maner world is this
I se wel that some thyng ther is a mys
Ye loke as though the wode were ful of theuys
Sit doun a non and telle me what youre grene is
And it shal ben amended if y may
I haue quod he had a dispite to day
God yelde you a doun in youre village
That in al this world ther nys so pore page
That he nolde haue abhomynacion
Of that y haue receyued in youre toun
And yit ne greueth me no thyng so sore
As that this olde cherle with lokkes hore
Blasphemed hath oure holy couent eke
Now maistre quod this lord y you bysek
No maistre ʆsir quod he but s̉erutour͗e
Though y haue had in scole that honour
God liketh nat that Raby men vs calle
Neither in market nyn youre large halle
No force quod he but telle me al youre grief/
Sire quod this frere an odiouse meschief
This day bitid is to myn ordre and me
And so ꝑpar consequens to eche degre
Of holy cherche god a mende it sone
Sire quod the lorde ye wote what is to done
Distempre you nought ye ben my confessour
Ye ben the salte of the erthe and the sauour͗e
For goddes loue youre pacience ye holde
Telle me your͗e greef and he a non hym tolde
As ye han herd biforn ye wot wel what
The lady of the hous ay stylle sat
Til she hadde herde what the frere seide
A goddes mother quod she blisful mayde
Is ther aught elles telle me feithfully
Madame quod he how thynketh ye therby
How that me thynketh quod she so god me spede
I say a cherle hath doon a cherles dede
What shulde y say god let hym neuer the
His sike hed is ful of vanite
I holde hym in a maner frenesie
Madame quod he by god y shal nat lye
But y on other wise may be wreke
I shal diffame hym ouer al there y speke
This fals blasphemour that charged me
To part that wol nought departed be
To eủery man y leche with meschaunce
The lord sat stylle as he were in a traunce
And in his herte he rolled vp and doun
How hath this cherle ymagniacio
To shewe suche a ꝓprobleme to a frere
Neuer est erst or now herd y such matere
I trow the deuel put it in his mynde
In ars metrik shal ther no man fynde
By for thys day of such a question
Whe sholde make a demonstracion
Tha\t/ euery man shulde han y lyke his part
As of a soun or sauour of a fart
Onyce proude cherle y shrewe his face
Lo sires quod the lord with harde grace
Who euer herde of such a thyng/ or now
To eủery man ylyke telle me how
It is an inpossible it may nat be
Ey necy cherle god lat hym neuer the
The romblyng of a fart and euery soun
Nis but of eyr͗e reverberacion
And euer hit wasted lite and lite a wey
Ther nys no man can deme by my fey
Yif it were departed equaly
What lo m my cherle lo yit how shrewedly
Vn to my confessour to day he spak/
I holde hym c̉erteynly a demenyak
Now ete youre mete and let the cherle go pley
Let hym go honge hym self a deuel weye
Now stode the lordes Squyere atte bord
That carf his mete and herde word by word
Of al thyng of which y haue you seid
Mi lord quod he be ye nought euel a paied
I couthe telle for a goune cloth
To you sire frere so ye be nat wroth
How that this fart shulde euen ydeled be
A monge youre couent yif it liked me
Telle quod the lord and thou shalt haue a non
A goune cloth by god and by seynt Ioh
Mi lord quod he whan that the weder as feyre
With outen wynd or ꝑpartourbyng of eyre
Letbrynge a cart whiel here in to this halle
But loke that it haue his spokes alle
Twelue spokes hath a cart whiel comunely
And brenge me thanne twelue freres wot ye why
For .xiy. is a couent as y gesse
Youre confessour here for his worthynesse
Shal perfourme vp the nomubre of/ this couent
Than shal thay knele doun by on assent
And to eủery spokes ende in this manere
Ful sadly lay his nose shal a frere
Youre noble confessour there god hym saue
Shal holde his nose vpright vnder the naue
Than shal this cherle with baly styf/ and tought
As any tabour hider ben y brought
And set hym on the whiel right of this cart
Vpʸon the naue and make hym lete a fart
And ye shal seen up ꝑperel of my lif
By proef which is that is demonstratif/
That equaly the soun of hit wil wende
And eke the stynke stynke vn to the spokes ende
Saue that this worthi man youre confessour
By cause he is a man of gret honour
Shal han the first fruyt as reson is
The noble vsage of freres yit is is
The worthi men of hem shul first beʆserued
And c̉erteynly he hath it wel deʆserued
He hath to day taught vs so mochel good
With prechyng in the pulpit there he stood
That y may vouche sauf y say for me
He had the first smel of fartes three
And so wolde his couent hardyly
He bereth hym so feyre and holyl
The lord the lady and eche man saue the frere
Seide that Iankyn spak in this matere
As wel as Euclyde or Protholomee
Thonkyng the cherle they seyde subtiltee
And height wit mad hym speke as he spak
He nys no fool ne no demonyak
And Iankyn hath y wonne a newe goune
Mi tale is doon we ben almost at towne
Here endeth the Somnours tale
Hic finita fabula Summonitoris
⁊and bigynneth the Secund Nonnes Tale of Seynt Cecile with oute a Ꝓprologe
the mynystre And the norice Vn to Vices
Which that men clepeth in Englissh ydelnesse
That is porter atte gate of delytes
To eschuen and by hir contrarie hir oppresse
That is to seyn by leueful bisynesse
Wel ought we to doon al oure entente
Lest that the fend thurgh ydelnesse vs hente
For he that with his thousand cordes slye
Contynuelly vs wayteth to byclappe
Whan he may man in ydelnesse espie
He can so lightly cacche hym in his trappe
Til that a man be hent right by the lappe
He nys nat war the fend hath him in honde
Wel ought we wyrche and ydelnesse \wᵗith/ stonde
And though men dradden neuer for to dye
Yit se men wel bi reson doutelee
That ydelnesse is rote \of/ slogardie
Of which ther neủere comth no good nencrees
And seen that slouthe hir holdeth in a lees
Oonly for to slepe and ete and drynke
And to deuouren al that other swynke
And for to put vs from swiche ydelnesse
That cause is of so gret confusion
I haue here doon my feithful bysynesse
After the legende in translacion
Right of the glorious lif and passion
Thou with thi gerlond wroght of rose and lilie
The nicene y mayde and martyr Seynt Cecilie
And thou that floure of Virgynes art alle
Of whom that Bernard list so wel to write
To thee at my bygynnyng y first calle
Thou confort of vs wrecches do mendite
Thi maidens deth that wan thurgh hir merite
The et̉ernal lif and ouer the feend victorie
As man may after reden in hir Storie
Thou maide and moder doghter of thi sone
Thou welle of mercy synful soules cure
In whom that god of bounte chees to wone
Thou humble and heigh ouer euery creature
Thou nobledest so ferforth oure nature
That no desdayne the maker hadde of kynde
His sone in blood and flessh to clothe and wynde
With in the cloistre blisful of thi sides
Took mannes shap the eternal loue and pees
That of the tryne compas lord and gyde is
Whom erthe and see and heuene out of relee
Ay herien and thou virgine wemmelees
Baar of thi bodi and dweltest mayde pure
The creatour of euey creature
Assembled is in thi magnificence
With mercy goodnesse and swich pitee
That thou that art the sonne of excellence
Nat oonly helpest hem that prayen the
But ofte tyme of thi benygnytee
Ful frely er that men thyn helpe beseche
Thou goost biforn and art hir lyues leche
Now helpe thou meke and blisful faire maide
Me flemed wrecche in this desert of galle
Thynk on the womman Cananee that sayde
That whelpes eten somme of the cromes alle
That from hir lordes table ben y falle
And though that y vnworthi sone of Eue
Be synful yit accepte my byleue
And for that fauthis deth with outen werkes
So for to werken yene me wit and space
That y be quite from thennes that moost derk is
And thou that art so fair and ful of grace
Be myn aduocate in that heigh place
Ther as with outen ende is songe osanna
Thou cristes moder doghter dere of Anna
And of thi light my soule in prison lighte
That trobled is by the cogitacion
Of my bodi and also bi the wighte
Of erthely lust and fals affeccion
O hauene .o. refut .o. sauacion
Of hem that ben in sorwe and in destress
Now help for to my werk y wol me dresse
Yit prayde ich you that reden that y write
For yue me that y do no diligence
This ilk stori subtily to tendite
For bothe haue y the wordes and sentence
Of hem that at the Sayntes reuerence
The story wrot and folowen hir legende
And pray you that ye wol my werk amende
First wolde y the name of Seynte Cecilie
Expoune as men may in hir stori se
It is to seyn on Englissh heuenes lilie
For pure chastnesse of virginitee
Or for she whitnesse hadde \of/ honeste
And grene of conscience and of good fame
The swote sauour lilie was hir name
Or Cecili is to seyn the wey to blynde
For she ensample was bi good techynge
Or elles Secile as y wryten fynde
Is ioyned by a maner conioynynge
Of heuene and liA and hir in figurynge
The heuene it set for thoght of holynesse
And liA for hir lastynge bisynesse
Cecili may eke be sayd in this manere
Wantynge of blyndnesse for hir grete light
Of sapience and for hir thewes clere
Or elles lo this maydens name bright
Of heuene and leos comth for whiche biryght
Men myght hir wel the heue of peple calle
Ensample of good and wyse werkes alle
For leos peple in englissh is to sey
And right as men may in the heuene se
The sonne and the moone and sterres euery wey
Right so men goostly in this mayden free
Saien of forth of magnanymytee
And eke the cleernesse hool of Sapience
And sondry werkes brighte of excellence
And right so as thise Philosophers write
That heuene is swift and round and eke brennynge
Right so was faire Cecile the white
Ful swⁱft and besy eủery in good werkynge
And roond and hool in good ꝑperceuerynge
And brennyng/ euer in charite ful brighte
Now haue y you declared what she highte
This mayden bright Cecilie as hir lif seigh
Was come of Romayns and of noble kynde
And from hir cradel vp fostred in the feith
Of crist and bar his gospel in hir mynde
She neuer cesed as y wryten fynde
Of hir praiere and god to loue and drede
Bisekyng/ hym to kepe hir͗e maydenhede
And whan this mayden shulde vn til a man
Y wedded be that was ful yonge of Age
Which that y cleped was Valerian
And day was comen of hir mariage
She ful deuoute and humble in hir corage
Vnder hir robe of goold that sat ful faire
Had next hir flessh y clode hir in an haire
And whil that the orgones maden melodie
To god allone in hir herte thus songe sh
O lord my soule and eke my body gye
Vnwemmed lest that y confonded be
And for his loue that dayde vpon the tree
Euery seconde and thirdde day she faste
Ay biddyng in hir orisons ful faste
The nyght cam and to bedde moste she gon
With hire housbonde as ofte is the manere
And pryuely she seide to hym a non
O swete and welbeloued spouse dere
Ther is a conseil and ye wolde it here
Which that right fayn y wolde vn to you seye
So that ye swere ye shul it nat biwrie
Valerian gan faste vn to hir swere
That for no cas ne thyng that myght be
He shold neuer morbiwryen here
And than at erst to hym seide she
I haue an Angel which that loueth me
That with gret loue wher so y wake or slepe
Is redy ay my body for to kepe
And if that he me felen out of drede
That ye me touche or loue in vileynye
He right a non wil sleen you with the dede
And in your͗e yowthe thus ye shulden dye
And if that ye in clene loue me geye
He wol you loue as me for youre clennesse
And shewe to you his ioye and his brightnesse
This Valerian corrected as god wolde
Answerde a gAyn if y shal trusten the
Lat me that Angel seen and hym biholde
And if that it a verrey Aungel b
Thanne wol y doon as thou hast prayed me
And if thou loue a nother man for sothe
Right with this swerd than wil y ole you bothe
Cecile answerde a noon right in this wise
If that you liste the Angel shul ye se
So that ye trowe on crist and you baptise
Goth forth to Via Apia quod she
That fro this toun ne stont but myles three
And to the poure folkes that ther dwellen
Sey hem right as y shal you telle
Telle hem that \y/ Cecile you to hem sente
To all shewen you the goode Vrban the olde
For secree nedes and for good entente
And whan that ye Seynt Vrban han biholde
Telle hem the wordes which y to you tolde
And whan that he hath purged you fro synne
Than shal ye seen that Aungel er we twynne
This Valerian is to the place goon
And right as was taught by his lernynge
He fonde this holy \olde/ Vrban a noon
Among the Seyntes burieles latyng
And he a non with outen taryynge
Dide his message and whan that he hath tolde
Vrban for ioye his hondes gan vp holde
The teeris from his eyen leet he falle
Almyghty lord IħuIhesu crist quod he
Sowere of chaast conseil hierde v of vs alle
The fruet of thilke seed of chastitee
That thou hast sowe in Cecilie tak to thee
Lo like a bisi bee with outen gil
The serueth ay thyn owene thral Cecile
For thilk spouse that she took but now
Ful like a fiers leon she sendeth heere
As meke as eủer was any lambe to you
And with that word a non ther gan appere
An olde man clad in white clothes cleere
That had a book with łletres of gf golde in honde
And gan biforn Valerian to stonde
Valerian as ded ful doun for drede
Whan he hym say and he vp hent hym tho
And on his book right thus he gan to rede
O. lord o feight o god with outen mo
O. cristendom and fader of alle also
A bouen alle and ouer alle eueriwhere
Thise wordes al with gold y writen were
Whan this was rad than seide tholde man
Leuestow this thyng or no say ye or nay
I leue alle this thyng quod Valerian
For sother thyng than this y der wel say
Vnder the heuene no wight thynke may
Tho vanysshed this olde man he nyste where
And pope Vrban hym cristned right there
Valerian gooth hoom and fynt Cecilie
With Inne his chambre with an aungel stonde
This aungel had of Roses and of lilie
Corones two the which he bar in honde
And first to Cecile as y vnderstonde
He yaf that oon and after gan he take
That other to Valerian hir mak
With body clene and with vnwemmed thought
Kepeth ay wel these corones quod he
Fro paradys to you haue y hem brought
Ne neuere mo ne shal thei roten be
Ne lese hir swote sauour trusteth me
Neuer wight shal seen hem with his eye
But he be chaast and hate vileynye
And thou Valerian for thou so sone
Assentedest to good conseil also
Sey what the lest and thou shalt han thi bone
I haue a brother quod Valeryan tho
That in this worde y loue no man so
I pray that my brother may haue grace
To knowe the trowthe as y do in this place
The angel seide god liketh thi requeste
And bothe with the palme of mmartirdom
Ye shullen come vn to his blisful reste
And with that word Tiburce his \broþ̉er/ come
And what that he the sauour vndernoom
Which that the Roses and the lilies caste
With Inne his hert he gan to wonder faste
And seide y wondre this tyme of the yere
Whennes that swote sauour cometh so
Of Rose and lilies that y smelle here
For though y hadde hem in myn hondes two
The sauour in me myghte no depper go
The swete smel that in myn hert y fynde
Hath chaunged me al in a nother kynde
Valerian seide two corones han we
Snow white and rose reed that shynen cleer

(base) Telle me anon here with gode auyse
(base) The Aungel of god hath me the trouthe ytaught
(base) Which thow shalt seen if that thow wolt reneye
(base) The ydoles and be clene and ellis nAught
(base) And of the myracle of thise corones tweye
(base) Seint Ambrose in his preface list to seye
(base) Solempnely this noble doctour deere
(base) Commendeth it and seith in this manere
(base) The palme of martirdom for to receyue
(base) Seinte Cecile fulfild of goddes yifte
(base) The world and eek hir chambre gan she weyue
(base) Witnesse Tiburces and Cecilies shrifte
(base) To whiche god of his bountee wolde shifte
(base) Corones two of floures wel smellynge
(base) And made his Aungel hem the corones brynge
(base) The mayde hath broght men to blisse aboue
(base) The world hath wist what it is worth certeyn
(base) Deuocion of chastitee to loue
(base) Tho shewed hym Cecile al open and pleyn
That al ydoles nys but a thyng in veyn
For thei ben dombe and therto thei ben deeue
And charged hym his ydoles for to leeue
Who so that troweth nat this a beest he is
Quod tho Tiburce if that y shal nat lye
And she gan kisse his brest that herde this
And was ful glad he coude trouthe espie
This day y take the for myn allye
Seide this blisful faire mayde deere
And after that she saide as ye may heere
Lo right so as the loue of crist quod she
Made me thi brother wif right in that wyse
Anoon for myn allie heer take y thee
Syn that thou wolt thyn ydoles despise
Go with thi brother now and the baptise
And make the cleene so that thou mow biholde
The Angels face of whiche thi brother tolde
Tiburce answerde and seide brother deere
First telle me whether that y shal and to what man
To whom quod he comforth with righ good cheere
I wol the lede vn to the pope Vrban
Til vrban brother myn Valerian
Quod tho tiburce woltow me thider lede
Me thynketh that it were a wonder dede
Ne menestow nat Vrban quod he tho
That is so ofte dampned to be ded
And woneth in halkes alwey to and fro
And dar nat ones putte forth his hed
Men shul hym brennen in a fyr so red
If he were founde er that men myght hym spi
And we also to bere hym compaignye
And whil we seken thilke diuinitee
That is y hid in heuene pryuely
Algate y brend in this world shul we be
To whom Cecilie answerde boldely
Men myghten dreden wel and skilfully
This lif to lese myn owene dere brother
If this were lyuyng oonly and noon other
But ther is bettere lif in oother place
That neuer shal be lost ne drede the nought
Whiche goddes sone vus tolde thurgh his grace
That fadres sone hath alle thynges wrought
And al that wroght is with a skilful thoght
The gost that fro the fader gan ꝓprocede
Hath sowled hem with outen ony drede
By word and by myracle he goddes sone
Whan he was in this world declared here
That ther was other lif ther men may wone
Tho answerde Tiburce o·suster dere
Ne sei destow right now in this manere
Ther nys but o god lord in sothfastnesse
And now of three how maisthow bere witnesse
That shal y telle quod she or y go
Right as a man hath sapiences ·iij·
Memorie engyn and intellect͗e also
So in o beynge of diuinitee
Thre ꝑpersones may ther right wel be
Tho gan she hym ful bisily to preche
Of cristes sone and of his peynes tech
Of many poyntes of his passioıı̄un
How goddes sone in this world was with holde
To doon mankynde pleyne remyssioıı̄un
That was ibounde in synne and cares colde
Al this thyng she un to tiburce tolde
And after Tyburce in good entente
With Valerian to pope Vrban he wente
That thanked god and with glad herte ⁊and light
He cristned hym and mad hym in that place
ꝐParfit in his lernyng goddes knyght
And after this Tiburce gat sweche grace
That euery day he say in tyme and space
The Aungel of god and euery man̉er bone
That he god axed it was sped ful sone
It were ful hard be ordre for to seyn
How many wondres iħuihesu for hem wroght
But atte laste to tellen short and pleyn
The sergeauntes of the town of Rome hem soghte
And hem beforn̄ almathe the profet broghte
Whiche hem apposid and knew al hir entente
And to the ymage of Iubitir hem sente
And seide who so wol nought sacrifice
Swap of his hed this my sentence here
Anon thise martirs that y yow deuyse
On Maximius that was an officere
Of the Prefectes and his corniculere
He hente and whan he forth the seyntes ladde
Hym self he weep for pete that he hade
Whan Maximius hadde herd the seyntes lore
He gat hym of the turmentours leu
And ladde hem to his hous with oute more
And with here prechyng or that it were eue
They gonnen fro the turmentours to reue
And from maxime and fro his folk sone
The false feith to trowe in god allone
Cecile cam whan it was waxen nyght
With preestes that hem cristened alle yfeere
And afterward whan day was waxen light
Cecilie hym seide with a ful stedefast chere
Now cristes owne knyghtes leef and dere
Cast al away the werkes of derknesse
And Armeth yow in armes of brighnesse
Ye han for sothe idon̄ a greet bataille
Youre cours is doon youre feigh han ye conserued
Goth ye to the corone of lif that may not faile
The rightful Iuge which ye han serued
And whan this thyng was seid as y deuyse
Men ledde hem forth to do the sacrifice
But whan they weren to the place broght
To tellen shortly the conclusioıı̄un
Thei nolde encense ne sacrifise right noght
But on here knees they setten hem a doun
With humble hert and sad deuocioıı̄un
And losten bothe hir hedes in the place
Hir sowles wenten vn to the kyng of grace
This Maximꝰus that say this thyng bitide
With pitous teerys told anon̄ right
That hir soules sagh to heuen glide
With Aungeles ful of clernesse and of light
And with his word conuertid many a wigh
For whiche almathius dede hym to be bete
With whippe of leed til he his lyf gan lete
Cecilie hym tok and bul buried hym anon̄
By Tiburce and Valerian softely
With Inne hir burying place vnder the stoon̄
And aftir this Almachius hastily
Bad his Mynystres fecchen opynly
Cecilie so that she myght in his presence
Doon sacrifice and Iubiter encense
But they conuerted at here wise lore
Wepten ful sore and yauen ful credence
Vn to hir word and creyeden moore and moore
Crist goddes sone with outen difference
Is veray god this al oure sentence
That hath so good a seruant hym to serue
This with·o·voys we trowen though we sterue
Almachius that herde of this doynge
Bad fecchen Cecilie that he myghte hir se
And aldir first lo this was his axinge
What maner wōmman art thow quod hee
I am a gentil wōmman born quod she
I axe the quod he thogh it the greue
Of thi religioıı̄un and of thi bileue
Whi thanne by gan youre question̄ folili
Quod she that woldest two answeres conclude
In·o·demaunde ye axen lewedly
Almache answered vn to that similitude
Of whennes comth thyn answeryng so rude
Of whennes quod she whan that she was freyned
Of conscience and of good feith vnfeyne
Almathius seide ne takest thou noon heede
Of my power and she answerd hym this
Your͗e myght quod she ful litel is to drede
For eủery mortal mannes power nys
But like a bladdre ful of wynd ywis
For with a nedles point whan it is blowe
May al the bost of it be leid ful low
Ful wrongfully bygonne thow quod she
And yit in wrong is al thi ꝑperseueraunce
Wostow nat how oure myghty prynces fre
Ben thus comaunded and mad ordinaunce
That eủery cristen wight shal han penaunce
But if that he his cristendom withseye
And goon al quyt if he wol it reneye
Youre Prynces erren as youre nobley dooth
Quod tho Cecilie and with a wod sentence
Ye make vs gilty and is nat sooth
For ye that knowen oure Innocence
For as moche as we doon a reuerence
To crist and for we bere a cristen name
Ye putte oute vs a cryme and ek a blame
But we that knowen thilke name so
For Vertuous we may it not withseye
Almache answerd chees on of this two
Do sacrifice or cristendom reneye
That thou mow escapen by that weye
At whiche this hody holy blissful fayre mayde
Gan for to laugh and to the Iuge seide
O Iuge confused in thi nycetee
Woltow that y reney Innocenc
To makyn me a wikked wight quod she
Lo he dissimilith here in audience
He stareth and wodeth in his aduertence
To whom almachius vncely wrecche
Ne wostow nat how fer my myght may strecche
Han nought oure myghty prynces to me yeuen
Bothe pouer and Autorite
To maken folk to dyen or to leuen
Whi spekestow so proudly thanne to me
I speke nat but stedefastly quod she
Nat proudly for y seye as for my syde
We haten dedly thilke vice of pride
And yf thou drede not a sooth to here
Thanne wil I shewe al openly be right
That thou hast made a ful gret lesyng here
Thou seist thi p̉erynces han the yeuen myght
Bothe for to sleen and for to quyken a whight
Thou that me maist but only lif bereue
Thou hast noon oder power ne no leue
But thou mayst sayn thi prynces han the maked
Ministre of deth for if thou speke of moo
Thow lyest for thi power is ful naked
Do wey thi boldnesse seide Almachius thoo
And sacrifice to goddes do er thou goo
I recche nat what wrong that thou me profer
For y can suffre it as a philosophre
But thilke wronges may y not endure
That thou spekest of oure gooddes here quod he
Cecilie answerd o nyce creature
Thou seidest no word syn thou spak to m
That y ne knew ther with thi nycetee
And that thou were in eủery man̉er wyse
A lewed officer a veyn Iustise
Ther lakkyth no thyng to thyn outer eyen
That thou thou nart blynd for thyng that we sen alle
That is a stoon that men may wel espien
That ilke a stoon a god thou wilt it calle
I rede the lat thyn hond vp on it falle
And taste it wel astoon thou shalt it fynde
Syn that thou seest nat with thyne eyen blynde
It is a shame that the peple shal
Scornen the and laugh at thi folie
For comunly men woot it wel ouer al
That myghty god is in his heuenes hye
And thise ymages wel thou maist a spie
To the ne to hem self mow nat ꝓprofite
For in effect they be noot worth a myte
Thise and swich other seyde she
And he wex wroth and bad men sholde hir lede
Hoom til hir hous and in hir hous quod he
Brenne here right in a bath with flammes rede
And as he bad right so doon was the dede
For in a bath they gonne hir faste shetthen
And nyght and day gret fir they vnder betten
The longe nyght and eke a day also
For al the fir and eke the bathes hete
She sat al cold and feled no wo
It made hir nat a drope for to swete
But in that bath hir lif she must lete
For he Almachius with a ful wikke enten
To sleen hir in the bath his sonde sent
Thre strokes in the nekke he smot hir tho
The turmentour but for no man̉er chaunce
He myght not smyte al here nekke a two
And for ther was that tyme an ordinaunce
That no man sholde doon man swich penaunce
The ferthe stroke to smyten softe and sore
This turmentour ne dorste do na more
But half ded with hir nekke ycoruen there
He left hir ly and on his weye is went
The cristen folk wich that a boute hir were
With shetes han the blod ful faire y hent
Thre dayes lyued she in this turment
And neuer sesed hem the feith to teche
That she hadde fostred hem she gan to preche
And hem she yaf here meebles and hir thyng
And to the pope Vrban bitook hem tho
And seide y axed this of heuene kyng
To haue respit thre dayes and namo
To recomende to you or that y goo
Thise sowles lo and that y myght do werche
Here of myn hous ꝑperpetuelly a cherche
Seynt Vrban with his deknes p̉reuely
The body fette and buried it be nyght
Among his oder seintes honestly
Hir hous the chirche of seynte Cecilie hight
Seynt Vrban halowed it as he wel myght
In the wheche in to this day in noble wyse
Men doon to crist and too his seynte s̉eruyse

div.l: Sire clerk of Oxenford oure Hoost sayde
Ye ride as coy and stille as dooth a mayde
Were newe spoused sittyng at the bord
This day ne herde I of your tonge a word
I trowe ye studie aboute som Sophyme
But Salomon seith euery thyng hath tyme
For goddes sake as beth of bettre cheere
It is no tyme for to studien heere
Tel vs som murie tale by youre fey
For what man that is entred in a pley
He nedes moot vn to the pley assente
But precheth nat as freres doon in lente
To maken vs for oure olde synnes wepe
Ne that thy tale make vs nat to slepe
Tel vs som murye thyng of auentures
Youre termes your colours and your figures
Kepe hem in stoor til so be ye endite
Heigh stile as whan that men to kynges write
Speketh so pleyn at this tyme we yow preye
That we may vnderstonde what ye seye
This worthy clerk benygnely answerde
Hoost quod he I am vnder your yerde
Ye han of vs as now the gouernaunce
And therfore wol I do yow obeisaunce
As fer as reson asketh hardily
I wol yow telle a tale which that I
Lerned at Padwe of a worthy Clerk
As proued by his wordes and his werk
He is now deed and nayled in his Cheste
I pray to god so yeue his soule reste
Fraunceys Petrak the lauryat poete
Highte this clerk whos Rethoryk swete
Enlumyned al Ytaille of Poetrie
As Lynyan dide of Philosophie
Or lawe or other art ꝑparticuler
But deth that wole nat suffre vs dwelle here
But as it were twynclyng of an eye
He bothe hath slayn and and all shyl we deye
But for to tellen of this worthi man
That taught me this tale as y began
I sey that fyst he with hie stile enditith
Or he the body of his tale writeth
A prohemye in the which descreuyth he
Pemond and of Saluces the countre
And speketh of appenyn the hillehilleshilleshye
That ben the boundes of Westlumbardye
And of mont Vesules in speciall
Where as the poo out of a wel small
Taketh his first sprynginge and his cours
That estward ay encheset in his cours
To Emele ward to Ferare and Venyse
The wheche a long thyng were to deuyse
And trewely as to my iugement
Me thynketh it a thyng inꝑpartinent
Sauf that he wole conueyen his matere
But this is the tale whiche that ye may here
The Clarke of Oxenforde tale
t heer is right at þe Westside of ytaille
Douwn atte rote of Vesulus the colde
A lusti pleyn haboundant of Vitaille
Ther many a toun and tour thow mayst biholde
That founded were in tyme of fadres olde
And many an other deitable sighte
And Saluces this noble contre highte
A markes whilom lord was of that lond
As were his worthi eldres hym byfore
And obeisant ay redy to his hond
Were alle his lieges both lasse and more
Thus in delit he leueth and hath doon yore
By loued and drad thurgh Fortune
Bothe of his lordes and of his comune
Ther with he was to speken of lynage
The gentillest y born of lymbardie
A fair ꝑpersone and strong and yong of age
And ful of honour and of curtesye
Discret y now his countre for to gide
Sauf in sum thynges that he was to blame
And Wauter was this yonge lordes name
I blame hym thus that he considerith nought
In tyme comyng what myght hym be tyde
But on hys lust present was al his thoght
As for to hauke and hunte on eủery side
Wel ny al other cures let he slide
And eke he nolde and that was werst of alle
Wedde no wif for ought that may befalle
Only that poynt his peple bidbarbidarso sore
That flokmel on a day to hym they wente
And on of hem that wisest was of lore
Or elles that the lord wolde best assente
That he shulde telle hym what the peple mente
Or elles coude he shewe wel swich matere
He to the Marquys seyde as ye shul here
O noble Marquys youre humanite
Assureth vs and yeue vs hardinesse
As ofte as tyme of necessitee
That we you may telle our heuynesse
Acceptith lord thanne of youre gentillesse
That we with pitous herte vn to you pleyne
And lat youre eris nat my wis desdeyne
Al haue y not do do⁊andabsent: do to do in this matere
More than another man hath in this place
Yit for as moche as ye my lord so dere
Han alwey shewed me fauour and grace
Y dar the beter aske of you a space
Of audience to shewen oure requeste
And ye my lord to do right as you leste
For certes lord so wel vs liketh you
And al youre werk and euer han doon that we
Ne coude nat oure self deuysen how
We myghten lyuen in more felicite
Sauf o thyng lord if it youre wille be
That for to be a wedded man you leste
Than were your peple in soủereyne hertes reste
Bowith youre nekke vndyr that blisful yok
Of souereynte a a⁊andabsent: a nat of seruise
Whiche that men clepen sousaile or wedlok
And thynketh lord among your thoghtes wise
How that your days passe in sundry wise
For thogh we slepe or wake or ronne or ride
Ay fleeth the tyme it wol no man abide
And though youre grene youthe floure as yit
In crepeth age alwey as stille as ston
And deth manmanacethmanacetheuery age and smyth
In eche estate for ther eschapeth non
And also certeyn as we knowe echon
That we shul dye and vncereyn we alle
Acceptith⁊andabsent:AcceptithBen of that day deth shal vn vs falle
Acceptith tanne of vs the trewe entent
That neuer yit refuseden youre heste
And ⁊andabsent:wewewol lord yf that ye wele assente
Chese you a wif in short tyme atte leste
Borne of the gentilesse and of the meste
Of al this land so that it oght seme
Honour to god and you as we can deme
Delyuere vs ⁊andabsent:outeouteof this besy drede
And take a wif for hye goddes sake
For if it so bifil as god forbede
That thurgh youre deth youre lynage shuld slake
And that a straunge successour shulde take
Youre heritage o wo were vs alyue
Wher for we pray you hastyly to wyue
Hir meke prayere and her pitous chere
Made the marquis herte han pite
Ye wold quod he myn owne peple deere
To that y neuere er thoghte streyne me
I me reioysed of my libertee
That selden tyme is funden in mariage
The y was fre y moste ben in seruage
But natheles y se youre trew entent
And truste vp on youre wit and haue doon ay
Wherfore of my fre wille y wole assente
To wedde me as sone as euere y may
But there as ye han profered me to day
To chese me a wif y you relese
That choys and preye you that ꝓprofre sese
For god it wot that children often ben
Vnlyk hir worthi eldres hem before
Bounte comyth al of god and not of the stren
Of whiche they byn engendred and ybore
I trwstein goddes bountee and ther fore
Mi mariage and myn estate and reste
I hym betake he may do as hym liste
Lat me allone in chesyng of my wif
That charge vpon my bak y wole endure
But y you preye and charge vp on youre lif
That what wif y take that ye massure
To worsshipe hir whil that hir lif may dure
In word werk bothe here and eủery where
As she emꝑperoures doughter were
And furthermore this shul ye swere that ye
Agayn my choys shul neuer grucche ne striue
For syn y shal for goo my lyberte
At your requeste as euer mot y thryıı̄une
Ther as my herte is set there wol y wyue

app.rdg: And but ye wol assente in swhich manere

div.l: I prey/you speke no more of this matere
With hertly wille they sworen and assenten
To al this thyng there seyde no wight nay
Bysekyng hym of grace or that they wenten
That he wolde graunten hem a c̉erteyn day
Of his spousaile as sone as euer he may
For yit al way the peple sum what dredde
Lest that the marquys no wif wold wedde
He graunted hem a day swich as hym leste
On whiche he wolde be wedded sikerly
And seid he did al this at hir requeste
And thei with humble entent ful buxumly
Knelyng vp on hir knees ful reuerently
Hym thanken alle and thus they han an ende
Of hir entent and hom agayn they wente
And here vp on he to his officers
Commaundith for the feste to purueye
And to his pryue knyghtes and squyers
Swiche charge yaf as hym list on hem leye
And they to his commandement obeye
And eche of hem dooth al his diligence
to do vn to the feste a reuerence
¶ pars fabule chiīm
nOught fer from thilke paleys honurable
Where as this marquys shoop his mariage
Ther stod a thorp of site delitable
In the which that pore folk of that vilage
Hadden hir bestes and hir herbergage
And of hir labour took hir sustenaunce
After the erthe yaf hem habundaunce
Among this pore folk ther dwelt a man
Whiche that was holden porest of hem alle
But hye god sum tyme sende can
His grace in to a litel oxes stalle
Ianicola men of that troop hym calle
A dowter hadde he fair ynow to sighte
And Grysildis this yonge mayde highte
But for speke of vertuous beaute
Thanne was she the fayreste vnder sonne
Ful pouerly yfostred vp was she
No likerous lust was in hir herte y ronne
Wel ofter the⁊andabsent:theof the welle than the toune Wel ofter of the welle than of the tonne
She drank and for she wolde vertu plese
She knew wel labour but non idel ese
But though this maide tendre were of age
Yit in the brest of hir virginitee
There was enclosed ripriperipeand sad corage
And in gret reuerence and charitee
Hir olde pore fader fostryd she
A fewe shep spynnyng on feeld she kepte
She wolde nat be ydel til she slepte
And whan she homward came she wolde brynge
Wortes or other erbes tymes ofte
The whiche she shredde and seth for hir lynynge
And made her bed ful hard and nothyng softe
And ay she kepte hir fadres lif on lofte
And forth ge goth with a ful sobre chere
Out atte dore and after that cam she
And to the peple he seyde in this manere
This is my wif quod he that stondeth here
Honoureth here and loueth here y preye
Ho so me loueth ther nys no more to seye
And for that no thyng of here olde gere
She shulde brynge in to his hous he bad
That wommewommenwommenshulde dispoilen hir right there
Of whiche this ladies weren no thyng glad
To handel hir clothes where in she was clad
But natheles this mayden bright of hewe
Fro foot to heed they clothed hadde al newe
Hir heres han they kempt that lay vntressed
Ful rudely and with hir fyngres smale
A corone on here hed they han ydressed
And sette it ful of nouches grete and smale
Of hir array what shulde y make a tale
Vnnethe the peple hir knewe for hir fairnesse
Whan she transmewyd was in swich richesse
This marquys hath hir spoused with a ryng
Brought for the same cause and than hir sette
Vp on an hors snow whit and wel anmblynge
And to his palys or he lengere lette
With ioyful peple that hir ladde and mette
Conueyed here and thus the day they spende
In reuel thil the sonne gaan descende
And shortly forth this matere for to chace
I sey to this new Marquysesse
Fod hath swiche fauour sent here of his grace
That it semeth nat by liklynesse
That she was born and fed in rudenesse
As in a cote or in oxe stalle
But norisshed in an Emꝑperours halle
To euery wight she waxen is do dere
And worsshipful that folk there she was bore
And from hir birthe knew hir yeer be yeer
Vnneth trowed they but durst han swore
That to Ianycle of whiche y spake before
She doughtir ne was for as be coniecture
Hem d⁊andabsent:dthought she was a nother creature
For thogh that euere vertuous was she
She was encresed in swich excellence
Of thewes goode y set in hy bountee
And so discret and fair of eloquence

div.l: A worthi knyght he leued in gret proꝑperspitethat bore was yn peuye
In which he leued in gret prosꝑperite
And . lx . yeer a wifles man was he
And folowed his body delyte
On wommen ther as was his apetite
As do thise foles that ben seculer
And whanne he was passid x lx yeer
Were it for holinesse or for dotage
Y can nat sey but swich agret corage
Hath this knyght to ben a wedded man
That day and nyght he doth al that he can
Tespien where he myghte weddid be
Preyinge oure lord to graunte hym that he
Might knowe ones of that blisful lif
That is bitwixe an husbonde and his wif
And for to leue vndir that holy bonde
With which that god man and womman bonde
Noon othir lif seyde he is worth a bene
For wedlok is so esy and so clene
That it is in hym self a paradis
Thus seyde this olde knyght that was so wys
And certeynly as soth as god is kyng
To take a wif it is a glorious thyn
And namely whan aman is old and hoor
Thanne is a wif ye furst of his tre soor
Thanne shuld he take a yonge wif and afeir
On which he myght engendren hym an Eyer
And lede his lif in yoye and solas
Where as thise bachelers synge allas
Whan that they fynde any aduersitee
In loue which nys but childisshe vanitee
And trewely it sit wel to be soo
That bachilers haue ofte peyne and woo
On brytil ground they bilde and brotilnesse
They fynde whan they wene sikernesse
Thei leue but as a bird or as a beste
In lybertee and vndir noon areste
Ther as a weddid man in his estate
Lyueth a lyf blisful and ordenate
Vndir this yok of mariage y bounde
Wel may his herte in ioye and blisse habounde
For ho can be so boxom as a wif
Who is so trewe and ek so ententif
To kepe hym seek and hool as is his make
For weele or wo she wil hym nat for sake
She is nat wery hym to loue and serue
Thoght he be bedrede til that he sterue
And yit some clerkes sey it is nat soo
Of which he theofrast is on of thoo
What fors thogh theofrast list for to lye
Ne take no wif quod for he for housboundrye
As for to spare in housholde they dispence
A trewe seruant doth more diligence
Thi good to kepe than thyn oune wif
For she wil clayme half part al hir lyf
And yf thou be seek so god me saue
Thy verrey frendes or a trewe knaue
Wol kepe the bet than she that waiteth ay
Aftir thi good and hath doon many a day
And if thou take a wif be wel y war
Of on thyng whiche y declare nedar
This sentence and an hundred thynges worse
Writith this man ther god his bones corse
But take no kepe of al such vanitee
Diffie Theofrast and herkene me
A wif is goddes yifte verrayly right
Alle other maner yiftes hardyly
As londes rentes pasture or comune
Thise bith the yiftes of fortune
That passen as a shadowe on the wal
But drede thou nat if pleynly speke y shal
A wif wol last and in thyn hous endure
Wel lengere than the list ꝑparauenture
Mariage is a ful gret sacrament
He which that hath no wif y holde hym shent
He leuyth helpelees and al desolat
Y speke of folk in seculere estat
And herkyn whi y sey nat this for noght
That womman is for mannes helpe y wroght
The hye god whan he hadde Adam y maked
And saugh hym allone baly naked
God of his greet goodnesse seyde thanne
Let vs now make an helpe vn to this manne
Lik to hym self and thanne he made hym Eue
Here may ye se and here may ye preue
That wif is mannes helpe and confort
His paradis terrestre and his disport
So buxom and so vertuous is shee
They moste nede lyue in vnitee
O flessh they ben and o flessh as y gesse
Hath but on herte in wele and in distresse
A wif a seynte Marie benedicite
How myght a man haue any aduersitee
That hath a wif certes y can nat seye
The blisshe the which is betwex hem tweye
Ther may no tonge telle or herte thynke
Yif he be poore she helpeth hym to swynke
She kepith his good and wasteth neuer adel
Al that hir husbonde doth hir liketh wel
She seith nat ones nay whan he seith ye
Do this seyth he al redy syre seith she
O blisful ordre o wedlok precious
Thou art so murie and ek so vertuous
And so comended and approued ek
That ony man that holt hym worth a leke
Vp on his bare knees oghte al his lif
Thanken his god that hym hath sente a wif
Or elles preye to god hym for to sende
A wif to laste vn to his lyues ende
For than his lif is set in sikernesse
He may nat be desceyued as y gesse
So that he werche after his wifes reed
Than may he boldely kepen vp his hed
They byn so trewe and ther with so wise
For which yif thou wolt worchen as the wyse
Do alwey so as wommen wol the reede
Lo how that Iacob as this clerkis reede
Be good conseil of his moder Rebekke
Boond the kydes skyn aboute his nekke
For which his fadres benesou he wan
Loo Iudith as the story ek telle kan
By gode conseil she goddes peple kepte
And slogh hym Olofernes whil he slepte
Loo Abygayl by good conseil how she
Sauyd hir husbonde nabal whan that he
Shulde han be slayn and loke Ester also
By good conseil deliuered out of wo
The peple of god and made hym Mardochee
Of assuere enchanted for to be
Ther nys no thyng in gree suꝑperlatif
As seith senek a boue an humble wif
Suffre thi wyues tonge as Caton bit right
She comande and thou shalt suffren it
And yit she wol obeye of curtesye
A wif is kepere of thyn husbondrie
Wel may the seek man bewayle and wepe
Ther as is no wif the hous to kepe
I warne the yf wisily thou wolt werche
Loue wel thi wif as crist loueth his cherche
Yif thou louest thi self thou louest thi wif
Noman hatith his flessh but in his lif
He Fostred hit and therfore bid he the
Cherisshe thi wif or thou shalt neuer the
Housbonde and wif what so men iape or pleye
Of wordly folk ye holden the siker weye
They ben so knyt ther may non yvel be tyde
And namely vp on the wyues syde
For which this Ianuarie of hom y tolde
Considered hath in which his dayes olde
The lusty lif the vertuous quyetee
That is in mariage hony swete
And for his freendes on a day he sente
To tellen hem theffect of his entente
With face sad this tale he hath hem tolde
He seyde freendes y am hoor and olde
And almost god woot on my pittes brynke
Vp on my soule sumwhat most y thynke
I haue my body folily despended
Blessid be god that y shal ben amended
For y wol be certeyn a weddid man
And that a non in al the hast y can
Vn to some mayde fair and tendre of age
I prey you shapeth for my mariage
Al sodeynly for y wol nat abyde
And y wol fonde tespien on my syde
To whom y may be weddid hastily
But for as myche as ye been mo than y
Ye shal rathir swich athyng espien
Than y and where me best were to allien
But athyng warne y you my frendes dere
I wol no wif han in no manere
She shal nat passe twenty yeer c̉erteyn
Old fisshe and yonge flesshe wold y haue fayn
Bet is quod he a pike than a pykerel
And bet thanne old beef is the tendre vel
I wol no womman xxxᵗⁱ yeer of age
It is but benestrawe and gret forage
And ek thise old wedues god it woot
Thi kenne so moche craft on wades boot
So mochel brokyn harm whan hem leste
That with hem sholde y neuere leue in reste
For sondry scoles makyn subtile clerkes
Womman of many scoles half a clerkis
But certeynly yonge thyng men may gye
Right as men may warm wex with handes plye
Wherfore y sey you pleynly in a clause
I wol non old wif han right for this cause
For if so were y hadde swiche meschaunce
That y in hir couche had no plesaunce
Thanne sholde y lede my lif in a uoutrye
And strenght to the deuel whan y dye
Ne children shulde y noon vp on hir geten
Yit were me leuer houndes me had y eteen
Than that myn heritage shulde falle
In straunge hondes and this y telle you alle
I doute nat y woot the cause whi
Men sholde wedde and ferther moor wot y
Ther speketh many a man of mariage
That woot no more of it than woot my page
For which causes a man shulde take a wif
Yf he ne may nat leue in chastitee his lif
Take hym a wif with gret deuociou
Be cause of leueful ꝓprocreaciou
Of children to honour of god a boue
And nat only for ꝓproamour or for loue
And for they shulde leccherie eschue
And yelde her dette whan that it is due
And for that ech of hem shulde helpen other
In meschif as a suster shal the brother
And leue in chastitee ful holyly
But sires by youre leue that am nat I
For god be thanked y dar make auaunt
I fele my lymes stark and sufficiant
To do al that a man bilongeth to
I woot my self best what y may doo
Thogh y be hoor y fare as doth a tre
That blosmeth er the fruyt y woxen be
And blosmy tree nys neyther drye ne deed
I fele me nogh wher hoor but on myn heed
Myn herte also and my lymes ben as grene
As laurer thurgh the yeer is for to sene
And syn that ye han herd al myn entent
I praye you to my conseil ye wolde assent
Dyuers men diuersly hym tolde
Of mariage many ensamples olde
Some blameth it some preysith it c̉erteyn
But atte laste shortly for to seyn
Alday fallith altercaciou
Be twixe freendes in disputisoun
Ther fil a strif betwix his brethern two
Of which that on was clepid Placebo
Iustinus sothly clepid was that other
Placebo seide o Ianuarie brother
Ful litel nede had ye my lord so dere
Conseil to axe of ony that is here
But that ye ben so ful of sapience
That you ne liketh for youre hy prudence
To weyuen fro the word of salamon
This word seide he vn to vs euerichon
Werk al thyng by conseil thus seyde he
And thanne shalt thou nat repente the
But thogh that Salamon spak swich a word
Myn one dere brother and my lord
So wisly god my soule brynge to reste
I holde youre owen conseil is the beste
For brother myn of me take this motif
I haue now ben a court man al my lif
And god it wot thogh y vnworthi bee
I haue stonden in ful gret degree
A bouten lordes in ful gret estate
Yit hadde y neuere with non of hem debate
I neuere contraried hem trewely
I wot wel that my lord can more than y
What that he seith y holde it ferme and stabule
I sey the same or elles thyng semblable
A ful gret fool is any conseillour
That serueth ony lord of hy honour
That dar presume or elles thenke it
That his conseil shulde passe his lordes wit
Nay lordes be no foles by my fay
Ye han your seluen swewed here to day
So high sentence so holily and wel
That y concente and conferme eueridel
Youre wordes alle who couth bet han y sayd
Crist holte him of this conseil ful wel apayed
And crewly it is and high corage
Of any man that stopen is in age
To take a yong wif by my fadir kyn
Youre herte hangeth on a ioly pyn
Dooth now in this matere right as you liste
For fynally y holde it for the beste
Iustinus that ay stille sat and herde
Right in thys wise he to placebo answerde
Now brethern myn be pacient y preye
Syn ye han seide herkneth what y seye
Senek amonge other wordes wise
Seith that a man oght hym right wel to auyse
To whom he yeuith his lond or his catel
And sith y oghte auyse me right wel
To whom y yeue my good a way fro me
Wel moche more y oght auysed be
To whom y yeue my body for alwey
I warne you wel it is no childes pley
To taken awif withoute auysement
Men moste enquere this is myn assent
Whether shebe wis or sobre or dronkelew
Or proude or elles othir weys a shrewe
A chidester or wastour of thi good
Or riche or pore or elles mannysshewod
Al be it so that no man fynde shal
Noon in this worl that trotteth hol al
Ne man ne beste swich as men kouth deuyse
But nathelees it oghte y now suffise
With ony wif if so were that she hadde
Moo good thewes thanne hir vices badde top
And al this axeth leyser for enquere
For god it wot y haue wept many a tere
Ful pryuely syn that y hade a wif
Preyse ho so wol a wedded mannes lif
Certeyn y fynde in it but cost and care
And obseruances an al of blisses bare
And yt god woot my neighburghe a boute
And namely of wommen many arowte
Seyn that y haue the stedefaste wif
And ek the mekeste that bereth lif
But y wot beste where wryngeth me my shoo
Ye mow for me right as you lyketh doo
Auyseth you ye be a man of age
How that ye entren in to mariage
And namely with ayonge wif and a feire
By hym that made water erthe and eyre
The yongeste man that is in al this rowte
Is besy ynogh to bryngyn it abowte
To han his wif allone trusteth me
Ye shul nat pleysen here yeeres three
This is to seyn to doon hir ful plesaunce
A wif axeth ful many an obseruaunce
Y prey you that ye be nat evel apayed
Wel quod this Ianuarie and hastow said
Straw for senek and straw for thi ꝓprouerbes
I counte nat apanyer ful of herbes
Of scoole termes a wiser man than thou
Asthou hast herd assentede righ now
To my purpos placebo what sey ye
I sey it is a cursid man quod he
That letteth matrymoyne sikerly
And with that word they risen sodenly
And ben assentid fulli that he sholde
Be wedded to whom hym lest and where he wolde
High fantasie and Curious bisinesse
Fro day to day gan in the soule impresse
Of Ianuarie abouten his mariage
Many fair shap and many a fair visage
Ther passed thurgh his herte nyght by nyght
As ho so took a myrour pollisshid bright
And sette it in a comune Market place
Thanne sholde he se ful many a figure pace
Bi his myrour and in the same wise
Gan Ianuarie inwith his thoght deuyse
Of maydens which that dwelten hym biside
He wist nat where that he myght abide
For if that on haue beaute in hir face
An othir stant so in the peples grace
For hir sadnesse and hir benygnitee
That of the peple gretteste vois hadde she
But nathelees bitwix ernest and game
And some were riche and hadden badde name
He atte laste apoynted hym on oon
And lete al other from his herte goon
And chees hir of his owne auctoritee
For loue is blynd al day and may nat see
And whan that he was in his bed ybroght
He purtreid in his herte and in his thoght
Hir fresshe beaute and hire age tendre
Hir myddil smal hir armes longe and sclendre
Hir wise gouernaunce hir gentillesse
Hir wommanly beryng and hir sadnesse
And whan that he on hire was condescended
Hym thoght his chois myght nat ben amendid
For whanne that he hym selue concluded hadde
Hym thoght eche other mannes was badde
That impossible it were to replie
A gayn his chois this was his fantasie
His frendes sente he to at his instance
And preyde hem to doon hym that plesaunce
That hastily thei wolden to hym come
He wolde abregge hir labour al and some
Neded na mare to hem to goo ne ride
He was a poynted there he wolde abide
Placebo cam and ek his frendes sone
And alder first he bad hem alla aboone
That noon of hem non argumentes make
A gayn the purpos which that he hath y take
Which purpos was plesant to god seyde he
And verray grounde of his prosꝑperite
He seide ther was a mayde inthe toun
Which that of beaute had gret renoun
Al were it so she were of smal degree
Suffiseth hym hir youthe and hir beaute
Which mayde he seide he wold han to his wif
To lede in ese and holinesse his lif
And thanked god that he myght han hir al
That no wight his blisse parten shal
And preyde hem to labouren in this nede
And shapyn that he faile nat to spede
For thanne he seyde his spirit was at ese
Thanne is quod he nothyngmay me displese
Saue on thyng priketh in my conscience
The which y wol reherce in youre presence
I haue quod he herd seid fur yore ago
Ther may no man han ꝑperfit blisses too
This is to seyn in erthe and ek in heuene
For thogh he kepe hym fro the synnes seuene
And ek from euery braunche of thilke tree
Yit is there so ꝑperfit felicite
And so gret ese and lust in mariage
That euere y am agast now in myn age That I shal lede
That y shal lede now so merya lif
So delicat with outen wo or strif
That y shal han myn heuen in erthe here
For sitthe that verrey heuen is boght so dere
With tribulacoıı̄uns and gret penance
How sholde y thanne lyue in such plesance
As alle wedded men doon with hir wyues
Come to the blisse that crist eterne on lyue is
This is my drede and ye my brethern tweye
Assoileth me this questiou y preye
Iustinus which that hateth his folye
Answered a noon right in his iaperie
And for he wold his longe tale abregge
He wolde noon autoritee allegge
But seide sere so ther be noon obstakele
Oother than this god of his meracle
And of his mercy may so for you werche
That er ye haue youre rightes of holy cherche
Ye may repente of wedded mannes lif
In which ye seyn ther is no wo ne strif
And elles god forbede but he sente
A wedded man hym grace to repente
Wel ofte rather than a sengle man
And therfore sire the beste reed y can
Despeire you noght but haue in memorie
ꝐParauenture she may be youre purgatorie
She may by goddes mene and goddes whi
Thanne shal youre sowle vp to heuene sk
Swifter thanne doth an arowe of a bow
I hope to god hir aftir shul ye knowe
That ther nys noon so gret felicitee
In mariage ne neuer more shal be
That you shal lette of youre saluacou
So that ye vse as skyl is and resou
