And ful of instrumentes and of vitaille
The moste deyntewous of al ytaille
Be forn hem stood swich instrument of soun
That Orpheus ne of thebes Amphyou
Ne maden neuere swich a melodye
At euery cours in cam loud mynstralcye
That neuere trumpid Ioab half so clerre
Ne theodomas yit for to here
At Thebes whan the sytee wans in doute
Bacus the wyn hem shenkyth al a bowte
And venus lawith vp on euery wight
For Ianuarie was bycome hir knyght
And wolde both assayen his corage
In lybertee and ek in mariage
And with hir firbrand in hir hand a boute
Dauncith beforn the bryde and al the rowte
And certeynly y dar right wel sey this
Ymenyus that god of weddyng is
Say neuere his lif so mery a wedded man
Holde thou thi pees thou poete marcian
That writest vs that ilke weddyng merye
Of here philologie and he mercurie
And of thee the songes that the muses songe
To smal is bothe thi penne and ek thy tonge
For to descriuen of this mariage
Whan tendr youthe hath wedded stoupyng age
Ther is ne swiche myrthe that it may nat be wreten
Assayeth it your seluen than may ye weten
If that y lye or non in this matere
Mayus that sit with so benygne acher
Hir to beholde it semede me fayrie
Queen Ester lookyd neuer with swiche an eye
On assuer so meke alook hath she
Y may you nat deuyse l al hir beaute
But thus moche of hir beaute telle y may
That she was lik the brighte morwe of may
Fulfilled of al beaute and plesaunce
This Ianuarye is rauysshid in a traunce
At euery tyme he lokith on hir face
But in his herte he gan hir to manace
That he that myght in armes wolde hir stryne
Harder than euer Paris dede Eleyne
But nathelees yit hadde he gret pyte
That thik nyght offenden here most he
And thoghte alas o tendre creature
Now wol god ye myghten wel endure
Al my corage it is so sharp and kene
I am a gast y shul it not sustene
But god forbede that y dede al my myght
Now wold god that it were waxen nyght
And that the nyght wolde lasten euer mo
I wold that al this peple were agoo
And fynally he doth al his labour
As he best myghte sauyng his honour
To haste hem fro the mete in sotil wise
The tyme cam that reson was to rise
And aftir that men daunce and drynken faste
And spices al aboute the hous they caste
And ful of yoye and blisse is euery man
Sauynge a squyer highte damyan
Wiche carf beforn the knyght ful many aday
He was so rauysshit on his laydy may
That for the verray peyne he was ny wood
Almost he swelte and swouned as he stood
So sore hath venus hurt hym with here word brond
As that she bar it daunsyng in here hond
And to his bed he wente hym hastily
No more of hym as at this tyme speke I
But there y lete hym wepe ynow and pleyne
Til fressh may wil rewen on his peyne
O ꝑperillous fir that in the bedstrau bredith
O famuler fo that hye seruice bedith
O seruant traytour false homly hewe
Lik to the nedder in bosom sly ontrewe
God shelde vs al from youre aquyntaunce
O Ianuarie dronken in plesaunce
In mariage se how thy bore man
Thyn owene squyer callid damyan
Ententith for to do the vylenye
God graunte the thyn homly foo for tospie
For in this world nys werse pestilence
Than homly fo alday in thi psence
Parformed hath the sonne his arke dyurne
Ne lengere may the body of hym soiorne
On the orizonte as in that latitude
Night with his mantel that is derk and rude
Gan ouer sprede themisꝑperie a boute
For which departid is this lusti route
Fro Ianuarie with thank on euery syde
Hom to hir houses lustily they ryde
Where as they doon hir thynges as hem leste
And whan they saw hir tyme go to reste
Sone after that this hastif Ianuarie
Wol go to bedde he wol no lengere tarye
He drynkith ypocras clarre and vernage
Of spices hote tencrecen his corage
And many a letuarie hadde he ful fyne
Swich as the cursed munke dan Costantyn
Hath wreten in his book de coytu
To ete hem alle he was no thyng eschu
And to his pryue frendes thus seyde he
For goddis loue as sone as it may be
Let voiden al this hous in curteys wise
And they han doon right as he wol deuyse
Men dronken and the trauers drowen anon
The bride is broght abedde as stille as ston
And whan the bedde was with the prest y blessed
Out of the chaumbre hath euery wight hym dressed
And Ianuarie hath fast in armes take
His fressh may his peradis his make
He lullith here he kissith here ful ofte
With thilke bristeles of his berd vnsofte
Lik to the skyn of houndfissh sharp as brer
For he was shaue al newe in his manere
He rubbith here aboute hir tendre face
And seid thus allas y mot trespace
To you my spouse and you gretly offende
Or tyme come that y wol doun decende
But nathelees considerith this qd he
Ther nys no werkman what so eủere he be
That may bothe werkyn wel and hastily
This wol be doon at leyser parfitly
Hit is no force how longe that we pleye
In trewe wedlok couplid be we tweye
And blessed be the yok that we ben Inne
For in oure actes may there be no synne
A man may do no synne with his wif
Ne hurte hym seluen with his owne knyf
For we haue leue to pleye vs by the lawe
Thus labourth he til the day gan dawe
And than he takith a sop in fyn clarr
And vpright in his bed thanne sittith he
And aftir that he sang ful lowle and cleere
And kist his wif and made wanton cheere
He was al coltissh fullof ragerie
And ful of iergou as a flekked pie
The slakke skyn aboute his nekke shakith
Whil that he sang so chauntith he and crakith
But god wot what that may thoghte in hir herte
Whan she hym sey vp sittyng in his sherte
In his nyghte cappe and with his nekke lene
She preysith nat his pleyyng worth a bene
Than seyde he thus my reste wol y take
Now day is come y may no lengere wake
And doun he leyde his heed and sleep til pryme
And aftirward whan he saw his tyme
Vp riseth Ianuarie but fressh May
Heeld hir in chaumbre vn to the iiijthe day
As vsage is of wyues for the beste
For euery labour sumtyme muste han reste
Or elles longe may he nat endure
This is to seyn no lyues creature
Be it fissh or bird or beste or man
Now wol y speke of woful damyan
That langwisshit in loue as ye shul here
Therfore y speke to hym in this manere
I sey o sely Damyan allas
Answere to my demaunde as in this cas
How shalt tow to thy lady fressh may
Telle thi wo she wol alwey sey nay
Ek if thou speke she wol thy wo biwreye
God be thyn help y can no betere seye
This sike damyan in venus fir
So brennyth that he dyeth for desir
For whiche he put his lif in auentur
No lenger myght he in this wise endure
But pryuely a pennere gan he borwe
And in a lre wrot he al his sorwe
In maner of a compleynt or a lay
Vn to his faire fresshe lady May
And in a purs of sylk heeng on his sherte
He hath it put and leyde it at his herte
The moone that at noon was thilke day
That Ianuarie hath wedded fressh may
In to syn of taur was in to Cancer gleden
So longe hath Mayus in his chambre abiden
As custume ys vn to this nobles alle
Abryde shal nat eten in the halle
Til dayes . iiij . or . iij . dayes atte leste
Y passed ben than lat here go to feste
The . iiij . day compleet fro noon to noon
When that the hye messe was y doon
In halle sit this Ianuarie and may
As fressh as is the brighte someres day
And so be fil how that this goode man
Remembrid hym vpon this damyan
And seyd seynte marie how may this be
That damyan entendith nat to me
Is he ay sik or how this betide
His squyers whichas stoden ther be syde
Excusid hym be cause of his siknesse
Non other cause myght make hym tarie
That me forthynkith qd this Ianuarie
He is a gentil squyer by my trowthe
If that he deyde it were gret harm and rowthe
He is as wis discret and as secree
As ony man y wot of his degree
And ther to manly and ek seruysable
And for to byn athirfty man right able
But aftir mete as sone as euer y may
I wol my self visite hym and ek may
To don hym al the comfort that y can
And for that word hym blessed euery man
That of his bounte and his gentilnesse
He wolde hym so conforten in siknesse
His squyer for it was a gentil dede
Dame quod this Ianuarie take god hede
At aftir mete ye with youre wommen alle
Whan that ye been yn chamber out of this halle
That al ye goo to se damyan
Doth hym desport he is a gentil man
And tellith hym that y wol hym visite
Haue y nothyng but restyd me alyte
And spede you faste for y wol abide
Til that ye slepe faste be my syde
And with that word he gan vn to hym calle
A squyer that was Mareschal of his halle
And tolde hym serteyn thynges that he wold
This fressh may hath streight here weye y holde
With al hir wommen vn to Damyan
Doun bi his beddes side sit she thanne
Comfortyng hym as goodly as she may
This damyan whan he his tyme say
In secret wise his purs and ek his bille
In whiche that he y writen hadde his fille
Hath put in to hir hand with outen more
Saue that he sikit wonder depe and sore
And softely to hir right thus seide he
Mercy and that ye discouere not me
For y am deed if that this thyng be kyd
This purs hath she inwith here bosom hyd
And wente hir wey ye gete no more of me
But vn to Ianuarie y comen is she
That on his beddes syde sat ful softe
And taketh here and kissith here ful ofte
And leyde hym doun to slepe and that a non
She feyned here ther as she muste gon
Ther as ye wot that euery wight mot nede
And whan she of this bille hath taken hede
She rente it al to cloutes at the laste
And in the pryue softeliche hit cast
Who studieth now but faire fresshe may
A doun by olde Ianuarie she lay
That slepte til that þe cowhe had hym awakyd
A non preyde hire strepen hir al naked
He wolde of here haue sumplesaunce
He seyde hir clothes dede hym encoumbraunce
And she abeyeth hym be here lef or loth
But lest that precious folk be wroth
How that he wroghte y dar nat to you telle
Or wheyder hir thoghte hit ꝓproadis or helle
But there y lete hem werken in hir wise
Til euesong rang and that they muste aryse
Where it be destenye or auenture
Where it be by influence or nature
Or constellaciou that in sweche estat
The heuene stood at that tyme fortunat
As for to putte a bille of venus werkes
For al thyng hath tyme as sey clerkes
To eny womman for to gete hir loue
I kan nat seyn but gret god a boue
That knoweth that noon act is causelees
He deme of al for y wol holde my pees
But soth is this how that this fresshe may
Hath taken swich impressiou that day
For pite of this sike Damyan
That from hir herte she ne dryue can
The remenbraunce for to do hym ese
Serteyn thoghte she whom that this thyng displese
I rekke nat for here y hym assure
To loue hym best of ony creature
Thogh he nomor hadde than his bar sherte
Lo pite renneth sone in gentil herte
He may ye seen how excellent fraunchise
In wommen is whan they hem narwe auyse
Su tyraunt is as therbyen many on
That hath an herte as hard as any stoon
Which wolde han lete hym storuen in that place
Wel rather than han grauntid hym hir grace
And hem reioisen in hir crewel pryde
And rekken nat to been an homycide
This gentil may fulfild of pite
Right of hir hand a lre maketh she
In which she grauntith hym hir grace
Ther k lakketh nat but only day and space
Where that she myghte vn to his loust suffise
For it shal be right as he wol deuyse
And whan she saw hir tyme vp on a day
To visiten this damyan goth this faire may
And sotilli this lre doun she threste
Vndir his pilwe red it if hym leste
She takith hym by the hond and harde hym twiste
So secretly that no wight of it wiste
And bad hym ben al hool and forth she wente
To Ianuarie whan that he for here sente
Vp risith damyan the nexte morwe
Al passed was his siknesse and his sorwe
He kymbith hym he proyneth hym and pyketh
He doth al that his lady lust and liketh
And ek to Ianuarie he goth as lowe
As euery dede adogge for the bowe
He is so plesaunt vn to euery man
For craft is al ho so that don can
That euery wight is fayn to speke hym good
And fully in his ladyes grace he stood
Thus lete y Damyan aboute his nede
And my tale forth y wol procede
Sum clerkes holden that felicity
Stant in delit and therfore certeyn he
This nobele Ianuarie with al his myght
In honest wise as longith vn to a knyght
Shoop hym to leuen ful deliciously
His housyng his array as honestly
To his degree was makid as a kynges
Amonges othir of his honest thynges
He made agardyn wallid al with stoon
So fair a gardyn wot y nowher noon
For out of doute y verayly suppose
That he that made the romaunce of the rose
Ne coude of hit the beaute dyuyse
Ne pryapus ne myght nat suffice
Thogh he be god of gardyns for to telle
The beaute of the gardeyn and the welle
That stood vnder a laurer alway grene
Ful often tyme he pluto and his queene
Proserpina and al here fayerye
Desporten hem and makyn melodye
Aboute that welle and daunced as men tolde
This noble knyght this Ianuarie the olde
Sweche deynte hath in hit to walke and pleye
That he wol no wight suffre bere the keye
Sauf he hym self for of the smal wiket
He ber alwes of siluer a clyket
With the which whan that hym list he it vnshette
And whan he wold paye his wif his dette
In somer sesou thider wol he go
And may his wif an nowight but they two
And thynges whiche that were nat don abedde
He in the gardeyn ꝓproformed hem and spedde
And in this wise many amery day
Leued this Ianuarie and fresshe may
But worldly ioye may nat alwey dure
To Ianuarie ne to no creature
O sodeyn hap o thow fortune vnstable
Lik to the scorpiou so deceyuable
That flaterist with thyn heed whan thou wost stynge
Thi tail is deth thurgh thyn enuenymynge
O brotel ioye o swete venym queynte
O monstre that so sotilly canst peynte
Thi yiftes vnder hew of stedefastnesse
That thou deceyuest bothe more and lesse
Whi hastow Ianuarie thus deceyued
That haddest hym for thi ful frend receyued
And now thou hast biraft hym bothe his eyen
For sorwe of whiche desirest he to dyen
Alas thys nobele Ianuarie free
Amydde his lust and his prosꝑperite
Is waxen blynd and that al sodeynly
He wepith and he wayleth pytously
And ther with al the fir of Ielousye
Lest that his wif shulde falle in som folye
So brente his herte that he wolde fayn
That sum man hadde bothe hym and her y slayn
For nouther his deth ne in his lif
Ne wolde he that she were loue ne wif
But euer lyue as a widwe in clothes blake
Soul as the Turtel that hath lost hir make
But atte laste aftir amonthe or tweye
His sorwe gan asswage soth to seye
For whan he wiste it may non othir be
He paciently tok his aduersitee
Saue out of doute he ne may nat forgoon
That he nas gelous euermor in on
Whiche ielosie it was so outragious
That neyther in halle ne in non other hous
Ne in non othir place neuer the mo
He nolde suffre hir for to ride or goo
But if that he hadde hond on here alway
For which ful often wepid fressh may
That loueth Damyan so benyngly
That she muste outher dien sodeynly
Or elles she muste han hym as hir leste
She waytith whan hir herte wold breste
Vp on that othir syde Damyan
Bycome is the wofuleste man
That euere was for neyther nyght ne day
Ne myghte he speke a word to fressh may
As to his purpos of no swiche matere
But if that Ianuarie muste hit here
That hadde an hand vp on hir eueremo
But natheles by writyng to and fro
And pryue signys wist she what he mente
And she knew ek the fyn of his entente
O Ianuarie what myghte hit the auayle
Thou that myghtist se as fer as shippis sayle
For as good is al blynd deceyued be
As be deceyued whan a man may se
Lo Argus which that hadde an . C eyen
For al that euere he coude poure or pryen
Yit was he blent god wot and so ben mo
That wenen wisly that it be nat soo
Passe ouer is an esse y sey no more
This Fresshe may of the whiche y spak of yore
In warm wex hath enprented the cleket
That Ianuarie bar of that smale wyket
By whiche onto his gardyn ofte he wente
And damyan that knew al his entente
The clyket contrefetid pryuely
Ther nys no more to sey but hastyly
Sum wondir bi this cliket shal betyde
Which ye shul here if that ye wol abide
O noble ouyde soth seystow god wot
That sleythe is hy if loue be longe and hoot
That he nyl fynde it out in sum manere
By piramus and tisbe may men lere
Thogh they were kept ful longe and streit oủere al
They byen acordid rownynge thourgh a wal
There no wigh coude han founde out swich a sleyghte
But now to purpos or that dayes . viijᵉ .
Were passed of the monthe of Iul be fil
That Ianuarie hath caght so greet a wil
Thurgh eggynge of his wif hym for to pleye
In his gardyn and no wight but they tweye
That in a morwen vn to may seyde he
Rise vp my wif my loue my lady free
The turtiles vois is herd myn owne swete
The wyntir is goon with alle his reynes wete
Come forth now with thyn eyen Columbyn
Wel fairere be thi brestes that is ony wyn
The gardyn is enclosed a boute
Come forth my white spouse out of doute
Thou hast me woundid in my herte o wif
No spot in the nas neuere in al thi lif
Come forth and lat vs taken our disport
I chese the for my wif and my comfort
Swiche olde lewed wordes vsed he
On damyan a signe made she
That he shulde go biforn with his clyket
This damyan hath opened the wiket
And in he sterte and that in swich manere
That no wight myghte it se ne here
And stil he sit vndir abussh a noon
This Iānuarie as blynd as is a ston
With mayus in his hond and no wight mo
In to this fressh gardeyn is goo
And clapte to the wiket sodeynly
Now wif qd he hir nys but thou and y
That art the creature that y best loue
For by that lord Ihu that sit aboue
Y hadde leuere dyen on a knyf
Thanne the offenden dere trewe wif
For goddes sake thynke how y the ches
Nat for no couytise douteles
But only for the loue y hadde to the
And thou that y be old and may nat see
Beth to me trewe and y wol tel you whi
Certes iijᵉ thynges shul ye wynne ther bi
First loue of crist and to youre self honour
And al myn heritage toun and tour
I yeue you makith chartres as you leste
This shal be doon to morwe or sonne reste
So wisly god my sowle brynge to blysse
And preye you on this couenant ye me kisse
And thogh that y be Ielus wyte me noght
Ye ben so depe enpreyntid in my thoght
That whan that y considere your beaute
And ther with al thunlikly elde of me
I may nat certes thogh y shulde dye
Forbere to ben out of youre compaignye
For verray loue this is with outen dowte
Now kisse me wif and lat vs rome aboute
This fressh may whan she this wordes herde
Benygnely to Ianuarie answede
But first and forward she be gan to wepe
I haue quod she ꝓprode a sowle for to kepe
As wel as ye and also myn honour And of my wifhod
And of my wifhod thilke tendre flour
Which that y haue assured in youre hond
Whan that the prest to you my body bond
Where fore y wol answere in this manere
With leue of you myn owne lord so dere
Y pray god dawe neuere thilke day
That y ne sterue as foule as womman may
Yf euere y do my kyn that shame
Or elles y empeyre so myn name
That y be fals and if y do that lak
Do stripe me and pute me in a sak
And in the next reuer do me drenche
I am a gentel womman and no wenche
Whi speke ye thus but men ben euere ontrewe
And wommen han of you reprif ay newe
Ye conne non othir contenaunce y leue
But speke to vs of vtrist in repreue
And with that word she say where damyan
Sat in the busshe and cowhen she be gan
And with here fynger signes made she
That damyan shulde clymbyn in a tree
That chargid was with fruyt and vp he went
For verraily he knew al hir entente
And euery sygne that she cowde make
For in a lre she hadde told hym al
Of this matere how that he werken shal
And thus y lete hym syttynge in the pirie
And Ianuarie and may romynge ful merie
Bright was that day and blew the firmament
Phebus of gold doun hath his stremes sent
To glaydyn euery flour with his warmnesse
He was that tyme in geminys y gesse
But litil fro his declynaciou
Of Cancer Ioues exaltaciou
And so be fil that brighte morwe tyde
That in the gardyn on the ferthere syde
Pluto that is the kyng of fayrye
And many alady in his compaignye
Folwyng his wif the quene proserpina
Which that he rauysshed out of Ethna
Whil that she gaderid floures in a mede
In Claudyan ye may the storye rede
How that here in his grysly carte he sette
This kyng of fayrie adoun hym sette
Vp on a bench of turues fressh and grene
And right a non seyde he thus to his quene
Mi wif quod he ther may no wight sey nay
The exꝑperience preueth hit euery day
The tresou which that womman doth to man
Ten C Mˢ stories telle y can
Notabele of youre vntrowthe and brotilnesse
O Salamon richest of al richesse
Fulfild of Sapience and wordly glorie
Fulworthi ben thi wordes to han in memorie
To euery wight that wit and reson can
Thus preyset he the bounte yit of man
Among a Mˢ men yt fonde y on
But of al wommen fond y neuere non
Thus seith this kyng that knew youre wikkednesse
And Ihus filius Sirak as y gesse
Ne spekith of you but selden reuerence
A wilde fir a corupt pestilence
So falle vp on youre bodyes yit to nyght
Ne seye nat this honurable knyght
By cause allas he is blynd and old
His oune man shal make hym Cokewold
Lo where he sit the leccheour in the tree
Now wol y grauntyn of my magestee
Vn to this olde blynde worthi knyght
That he shal haue ageyn his eyen sight
Whan that his wif wol don hym vilenye
Than shal he knowe al hir harlatrie
Bothe in repref of here and othir mo
Ye shal quod proserpina and wol ye so
Now be my modres ceres soule y swere
That y shal yeue here sufficiaunt answere
And alle women aftir for hir sake
That thogh they ben in ony gilt y take
With face bold they shul hem selue excuse
And bere hem doun that wolden hem acuse
For lak of answere non of vs shal dyen

rdg.seg: Al hadde ye seen al thyng wᵗith bothe your yen

div.l: Yit shul we so visage hit hardily
And wepe and swere and chiden subtilly
That ye shul ben as w lewed s as ben gees
What rekkith me of youre youre autoritees
I wot wel that this Iew this salomon
Fand of vs women fooles many on
But thogh that he ne fond no good womman
Ther hath y funden many an other man
Wommen ful goode and trewe and vertuous
Witnesse on hem that dwelte in Cristes hous
With Martirdom they preued her Constance
The Romayn gestes maken remembrance
Of many a verray trewe wif al soo
But sere ne be nat wroth al be it soo
Thogh that he seyde he fond no good womman
I preye you take the sentence of the man
He mente thus that in souereyne bounte
Nis non but god no nouthir he ne she
Ey for the verray god that nys but on
What make ye so moche of Salamon
What thoght he made a temple goddes hous
What thogh he were riche and glorious
So made he ek a temple of false goddes
Who myghte doon a thyng that more forbode is
Parde as faire as ye his name emplastre
He was a lecchour and a ydolastre
And in his elde he verray god forsook

rdg.seg: And if that god ne hadd as seith the book

div.l: Sparid hym for his faderis sake he sholde
Han lost his regne sounere than he wolde
I set not of al the vilenye
That he of womme writ a botirflie
I am a womman nedes muste y speke
Or swelle vn to that tyme myn herl herte breke
For syn he seyde we be Iangleresses
As euere mote y wel browke my tresses
I shal nat spare for no curtesie
To speke hym harm that seith vs vilenye
Dame quod this pluto be no lengere wroth
I yeue it vp but syn y swor an oth
That y wolde grauntyn hym his sight agayn
Mi word shal stande that warne y the serteyn
I am a kyng it sit me not to lye
And y quod she am quene of fairie
Here answershal she han y vndirtake
Let vs no more wordes of it make
For sothe quod he y wol you nat contrarie
Now let vs turne a gayn to Ianuarie
That in the gardyn with his faire may
Syngeth wel myriere thanne the popyngay
You loue y best and shal and othir non
So longe a boute the aleys is he goon
Til he was come ageyns thilke pirie
Wher as this damyan sittith ful myrie
An hi a mong the fressh leues grene
This fressh may that is so bright and shene
Gan for to sike and seide allas my syde
Now sere quod she for oght that may be tyde
Y moste han of the peres that y see
Or I mot dye so sore longith me
To eten of the smale peres grene
Help for hir loue that is of heuene quene
I telle you wel a womman in my plit
May haue to frut so gret an appetit
That she may dyen but she of hit haue
Allas quod he that y nadde heer a knaue
That coude clymbe allas allas quod he
For y am blynd ye sere no fors quod she
But wolde ye vouche sauf for goddes sake
The pirie in with your armes for to take
For wel y wot that ye mystrusten me
Than shulde y clymbe wel y now quod she
So y my foot myghte setten on your bak
Certes quod he ther in shal be no lak
Mighte y you helpen with myn herte blood
He stoupid doun and on his bak she stood
And caghte here by a twiste and vp she gooth
Ladyes y prey you that ye be nat wrooth
I can not glose y am a rude man
And sodeynly a non this damyan
Gan pullen vp the smok and in he throng
And whan pluto sy this grete wrong
To Ianuarye he yaf a gayn his sighte
And made hym seen as wel as euere he myghte
And whan he thus had caght his sighte agayn
Ne was neuere man of thyng so fayn
But on his wif his thoght was euere mo
Vp to the tree he caste his eyen two
And sag saugh that damyan his wif had dressed
In sweche maner it may nat ben expressed
But if y wolde speke vncurteysly
And vp he yaf a roryng and acry
As doth the moder whan the child shal dye
Out help allas harrow he gan to crye
O strong lady store what doostow
And she answerde sere what eyleth you
Haue pacience and reson in your mynde
I haue you holpen on bothe youre eyen blynde
Vp peril of my soule y shal nat lyen
As me was taght to hele with youre eyen
Was no thyng bet to make you to see
Than strogelyng with a man vp on a tre
God wot y dede it in ful good entent
Strogelid quod he ye algate in yt wente
God yeue you bothe on shames deth to dyen
He dighte the y saw it with myn eyen
And elles be y hangid by the hals
Than is quod she my medycyne al fals
For certeynly if that ye myghte see
Y wold nat sey thise wordes vn to me
Ye haue sum grymsynge and no ꝑperfit sight
I see quod he as wel as euere y myghte
Thankid be god with bothe myn eyen two
And by my feith me thoghte he dede the soo
Ye maze maze good sere quod she
This thank haue y for y haue mad you see
Allas quod she that euere y was so kynde
Now dame quod he lat al passe out of mynde
Come doun my leef and if y haue myssayd
God help me so as y am euel payed
But by my fadres sowle y wende haue sayn
How þ this Damyan hadde by the layn
And that thi smok hadde leyn vp on his brest
Ye sere quod she ye may wene as you lest
But ʆsir a man that wakith of his sleep
He may nat sodeynly wel taky keep
Vp on a thyng ne sen hit parfitly
Til that he be adawed verraily
Right so a man that hath longe blynd be
Ne may nat sodeynly so wel y see
First whan his sighte is newe come agayn
As he that hath aday or to y seyn
Til that youre sighte satlid be a while
Ther may ful many a sighte you be gile
Beth war y preye you for be heuene kyng
Ful many a man weneth to seen a thyng
And it is al anothir thanne it semeth
He which mys conceyueth mysdemeth
And with that word she lep doun fro the tree
This Ianuarie who was glad but he
He kissith here and clippith here ful ofte
And on hir wombe he stroket here ful softe
And to his pallays hom he hath here lad
Now good men y preye you to be glad
Thus endith here my tale of Ianuarie
God blesse vs and his modir seynte marye amen
by goddes mercy seide oure ost tho
Now swich a wif y preye god kepe me fro
Lo swiche sleighthes and subtilites
In wommen ben for ay as besy as bees
Ben they vs sely men for to deseyue
And from a sothe euere wil they weyue
Bi this marchauntis tale hit preueth wel

Ther dowblenesse of feynyng shulde approche
Ne cowthe so thankyn a knyght as he dede me
His maner was an heuene for to se
To any womman were she neuere so wis
So peynteth he and kembede point deuys
As wel his wordes as continance
And y so louyd hym for his obeisaunce
And for the trowthe y demed in his herte
That if so were that eny thyng hym smerte
And were it neuere so litel and y hit wiste
Me though y felte deth at myn herte twiste
And shortly so ferforth this thyng is went
That my wille was his wille instrument
This is to say my wille obeied his wille
In alle thyng asfer as resoıı̄un fell
Kepyng the bondes of my worshep euere
Ne neuere hadde y thyng so lef ne leuere
As hym god wat ne neuere shal non so
This laste lengere thanne ayer or two
That y supposid of hym nought but good
But fynally at the laste thus hit stood
That fortune wolde that Vs muste twynne
Out of that place whiche y was Inne
Wher me was wo it is no questioun
I can nought make of hit discripcioun
For o thyng dar y telle boldly
I knowe what is the peyne of deth ther by
Whiche harm y felte for he ne myght be leue
So on a day of me he toke his leue
So sorweful eke that y wente verreyly
That he hadde feled as meche as y
Whenne that y herde hym speke and saw his hewe
But nathelees y thought he was so trewe
And ek that he shulde repeire agayn
With Inne a litell while soth to sayn
And reson wolde eke that he muste go
For his honour as happed so
That y made vertu of necessite
And tok hit wel sethyns hit muste be
As y best myght y hidde fro hym my sorwe
And tok hym by the hand Seint Iohn to borwe
And saide thus lo y am youre al
Beth swich as y haue be to yow and shal
What he answerde hit nedeth nought to reherce
Who can say bet then he who can do werce
When he hath al wel saide thanne hath he done
Therfore be houyth hire a fullong spone
That shal ete with a feend thus herd y seye
So at the laste he muste forth his wey
And forth he flith til he came ther hym leste
When it cam hym to purpoos for to reste
I trowe he hadde thilke tixte in mynde
That alle thyng repeiryng to his kynde
Gladeth hym selue thus seyn men as y gisse
Men louen of ꝓpropre kynde newe fangellnesse
As briddes doon that men in cage fede
For thou nyght and day take of hem hede
And strewe her cage faire and softe as selk
And yeue hem sugur hony bred and mylk
Ye right anon as his dore is vppe
He with his feet wil spurne doun his couppe
And to the wode he wol and wormes ete
So newe faggil they ben of here mete
And louen noueltes of propre kynde
No gentillesse of blood may hem bynde
So ferde this gentil Tercelt allas the day
They he were gentil born and fressh and gay
And goodlich for to seon and humble and fre
He saw vp on atyme a kyte fle
And sodeynly he loueth this kite so
That al his loue is clene fro me go
And hath his trowthe falsid in this wise
Thus hath the kyte my loue in hir seruise
And y am lorn with outen remedye
And with that word the fawcon̄ gan to crye
And sowneth este in canacees barme
Gret was the sorwe for that haukes harme
That Canace and alle here wommen made
They nyste how they myght the fawcon̄ glade
But Canace bereth here hom in here lappe
And softly in plastrees gan here wrappe
Ther as she with here bek hadde hert here selue
Now can not Canace but erbes delu

div.l: (base) Out of the grownd and maken saues newe
(base) Of herbes preciouse and fyn of hewe
(base) To heelen with this hauk fro day to nyght
(base) She dooth hir bisynesse and al hir myght
(base) And by hir beddes heed she made a Muwe
(base) And couered it with veluettes blue
(base) In signe of trouthe that is in wommen sene
(base) And al withoute the Muwe is peynted grene
(base) In which were peynted alle thise false fowles
(base) As been thise tydyues terceletz and Owles
(base) Right for despit were peynted hem bisyde
(base) And Pyes on hem for to crye and chyde
(base) Thus lete I Canacee hir hauk kepyng
(base) I wol namoore as now speke of hir ryng
(base) Til it come eft to purpos for to seyn
(base) How that this Faukon gat hir loue ageyn
(base) Repentant as the storie telleth vs
(base) By mediacion of Cambalus

(base) To speke of auentures and of batailles
(base) That neuere yet was herd so greet meruailles
(base) First wol I telle yow of Cambyuskan
(base) That in his tyme many a Citee wan

(base) How that he wan Theodora to his wyf
(base) For whom ful ofte in gret peril he was
(base) Ne hadde he been holpen by the Steede of bras

(base) That faught in lystes with the bretheren two

div.l: In feith Squier thou hast the wel I quyt
And gentilli y preyse thi wit
Quod the frankeleyn consideryng thi thoughte
So felyngly thou spekest sere y alowe the
As to my doom ther is non that is heere
Of eloquence that shal be thi peere
Yf that thou leue god yeue the good chaunce
And in vertu sende the contynaunce
For of thi speche haue y gret deyntee
I haue a sone and by the Trinitee
Hit were me leuere than xxᵗⁱ pound worth land
Thogh hit right now were fallyn in his hand
He were a man of swich discrescyou
Os that ye ben fy on possessiou
But yf a man be vertuous with al
I haue my sone snybbyd and yit shal
For he to vertu lystith nat entende
But for to pleye atat dees and to dispende
And leesen al that he hath in his vsage
And he hath leuere talkyn with a page
Thanne to comune with ony gentil wight
Ther he myght lerne gentellesse aright
Straw for youre gentillesse quod oure ost
What frankeleyn parde sire wel thou wost
That eche of vs mot tellen atte leste
A tale or two or breken his biheste
That knowe y wel sere quod the frankeleyn
I preye you haue me nat in desdeyn
Thogh y vn to hym speke a word or two
Telle on thi tale quod oure ost tho
Gladly sir ost quod he y wille obeye
Vn to youre wil now herkeneth what y sey
I wol nat you contrarien in no wise
As fer as that my wittes wel suffice
I pray to god that it may plesen you
Than wot y wel that it is good ynow
The Franklynes tale

div.l: This olde gentil Bretone in hir dayes
Of diuerse auentures maden layes
Rymeyed in hir firste Bryton tonge
With layes with instrumentes they songe
Or elles redden hem for her plesaunce
And on of hem haue y in remembraunce
Which y shal sayn with good will as y can
But sires bi cause y am a borell man
At my begynnyng first y you biseche
Haue me excused of my rude speche
I lerned neuere Retoryk certeyn
Thyng that y speke hit mot be bare and pleyn
I sleep neuere on the mont of pernaso
Ne lerned Marcus Tullius Scithero
Colours ne knowe y non with outen drede
But swich colours as growen in the mede
Or elles swiche as men dye or peynte
Colours of retorik ben to queynte
Mi spirit feleth nat of swiche matere
But yf yow lust my tale shul ye here
In armoryk that called was Breteigne
Ther was a knyght that louede and dede his peyne
To serue a lady in his best wyse
And many a labour many agret empryse
He for his lady wroght or she were wonne
For she was on the faireste vndir sonne
And ek ther to comyn of so hy kynreede
That wel vnnethes durste this knyght for drede
Telle here his wo his peyne and his distresse
But at laste she for his worthyness
And namely for his meke obeisaunce
Hath swich a pitee caght of his penaunce
That pryuely she fil of his acord
To take hym for hir husbonde and her lord
Of swiche lordshepe as men han oủere hir wyues
And for to lede the more in blisse hir lyues
Of his fre wille he swoor hir as a knyght
That neuere in al his lif he day ne nyght
Ne shulde vp on hym take no maistree
Ageyus hir will ne kythe hire h Ielousie
But her obeye and folue hir wille in al
As ony louere to his lady shal
Saue that the name of souereynte
That wold he han for shame of his degree
She thanked hym and with ful gret humblesse
She seyde sere syn of your͗e gentillesse
Ye profern me to haue so large a reyne
Ne wolde neuere god betwyxe vs tweyne
As in my gilt were othir werre or strif
Sire y wol be your͗e humble trewe wif
Haue here my trowthe til that myn herst herte breste
Thus ben they bothe in quyete and in rest
For o thyng sires saufly dar y seye
That frendes eủerych othir muste obeye
If they willonge holden compaignie
Loue wil nat be constreyned be maistrie
Whan maistrie comyth the god of loue anon
Betith his wengis and farwel he is gon
Loue is a thyng as ony spirit free
Wommen of kynde desiren liberte
And nat to be constreined as a thral
And so do men if sothly y seyn shal
Look who that most is pacient in loue
He is at his auantage al abou
Pacience is an hy Vertu serteyn
For it venquysshith as this clerkes seyn
Thynges that rigour shulde neuere atteyne
For eueri word men may nat chide or pleyne
Lerneth to soferen or so mote y goon
Ye shul it lerne wheyther ye wil or noon
For in this world certeyn no wight is
That he ne doth or seith sum tyme a mys
Ire seeknesse or constellacioıı̄un
Wyn wo or chaungynge of complexcioıı̄un
Causith ful ofte to doon amys or speekyn
Of eueri wrong a man may nat be wreken
After the tyme most he be temꝑperance
To euery wight that can on gouernaunce
And ther fore hath this wise worthi knyght
To leue in ese soffrance here be hight
And she to hym ful wisly gan to swere
That neuere shuld ther be defaute in here
Heer may men seen an humble wis accord
Thus hath she take hir seruant and hir lord
Seruant in loue and lord in mariage
Thanne was he bothe in lordshepe and seruage
Seruage nay but in lordshepe a boue
Syn he hath bothe his lady and his loue
His lady certes and his wif also
The which that lawe of loue acordeth to
And whan he was in this prosꝑperitee
Hoom with his wif he goth to his contre
Nat fer fro pedmark there his dwellyng was
Where as he leuyd in blisse and in solas
Who coude telle but he hadde wedded be
The ioye the ese and the prosꝑperitee
That is be twyxe an husbande and his wif
A yer and more lastith this blisful li
Thil that the knygh of wiche I spak of thus
That of Cairud was clept Arueragus
Shoop hym to gon and dwelle ayer or tweye
In Engelond that clepid was Briteigne
To seke in armys worsship and honour
For he al his lust sette in swich labour
And dwelte there two yeer the book seith thus
Now wil y stynte of this arueragus
And speke y wol of Dorygene his wif
That loueth hir husbonde as hir hertes lif
For his absence wepith she and syketh
As doon this I nobele wyues whan hem likith
She morneth wakith waylith fastith pleynyth
Desir of his presence hir so distreynyth
That al this wilde world she sette at noght
Here frendes which that knew hir heuy thoght
Conforten here in al that euere they may
They prechen here they telle hir nyght and day
That causeles she sleth hir silf alas
And eueri comfort possible in this caas
They doon to here with al hir bisynesse
Al for to make here leue hir heuinesse
By proces as ye knowen euerichon̄
Men may so longe grauen in a stoon
Til sum figure ther Inne emprentid be
So longe han they comfortid here tl til she
Receyued hath by hoope and by resoıı̄un
Themprentyng of hir consolacioıı̄un
Thurgh which hir gret sorwe gan as swage
She may nat alwey duren in swich rage
And ek Arueragus in al this care
Hath sent here łletres hom of his welfare
And that he wold come hastyly a gayn̄
And elles hadde this sorwe hir herte slayn
HEr frendes saw hir sorwe gan to slake
And preyed here on knees for goddis sake
To come and romen hir in compaygnie
A wey to dryue hir dirke fantasie
And fynally she grauntyd that request
For wel she saw that it was for the beste
Now stood hir castel fast by the see
And often with hir frendes walkith shee
Hir to disporten on the banke an hy
Where as she many a ship and barge sy
Saylynge hir cours wher as hem list to go
But it was that a parcelle of hir wo
For to hir self ful ofte allas seith she
Ys ther no ship of so manie as y se
Wol bryngyn hom my lord than were myn hert
Al warisshid of his bittre peynes smerte
An othir tyme ther wold she sitte and thynke
And cast hir eyen downward fro the brynke
But whan she say the grisly Rokkes blake
For Verray feere she wolde hir herte quake
That on hir feet she myght hir nat susteyne
Thanne wold she sitte adown vp on the greene
And pitously vn to the see be holde
And sey right thus with careful sykes colde
Eterne god that thurgh thi puruyaunce
Ledest the world by certeyn gouernance
In idel as men sayn ye nothyng make
But lord this grisly feendly Rokkes blake
That seme Rathir a foul confusioıı̄un
Of werk than ony fair creacioıı̄un
Of swich a parfit wis god and a stabule
Whi han ye wroght this werke vnresonable
For by this werk south north ne west ne Est
Ther nys y fostred man ne bird ne bes
Hit doth no good to my wit but anoyeth
Se ye nat lord how mankynde hit destroyeth
An ·C·ᵐᵗ bodies of mankynde
Han Rokkes slayn though they ben nat in mynde
Which mankynde is so fair part of thi werk
That thou madist it lik to thyn oune merk
Thanne semeth hit ye hadde a gret cherte
Toward mankynde but how thanne may hit be
That ye swiche menes makyn hit to destroyen
Whech menes doon no good but euere noyen
I wot wel clerkes wil seyn as hem leste
By argumentz that al is for the beste
Though ythe cause nat ne konne knowe
But thilke god that made wynd to blowe
As kepe my lord this is my conclusioıı̄un
To clerkes lete y al disputisoıı̄un
But wold god that al this Rokkes blake
Were sonken in to helle for his sake
This rokkes slen myn herte for the fer͗e
Thus wolde she sayn with many a pitous tere
Here frendes saw that it was no desport
To romyn by the see but discomfort
And shop hem for to pleyen sum wher elles
They leden here by reuers and by welles
And ek in other places delitables
They dauncen and thei pleye at ches and tables
So on a day right in the morwe tyde
Vnto a gardyn that was ther be syde
In which that they hadde maad hir ordinance
Of vitaile and of othir puruiaunce
Thei gon and pleye hem al the longe day
And this was on the VIᵗᵉ morwe of may
Which may hadde peyntyd with his softe shoures
This gardyn ful of leues and of floure
And craft of mannes hond so curiously
Arrayed had this gardyn trewely
That neuere was ther gardyn of swiche pris
But if it were verray paradys
The odour of floures and the fresshe sighte
Wold han y makyd ony herte lighte
That euere was born̄ but if to greet syknesse
Or to gret sorwe heeld hit in distresse
So ful hit was of beaute and plesance
And aftir dyner gonne they to daunce
And synge also sauf dorigen allone
Which made alwey hir compleynt and hir mone
For she ne saw hym on the daunce go
That was hir husbond and hir loue also
But nathelees she muste a tyme abyde
And with good hope lat hir sorwe slyde
Vp on this daunce amonges othir men
Daunced a squyer before dorygen
That fresshere was and ioliere of aray
As to my doom than is the moneth of may
He syngith dauncith passyng ony man
That is or was syn that the world began
Ther with he was yf men shulde hym descryue
On of the best faryng men alyue
Yong strong and Vertuos riche and wis
And wel beloued and holden in greet pris
And shortly if the sothe y tellen shal
Vnwitynge of this dorygene at al
This lusty Squyer seruant to venus
Which that y clepid was Aurelius
Hadde loued hir best of any creature
Two yeer and more as was his auenture
But neuere durste he telle hir his grenance
With outen cuppe he drank al his penanc
He was dispered nothyng durste he seye
Sauf in his songes sumwhat wolde he wreye
His wo as in a general compleynyng
He seyde he louede and was be loued no thyng
Of swiche materes made he many layes
Songes compleyntz rondelx virelayes
How that he durste nat his sorwe telle
But lang wisshe as a furie doth in helle
And dye he muste he seyde as dede Ecco
For narcisus that durst nat telle hir wo
In othir manere than ye here me seye
Ne durste he nat to here his wo be wreye
Sauf that ꝑparauenture sum tyme at daunces
There yonge folk kepen hir obseruances
Hit may wel be he lokith in hir face
In swich a wise as man that axith grace
But no thyng wist she of his entente
Nathelees hit happid or they thennes went
By cause that he was hir Neyghbour
And was a man of worship and honour
And hadde y knowen hym of tyme yore
They fil in speche and forth ay more and more
Vn to his purpos drow Aurelyus
And whan he say his tyme he seyde thus
Madame quod he be god that this world made
So that y wiste hit myghte youre herte glade
I wold that day that youre Arueragus
Wente oủere see that y Aurelyus
Hadde went ther neuere y sholde hau comyn agayn
For wel y wot my seruyce is in Veyn
My guerdon̄ is but brestyng of myn herte
Madame rewith on my peynes smerte
For with a word ye may me slen or saue
Heer at youre feet god wolde that y were grau
I haue as now no leiser more to seye
Haue mercy swete or ye wol do me dye
She gan to loke vp on Aurelyus
Ys ths youre wille quod she and seyde ye thus
Neuere erst quod she ne wist y what ye mente
But now Aurelye y knowe youre entente
By thilke god that yaf me soule and lif
Ne shal y neuere ben vntrewe wif
In word ne werk as fer as y haue wit
I wole ben his to whom that y am knyt
Take this for final answer as of me
But aftir that in pley thus seide she
Aurelie quod she by hye god a boue
Yit wil y graunte you to be youre loue
Syn y yow se so pitously compleyne
Loke what day that endelong Briteigne
Ye remue alle the rokkes ston bi ston
That they ne lette ship ne boot to goon
I sey whan ye han maad the coost so cleene
Of Rokkis that ther nys no stoon ysene
Thanne wol y loue you best of any man
Haue here my trowthe in al that euere y can
For wel y wot that shal neuere be tyde
Lat swich folye out of youre herte glide
What deynte shulde a man haue in his lif
For to go loue an other mannes wif
That hath hir body whan that euery hym likith
Aurelius ful ofte sore syketh
Is ther non other grace in you quod he
No by that lord quod she that mademe
Wo was Aurelye whan that he this herde
And with a sorwful herte he thus answerde
Madame quod he this were an Inpossible
Thanne mot y dye of sodeyn deth oribl
And with that word he turned hym anon̄
Tho come hir other freendes many on̄
And in the Aleyes romed vp and doun̄
And nothyng wiste of this conclusioıı̄un
But sodeynly begonne reuel newe
Til the bright sonne lost his hewe
For thoryzonte hath reft the sonne hight his light
This is as meche to seyn as it was nyght
And hom they goon in merthe and in solas
Sauf only wrecche Aurelius allas
He to his hous is gon with sorwful herte
He seth he may nat fro his deth a sterte
He semyth that he felte his herte colde
Vp to the heuene his handes he gan holde
And on his knees bare he sette hym doun
And in his rauyng seyde his orison
For warray wo out of his wit he breyde
He nyste what he spak but thus he seyde
With pitous herte his pleynt hath he begonne
Vn to the gooddes and first to the sonne
HE seide Apollo god and gouernour
Of euery plante herbe or tre or flour
That yeuest aftir thi declynacioıı̄un
To eche of hem his tyme and his sesoıı̄un
As that thyn herbergh chaungith low and hye
Lord phebus caste thi mercyable eye
On wrecche Aurelye which that am but lorn̄
Lo lord my lady hath my deth y sworn̄
Withouten gilt but thi benygnitee
Vp on̄ my deedly herte haue sum pytee
But wel y wot lord phebus if thou leste
Ye may me helpen sauf my lady beste
Now vouchith sauf that y may yow deuyse
How that y may ben holpe and in what wis
Youre blesful suster lucyna the shene
That of the see is chif gooddesse and quene
Thogh Neptunus haue deitee in the see
Yit Emperice Abouen hym is she
Ye knowe wel lord that right as hir desir
Is to be quykyd and lightid of youre fir
For which she folwith you ful bisily
Right so the see desirith naturelly
To folwen here as she that is goddesse
Bothe in the see and ryuers more and lesse
Wherfor lord Phebus this is my requeste
Do this myracle or do myn herte breste
That now next at this opposicioıı̄un
Which in the s signe shal be of the leoıı̄un
As preyeth hir so gret aflod to brynge
That fyue fadome atte leste it ouer sprynge
The hyeste Rokke in Armorik breteigne
And lat this fool flood enduren yere tweyne
Thanne certes to my lady may y seye
Haldith youre heste the rokkes ben awaye
Lord Phebus doth this myracle for me
Preye here she go no fastere cours than ye
I seye this youre preyeth youre suster that she go
No faster cours than ye this yeres two
Than shal she ben euene at fulle alwey
And sprynge flood lasten bothe day and nyght
And but she vouch saf in swich manere
To graunte me my souereyn lady dere
Preye hir to synkyn euery rokke a d doun̄
In to hir oune dirk regyoun̄
Vndir the ground ther pluto dwellith Inne
Or neueremo shal y my lady wynne
Thi temple in delphos wole y barfoot seek
Lord phebus se the teres on my cheke
And of my peyne haue sum compassioıı̄un
And with that word a swoun he fil a doun
And long tyme he lay forth in atraunce
His brother which that knew of his penance
Vp caghte hym and to bedde he hath hym broght
Dispeirid in this turment and this thoght
Lat y this woful creature lye
Chese he for me where he wol leue or dye
Arueragus with hele and greet honour
As he that was of Chyualrie the flour
Is comen hoom and othir worthi men
O blisful art thow now thou Dorygen
That hast thi luste husbonde in thyn armes
The fressh knyght the worthi man of armes
That loueth the as his oune hertes lif
Nothyng luste hym to be ymagynatif
If ony wight hadde spook whil he was oute
To hir of loue he hadde of that no do dowte
He nat entendith to no swiche mater͗e
But dancith iustith and makith myry chere
And thus in ioye and blisse y lat hem dwelle
And of the sike Aurelius wol y telle
In langur and in turment furious
Two yeer and more lay wrech Aurelius
Or any foot he myghte on erthe goon
Ne confort in this tyme ne hadde he noon
Sauf of his brother whiche that was a clerk
He knew of al this wo and al this werk
For to non othir creature certeyn
Of this matere he durste no word seyn
Vndir his breest he bar it more secree

And of hir owene vertu vnconstreyned
She hath ful often tyme sik hir feyned
For that she wold flee the compaignye
Ther likly was to treten of folye
As is at feestes reuele and at daunces
That ben occasions of daliaunces
Swich thynges makyn children for to be
To soone ripe and bolde as men may se
Which is ful perilous and hath ben yore
For al to soone may they lerne lore
Of boldnesse whanne that she is a wi
And ye maistresses in youre old lif
That lordes doghtres han in gouernance
Ne takith of my word no displesance
Thynkith that ye be seet in gouernynges
Of lordes doghtres oonly for two thynges
Outher for ye han kept youre honeste
Or elles ye han fallyn in freeltee
And knowe wel y now the olde daunce
And han for saken fully swich meschance
A thef of venysoıı̄un that hath for laft
His likerousnesse and al his olde craft
Can kepe a forest best of ony man
Now kepith wel for if ye wolle ye can
Looke wel that ye vn to no vice assente
Lest ye be dampnyd for youre wikke entente
For ho so doth a tretour is certeyn
And takith keep of that that y shal you seyn
Of alle tresons souereyne pestilence
Is whan a man betraisith innocence
Ye fadris and ye modres ek also
Thogh ye han children be hit on ormo
Youre is the charge of al hir suruyance
Whil that they ben vndir your gouernance
Beth war that by ensaumple of youre leuynge
Or by youre necligence in chastysynge
That they perice for y dar wel seye
If that ye doon ye shul it deere abeye
Vndir a shipperde soft and negligent
The wolf hath many a shep and lamb to rent
Suffisith thes ensamples now as heere
For y mot turne a geyn to my matere
This maide of which y wol my tale expresse
So kepte here that hir nedid no maistress
For in hir lyuyng maydnes myghten rede
As in a book euery good word and dede
That longith in to a mayden vertuous
She was so prudent and so bonteous
For whiche the fame out sprong on euery side
Bothe of hir beautee and hir bonte wide
That thurgh that lond they preysid hir echone
That loueden vertu sauf enuye allone
That sory is of othir mannes wele
And glad is of his sorwe and his Vnhele
The doctour makith this discripcioıı̄un
This maiden on a day wente in the toun
Toward a temple with hir modir deer͗e
As is of yonge maydenes the manere
NOw was ther thanne a Iustice in the toun
That gouernour was of that Regioıı̄un
And so be fil this Iuge his eyen caste
Vp on this maide auysyng hym ful faste
As she cam forby there this Iuge stood
Anon his herte chaungid and his mood
So was he caught with beaute of this mayde
And to hym self ful pryuely he seyde
This maiden shal be myn for any man
Anoon the feend in to his herte raan
And taghte hym sodeynly that he by slighte
This maide vn to his purpos wynne myghte
For certes by no force ne by mede
Hym thoghte he was nat able for to spede
For she was strong of freendes and ek she
Confermyd was in swich souereyn bountee
That wel he wiste he myght hir neuere wynne
As for to make hir with hir body synne
For which by gret deliberacioıı̄un
He sende after a clerk was in the tou
Whiche that he knew for sotil and for bold
This Iuge vn to the clerk his tale hath told
In secree wise and made hym to ensure
That he shulde telle hit to no creature
And if he dede he shulde lese his heed
And whan assentid was this cursid red
Glad was this Iuge and makid hym gret chere
And yaf hym yistes precious and deer
Whan shapyn was al hir conspiracie
Fro poynt to poynt how that þis leccherie
Parfornied shulde be ful sotilli
As ye shul here hit aftir openly
Hoom goth this cherl that hight Claudius
This false Iuge that hight Apius
So was his name for this is no fable
But knowen for historial thyng notable
The sentence of hit sooth is out of dowte
Thisfalse Iuge goth now faste aboute
To hasten his delit as that he may
And so by fil soone aftir on a day
This false Iuge as tellith Vs the storie
As he was wont sat in his consistorie
And yaf his doomes Vp on sundry cas
This false cherl comth forth a ful gret pas
And said lord if that it be youre wille
As dooth me right Vp on̄ this pitous bille
In which y pleyne vp on virginius
And if that he wole seyn hit is nat thus
I wol hit preue and fynde good witnesse
That sooth is that my bille wole expresse
¶ The Iuge answerde of this in his absence
I may not yeue diffynytif sentence
Lat doon hym calle and y wol gladly here
Thou shalt han right and no wrong as now heer
Virginius cam to wete the Iuges wille
And right a non was red this cursid bille
The sentence of hit was as ye shul here
To you my lord sere Apius so deer
Sheweth youre poore seruant claudius
How that a knyght callid virginius
A geyn the lawe a geyn al equytee
Haldeth expresse agayn the wille of me
Mi seruant whiche that is my thral by right
Which fro myn hous was stolen on a nyght
Whil that she was ful yong this wol y preue
By witnesse lord so that hit noght you greeue
She nys his doghter noght what so he seye
Wherfor to you my lord the Iuge y prey
Yelde me my thral if that hit be youre wille
Lo this was al the sentence of his bille
Virginius gan vp on the cherl beholde
But hastily or he his tale tolde
He wolde han preuyd hit as shulde a knyght
And ek be witnessynge of many a wight
That al was fals that seyde his aduersarie
This cursid Iuge wolde nothyng tarie
Ne here aword more of virginius
But yaf his Iugement and seyde thus
I deme anon this cherl his seruant haue
Thow shat no lengere in thyn hus hir saue
Go brynge hir forth and putte hir in our͗e warde
The cherl shal haue his tharl this y awarde
And whan this worthi knyght Virginius
Thurgh sentence of this Iustice Apius
Muste by force his deer doghter yeuen
Vn to the Iuge in leccherie to lyuen
He gooth hym hoom and sette hym in his halle
And let anon his deer͗e doghtir call
And with a face deed as asshen colde
Vp on hir humble face he gan beholde
With fadris pite stikynge thurgh his herte
Al wolde he from his purpos nat sterte
Doghtir quod he viginea by thi name
Ther ben two weyes outhir deth or shame
That thou muste soffre allas that y was bore
For neuere thou deseruedist wherfore
To dien with a swerd or with a knyf
O deer doghter ender of my lif
Which y haue fostrid vp with swich plesaunce
That thou were neuere out of my remembraunce
O doghtir which that art my laste wo
And in my lif my laste ioye also
O gemme of chastitee in pacience
Take thou thi deth for this is my sentence
For loue and nat for hate thou moste be deed
Mi pitous hand muste smyten of thyn heed
Allas that euere Apius the say
Thus hath he falsly Iugid the to day
And told hir al the cas as ye bifore
Han herd nat nedith for to telle yit moore
MErcy my deer fadir quod this mayde
And with that word she bothe hir Armes leyde
Aboute his necke as she was wont to do
The teres braste out of hir eyen two
And seyde good fadir shal y dye
Ys ther no grace is there no remedye
No certes deer doghtir myn quod he
Thanne yeue me leiser fadir myn quod she
Mi deth for to compleyne alitil space
For parde yaf his doghtir grace
For to compleyne or he hir slow Allas
And god it wot nothyng was hir trespa
But for she ran hir fadir first to se
To welcome hym with gret solempnytee
And with that word she fil swoun anon
And aftir whan hir swonnyng was gon
She risith vp and to hir fader seide
Blessid be god that y shal dye a mayde
Yeue me my deth or that y haue a shame
Doth with youre child youre wille a goddes name
And with that word she preyed hym ful ofte
That with his swerd he wolde smyte hir softe
And with that word a swoune doun she fil
Hir fadir with ful sorwful herte and wil
Hir heed of smot and by the top it hente
And to the Iuge he gan hit to presente
As he saat yit in doom in consistorie
And whan the Iuge it saw as seith the storye
He bad to take hym and anhange hym faste
But right anon a ·Mᵗ· peple in thraste
To saue the knyght for routhe and for pytee
For knowen was this fals Inyquytee
The peple anon hadde suspeit in this thyng
By manere of the cherles chalengyng
That it was be thassent of Apius
They wisten wel that he was leccherous
For which vn to this Apius they gon
And caste hym in a prison right anon
Where as he slow hym selue and claudius
That seruant was vn to this Apyus
Was demed for to hange vp on atree
But that Virgynyus of his pitee
So preyed for hym that he was exilid
And elles certes hadde he be bygilid
The remanant wer an hangid mor and lesse
That consentant were of this cursidness
HEer men may se how synne hath his meritee
Beeth war for no man wot whom god wole smyte
In no degree ne in that manere wise
The worm of concyence may agrise
Of wikkid lif thogh hit so pryue be
That no man wot ther of sauf god and he
For be he lewed man or ellis lerid
He not how sone he shal ben aferid
Therfore y rede you this conseil taake
Forsakith synne or synne you forsaake
Here endith the phisiciens tale
Our ost gan to swere as he were wood
Harrow quod he by nayles and by blood
This was a fals cherl and a fals Iustise
As shamful deth as herte can deuyse
Come to this Iuges and hir aduocas
Alwey this sely mayde is slayn allas
Allas to deer aboghte she beautee
Wherfore y seye alday that man may see
That yiftes of fortune or of nature
Ben cause of deth to many a creature
Of bothe yiftes that y speke of now
Men han fulofte grettere harm than prow
Hir beaute was hir deth y darwel sayn
Allas so pitously as she was slayn
But trewely myn owne maister deer
This was a pitous tale for to here
But natheles passe ouere is no fors
I preye to god so saue thy gentil corps
And thyne Vrnals and also thi Iardones
Thyn ypocras and ek thi galions
And euery boist ful of thi letuarie
God blesse hem and our lady Seynt Mari
So mote y then thou art a propre man
And lik a prelat by seynt Ronyan
Seide I nat wel y cannat speke in terme
But wel y wot thou doost myn herte erme
I haue almost y caught a Cardenacle
By corpus bones but y haue triacle
Or elles a draght of moyst and corny ale
Or but y here a non a myry tale
Myn herte is lost for pyte of this mayde
Thou beal amy thou pardoner he seide
Telle Vs a tale thou caust many on
Hit shal be don quod he and that anon
But first quod he heer at this ale stake
I wolle first drynke and biten on a cake
But right anon the gentils gonne crie
Nay lat hym telle vs of no ribandye
Telle Vs sum moral thyng that we may leer͗e
Gladly quod he and seide as ye shal heer
But in the cuppe wol y me be thynke
Vp on̄ sum honest thyng whil that y drynke
heer is the p̉redicacioıı̄un of the pardoner

l.hi: Ordynges quod he in chirchis whan I preche

div.l: I peyne me to haue an hauteyn speche
And rynge hit out as rounde as goth a bille
For y can al by rote that I telle
My teme is alway on and euere was
First I pronounce whennes y come
And thanne my bullis sw shewe I alle and sōmme
Our lege lordes seel on my patente
That shewe I first my body to warente
That no man be so bold no preest ne clerk
Me to destorbe of cristes holy wer
And aftir that thanne telle y forth my tales
Bullis of popes and of cardinales
Of patriarkes and bisshoppes I shewe
And in latyn y speke awordes Fewe
To saffron with my predicaciou
And for to stere hem to deuociou
Thanne shew y forth my longe cristal stonis
I crammed ful of clowtes and of bonis
Relikis they ben as wenen they echou
Thanne haue I in latou a shuldre bon
Which that was of an hooly Iewes shep
Good men sey I take of my wordes keep
If that this bon be wasshe in ony welle
If cow or calf or sheep or oxe swelle
That ony wronn hath ete or worm ystonge
Take watir of that welle and wasshe his tonge
And it is hool anon and forthermor
Of pokkes and of scabbe and eueri sor
Shal eueri sheep be hol that of this welle
Drynkith a draght take keep ek what y telle
If that the goodman that the beestes owith
Wole euery weke or that the cok hym crowith
Fastyng drynkyn of this welle a draght
As thilke holy Iew our eldres taghte
His bestes and his stoor shal multiplye
And sere also hit helith Ielousie
For thogh a man be fallen in Ielous rage
Lat makyn with this water his potage
And neuere shal he more his wif mistriste
Thogh he the sothe of hir defaute wiste
Al haue she taken prestes two or three
Heer is a myten ek that ye may see
He that his hand wil putte in this myteyn
He shal haue multiplyynge of his greyn
Whan he hath sowen be hit whete or otes
So that they offre pens or elles grootes
goodmen and wommen o thyng warne y you
If ony wight be in this chirche nowe
That hath doon synne horible that he
Dar not for shame of hit y shryuen be
Or ony womman be she yong or old
That hath ymaad hir housbonde Cok wold
Swich folk shul han no power ne no grace
To offre to my Reliques in this place
And ho so fyndith hym out of swiche blame
He wol come vp and offre a goddes name
And y assoile hym be the autorite
Which that be bulle grauntid was to me
by this gaude haue y wonnen euery yeer
An C . mark syn y was Pardoner
. I stonde lik a clerk in my pulpit
And whan the lewed peple is doun yset
I preche so as ye han herd before
And telle an C falce iapes more
Thanne peyne y me to strecch forth the nekke
And Est and west vp on the peple y bekke
As doth a dowue syttyng on a berne
Mym hondes and my tonge gon so yerne
That it is ioye to see my bisinesse
Of auerice and of swich cursidnesse
Is al my prechyng for to make hem free
To yeue hir pens and manely vn to me
For myn entent is naght but for to wynne
And no thyng for correcciou of synne
I recke neuere whan that they be beried
Thogh that hir sowles gon a blakeberied
For certes many a predicaciou
Comyth often tyme of il entenciou
For sum plesance of folk and flaterie
To ben auanced by ypocrecye
And sum for veyn glorie and sum for hate
For whan y dar non othir weyes debate
Thanne wil y stynge hym with my tonge smerte
In prechyng so that he shal nat asterte
To be defamed falsly if that he
Hath trespased to my brethern or to me
For thogh y telle nought his propre name
Men shul wel knowen that hit is the same
Be sygnes an be othir circumstances
Thus quyte y folk that don vs displesances
Thus spitte y out my wenem vndir hewe
Of holynesse to seme holy and trewe
But shortly my entent y wol deuyse
I preche of no thyng but for coueytyse
Therfore my teme is yit and euere was
thus can y preche ageyn the same vice
Which that y vse and that is auerice
But thogh myselue be gilte in that synne
Yit can I maken othir folk to twynne
From auerice and sore to repente
But that is nat my pryncipal entente
I preche nothyng but for coueytise
Of this mater hit owghte y now suffice
Thanne telle y hem ensamples many on
Of olde stories longe tyme agon
For lewde peple louen tales olde
Swich thynges can they wel reporte and holde
What trowe ye that whiles y may preche
And wynne gold and siluer for y teche
That y wol leue in pouert wilfully
Nay nay I thoghte hit neuere trewely
For y wol preche and begge in sundri landes
I wol nat do no labour with myn handes
Ne make baskestes and leue ther by
By cause y wil nat beggen ydelly
I wol noon of thapostles contrefete
I wol haue monye wolle chese and whete
Al were hit yeuen of the porest page
Or of the porest wydue in a village
Al shulde hir children sterue or for famyne
Nay y wol drynkyn lycour of the vyne
And haue a goly wenche in the toun
but herkenyth lordes in conclusiou
Your likyng is that y shal telle a tale
Now I haue y dronke a draght of corny ale
By god y hope y shal you telle a thyng
That shal by resou be at your lykyng
For thogh myself be a ful vicious man
A moral tale yit y you telle can
Which I am wont to preche for to wynne
Now hald your pees my tale y wol begynne

l.hi: First he repreuyth the vice of glotonye

div.l: In Flandres was whilom a compaignie
Of yonge folk that hauntedyn folye
As ryot hazard stewes and Tauernes
Where as with harpees lutes and gyternes
They daunce and pleye at des both day and nyght
And ete also and drynke euer hir myght
Thurgh whiche they doon the deuel sacrifice
With inne the deueles temple in cursid wise
By suꝓprofluyte abhomynable
Hir othis be so grete and dampable
That it is gresly for to heer hem swere
Oure blisful lordes sydes they to tere
Hem thoghte Iewes rente hym noght y now
And eche of hem at othris synne lowh
And right anon in Comyn Tumbesteres
Fetise and smale and yonge fruytesteres
Syngers with harpes baudes wafereres
Which be the verray deueles Officers
To kyndle and blowe the fir of leccherie
That is annexid vn to glotonye
The holy writte take y to my witnesse
That luxurie is in wyn and dronkenesse
Lo how that dronken loth vnkyndely
Lay by his doghtris two vnwetyngly
So dronke he was he nyste what he wroght
Herodes ho so wol the storye soghte
Whan he of wyn repleet was at his feste
Right at his owene table he yaf his heste
To sle the Baptist Iohn ful giltelees
senek seith a good word dowteles
He seith he can no difference fynde
Be twixe a man that is out of his mynde
And a man which that is drunkelewe
But that woodnesse fallyn in a shrewe
Ꝓproseuerith lengere than dooth drunkenesse
O glotonye ful of cursidnesse
O cause first of oure confusiou
O original of owre dampnaciou
Til crist hadde boght vs with his blood ageyn
Lokith how dere shortly for to seyn
A boght was thilke cursid vilenye
Corrupt was al this world for glotonye
Adam our fadir and his wif also
Fro paradys to labour and to wo
Were dryuen for that vice hit is no drede
For whil that Adam fastid as y reede
He was in paradys and whan that he
Ete of the fruyt deffendid on a tree
Anon he was out cast to wo and peyne
O glotounye on the wel oghte vs pleyne
O wiste a man how many maledyes
Folwen of excesse and of glotonyes
He wolde ben the more mesurable
Of his diete sittynge at his table
allas the shorte throte the tendre mough
Makith that Est and west and north and south
In erthe in eir in water men to swynke
To gete a glotou deyntee mete and drynke
Of this matere o pawle wel canstow treete
Mete vnto wombe and wombe ek vnto mete
Shal god destroien bothe as paulus seith
Allas aful thyng is it by my feith
To seyn this word and fouler is the dede
Whan man so drynkith of the whit and rede
That of his throte he makith his pryuee
Thurgh thilke cursid suꝓprofluytee
Thapostil wepyng seith ful pitously
Ther walken manye of which you told haue I
I sey it now wepyng with pitous vois
That ther ben enemys of cristes crois
Of which the ende is deth wombe is here god
O wombe o bely o stynkynge cod
Fulfild of dung and of corupciou
At either ende of the foul is the sou
How greet labour and cost is the to fynde
This cooke how they stampe and stryne and grynde
And turnen substance in to accident
To fulfille al thi likorous talent
Out of the hard bones knokken they
The mary for they casten naght a wey
That may go thurgh the golet softe and soote
Of spicerie of leef of bark and roote
Shal ben his saule y makid bi delyt
To make hym ȝit a newere appetit
But certes he that hauntith swich delites
Is deid whil that he leuyth in tho vice
a leccherous thyng is wyn and drounkenesse
Ful of stryuyng and of wrecchidnesse
O dronken man disfigured is thi face
Sour is thi breth foul art thou to embrace
And thurgh thi dronken nose semeth the sou
As though thy thou seydest ay sampsou Sampsou
And yit god wot sampsou drank neuere no wyn
Thou fallist as hit were a stiked swyn
Thi tonge is lost and al thyn honest cur
For dronkenesse is verray sepultur
Of mannes wit and his discreciou
In whom that drynk hath d
He can no conseil kepen
Now kepe you fro
And namely
That
Lokith the bible and nis ther ye may hit leer
look attila the greete conquerour
Dide in his slep with shame and dishonour
Bledyng ay at his nose in dronkenesse
A capitayn shuld leue in sobrenesse
And oủere al this auiʆsiri auisith you right wel
That was commandid vn to lamuel
Nat samuel but lamuel seide I
Redith the bille and fynde hit expressely
Of wyn yeuynge to hym that haue Iustise
more of this for hit may wel suffise
w that y haue spoke of glotonye
you deffenden hasardie
loosynges
es
And there seyde I wol nat lese myn name
I wol nat take on me so gret deffame
You for tallie vn to non hasardours
Sendith sum othre wyse Ambassatours
For by my trouthe me were leuere dye
Thanne y you shulde to hasardours Allie
For ye that be so glorious in honours
Shul nat allie you to non hasardours
As by my wille ne as by my tretee
This wise philosophre thus seid he
looke ek that to the kyng demetrius
The kyng of parches as the book seith vs
Sente hym a pere of dies of gold in scorn
For he hadde vsid hasard ther beforn
For which he hild his glorie or his renou
At no value or reputaciou
Lordes may fynden othir maner pley
Honest I now to dryue the day away
Now wol y speke of othis false and greete
A word or two as olde bookes treete
¶ How he repreuyth the vise of swerynge
gret swerynge is athyng abhomynable
And fals sweryng is yit more repreuable
The hye god forbad swerynge at al
Witnesse on Mathew but in special
Of swerynge seith the holy Ieromye
Thou shalt swere sooth thyn othis and nat lye
And swere in doom and ek in rightwisnesse
But idel swerynge is a cursidnesse
Be holde and se that in the firste table
Of hye goddis hestes honurable
How that the ij heste of hym is this
Take nat my name in ydil or amys
Lo rather he forbedeth swich swerynge
Than homicyde or many an othir thynge
I sey ek be ordre thus hit stondith
This knoweth that his hestes vndirstandith
How that the ij heste of god is that
And forthermore y wolle the telle al plat
That vengeance shal nat parte from his hous
That of his othes is coutageous
By goddes precious herte and by his nayles
And by the blood of Crist that is in hayles
Vijᵉ is my chaunce and thyn is cynk and treye
By goddes Armes if thou falsly pleye
This daggere shal thurgh out thyn herte go
This fruyt comyth of the bichet bones two
For swerynge ire falsnesse homycide
Now for the loue of crist that for vs dide
Letith youre othis bothe grete and smale
But sires now wol y telle forth my tale

Her begynnyth the
pardoner is tale of
the forseid riotours
this riotours thre of whiche y telle
Long erst or pryme rong or ony belle
Were set hem in a Tauerne to drynke
And as they sat they herde a belle thynke
Beforn a corps was caried to his graue
That on of hem gan callen to his knaue
Go bet quod he and axe redely
What corps is this that passith heer forby
And loke that thou reporte his name wel
Sere quod this boy it nedith neuer adel
Hit was me told or ye cam her . ij . houres
He was parde an old felawe of youres
And sodeynly he was yslayn to nyght
